title: Moosally v. W. W. Norton Company
description: In these civil actions, Appellants contend the trial judge erred in dismissing the cases pursuant to Rule 12(b) motions for lack of subject matter jurisdiction and lack of personal jurisdiction.  These actions emanate from the death of 47 men on the USS IOWA.  A book titled "A Glimpse of Hell" was written by Respondent Thompson, using Respondent Meyer, as a collaborator and published by W.W. Norton.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Fred Moosally, Joseph Miceli, John Morse and Robert D. Finney,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

  v.

  
    
      
W.W. Norton & Company, Inc., Charles C. Thompson, II, and Daniel Meyer,       
Respondents.
      
    
  



  
    
      
Dale E. Mortensen,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

  v.

  
    
      
W.W. Norton & Company, Inc., Charles C. Thompson, II, and Daniel Meyer,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3769
Heard March 11, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  5, 2004

AFFIRMED AS TO THOMPSON AND MEYER; 
  REVERSED AND REMANDED AS TO W.W. NORTON


  
    
      
Stephen F. DeAntonio, of Charleston, for Appellants.
John J. Kerr and David B. McCormack, both of Charleston, 
  for Respondents W.W. Norton & Company, Inc., and Charles C. Thompson, II.
Daniel P. Meyer, of Washington, D.C., pro se.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Fred Moosally, Joseph Miceli, John Morse, Robert D. Finney 
  and Dale E. Mortensen (collectively referred to as â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal from 
  the trial courtâ€™s grant of motions to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction 
  to W.W. Norton & Company, Inc., Charles C. Thompson, II, and Daniel Meyer 
  (collectively referred to as â€œRespondentsâ€).Â  Additionally, Appellants appeal 
  from the trial courtâ€™s grant of Respondent W.W. Nortonâ€™s motion to dismiss pursuant 
  to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-150 (1977), the door closing statute.Â  We affirm as 
  to Thompson and Meyer.Â  We reverse and remand as to W.W. Norton.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On the morning of April 19, 1989, the center 16â€ gun in Gun Turret 
  Two of the battleship USS IOWA exploded, killing 47 sailors.Â  As an event of 
  national concern, the explosion was made the subject of two CBS 60 Minutes 
  programs of which Respondent Thompson, a Virginia resident, was a producer.Â  
  Subsequently, Respondent W.W. Norton, a New York publishing company, contracted 
  with Thompson to write a book explaining the events leading up to and following 
  the explosion aboard the battleship.Â  In preparing his manuscript, Thompson 
  interviewed over 200 individuals, one of whom was Respondent Meyer, a resident 
  of Maryland.Â  The ensuing book, A Glimpse of Hell, was first published 
  in March 1999 and distributed throughout the United States, including South 
  Carolina.
In March and April of 2001, Appellants filed suit against Respondents, asserting 
  causes of action for libel, false light privacy, and conspiracy. [1] Â  Specifically, Moosally, Miceli, 
  Morse, and Finney allege the book contains numerous falsities that suggest their 
  actions led to the deaths of the sailors aboard the battleship.Â  Mortensen avers 
  â€œthe book contains numerous falsehoods, inaccuracies and defamatory statements 
  that both libel and slander the Plaintiff.â€
In April of 2001, Respondents filed motions to dismiss pursuant to 
  Rule 12(b)(2), SCRCP, for lack of personal jurisdiction.Â  Additionally, Respondent 
  W.W. Norton moved to dismiss the complaints pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-150 
  (1977), commonly known as South Carolinaâ€™s door closing statute.Â  Following 
  a hearing, the Circuit Court entered separate orders dismissing the claims against 
  all three Respondents.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The question of personal jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant is one which 
  must be resolved upon the facts of each particular case.Â  Engineered Prods. 
  v. Cleveland Crane & Engâ€™g, 262 S.C. 1, 201 S.E.2d 921 (1974).Â  The 
  decision of the trial court should be affirmed unless unsupported by the evidence 
  or influenced by an error of law.Â  Engineered Prods., 262 S.C. at 4, 
  201 S.E.2d at 922; see also Hammond v. Cummins Engine Co., 287 
  S.C. 200, 336 S.E.2d 867 (1985) (stating that this Court is bound by Circuit 
  Courtâ€™s finding that nonresident defendant is subject to its jurisdiction absent 
  determination that Circuit Courtâ€™s ruling is without evidentiary support or 
  controlled by error of law); Industrial Equip. Co. v. Frank G. Hough Co., 
  218 S.C. 169, 173, 61 S.E.2d 884, 885 (1950) (â€œ[T]his Court has adhered to the 
  rule that a finding by the Circuit Court as to jurisdiction or lack of jurisdiction 
  will not be disturbed on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence or 
  manifestly influenced or controlled by error of law.â€).
It is well-settled that the party seeking to invoke personal jurisdiction over 
  a non-resident defendant via our long-arm statute bears the burden of proving 
  the existence of personal jurisdiction.Â  Southern Plastics Co. v. Southern 
  Commerce Bank, 310 S.C. 256, 423 S.E.2d 128 (1992); Aviation Assocs. 
  & Consultants, Inc. v. Jet Time, Inc., 303 S.C. 502, 402 S.E.2d 177 
  (1991); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Basnight, 346 S.C. 241, 
  551 S.E.2d 274 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  At the pretrial stage, the burden of proving 
  personal jurisdiction over a nonresident is met by a prima facie showing of 
  jurisdiction either in the complaint or in affidavits.Â  Mid-State Distribs., 
  Inc. v. Century Importers, Inc., 310 S.C. 330, 426 S.E.2d 777 (1993); White 
  v. Stephens, 300 S.C. 241, 387 S.E.2d 260 (1990); International Mariculture 
  Res. v. Grant, 336 S.C. 434, 520 S.E.2d 160 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  JURISDICTION
Appellants argue the Circuit Court erred in dismissing the claims against Meyer, 
  Thompson and W.W. Norton for lack of personal jurisdiction.
The determination of whether a court may exercise personal jurisdiction over 
  a nonresident defendant involves a two-step analysis.Â  Hammond v. Butler, 
  Means, Evins & Brown, 300 S.C. 458, 388 S.E.2d 796 (1990); South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Basnight, 346 S.C. 241, 551 S.E.2d 274 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  First, in order for the courts to have statutory authority 
  to exercise jurisdiction, the nonresident defendantâ€™s conduct must meet the 
  requirements of South Carolinaâ€™s long-arm statute.Â  White v. Stephens, 
  300 S.C. 241, 387 S.E.2d 260 (1990).Â  Second, the exercise of jurisdiction must 
  comport with the requirements of the due process clause.Â  Southern Plastics 
  Co. v. Southern Commerce Bank, 310 S.C. 256, 423 S.E.2d 128 (1992).Â  The 
  defendant must have sufficient contacts with South Carolina so that the constitutional 
  standards of due process are not violated.Â  White, 300 S.C. at 245, 387 
  S.E.2d at 262; Basnight, 346 S.C. at 246, 551 S.E.2d at 277; International 
  Mariculture Res. v. Grant, 336 S.C. 434, 520 S.E.2d 160 (Ct. App. 1999).
South Carolinaâ€™s long-arm statute provides:

(1) A court may exercise personal jurisdiction over a person who acts directly 
  or by an agent as to a cause of action arising from the personâ€™s
  
(a) transacting any business in this State;
(b) contracting to supply services or things in the State;
(c) commission of a tortious act in whole or in part in this State;
(d) causing tortious injury or death in this State by an act or omission outside 
  this State if he regularly does or solicits business, or engages in any other 
  persistent course of conduct, or derives substantial revenue from goods used 
  or consumed or services rendered, in this State; or
(e) having an interest in, using, or possessing real property in this State; 
  or
(f) contracting to insure any person, property or risk located within this State 
  at the time of contracting; or
(g) entry into a contract to be performed in whole or in part by either party 
  in this State; or
(h) production, manufacture, or distribution of goods with the reasonable expectation 
  that those goods are to be used or consumed in this State and are so used or 
  consumed.
  
(2) When jurisdiction over a person is based solely upon 
  this section, only a cause of action arising from acts enumerated in this section 
  may be asserted against him, and such action, if brought in this State, shall 
  not be subject to the provisions of Â§ 15-7-100 (3).

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-803 (2003).
Our long-arm statute, which affords broad power to exercise personal jurisdiction 
  over causes of action arising from tortious injuries in South Carolina, has 
  been construed to extend to the outer limits of the due process clause.Â  Meyer 
  v. Paschal, 330 S.C. 175, 498 S.E.2d 635 (1998); Hammond v. Cummins Engine 
  Co., 287 S.C. 200, 336 S.E.2d 867 (1985); see also Cozi Investments 
  v. Schneider, 272 S.C. 354, 252 S.E.2d 116 (1979) (stating that South Carolinaâ€™s 
  long-arm statute has been construed as a grant of jurisdiction as broad as constitutionally 
  permissible; hence, parameters of statute are restricted only by due process 
  limitations).Â  Because we treat our long-arm statute as coextensive with the 
  due process clause, the sole question becomes whether the exercise of personal 
  jurisdiction in this case would violate the strictures of due process.Â  See 
  Sonoco Products Co. v. Inteplast Corp., 867 F. Supp. 352, 354 (D.S.C. 
  1994) (â€œThe South Carolina long-arm statute . . . has been interpreted to reach 
  to the limits of due processâ€; â€œ[t]herefore, the determination of personal jurisdiction 
  in South Carolina compresses into a due process assessment of minimum contacts 
  and fair play.â€); Ryobi America Corp. v. Peters, 815 F. Supp. 172, 175 
  (D.S.C. 1993) (â€œThe Long-Arm Statute in South Carolina is construed to extend 
  jurisdiction to the limits of Due Process.Â  Because the extent of the statute 
  and the relevant constitutional tests are the same, the inquiry for this court 
  is simply whether the exercise of jurisdiction over Jerry Peters violates his 
  right to Due Process.â€) (citation omitted).
The Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment limits the power of a state 
  court to exert personal jurisdiction over a nonresident defendant.Â  Asahi 
  Metal Ind. Co. v. Superior Court, 480 U.S. 102 (1987).Â  Due process requires 
  that there exist minimum contacts between the defendant and the forum state 
  such that maintenance of the suit does not offend traditional notions of fair 
  play and substantial justice.Â  Burger King Corp. v. Rudzewicz, 471 U.S. 
  462 (1985); Aviation Assocs. & Consultants, Inc. v. Jet Time, Inc., 
  303 S.C. 502, 402 S.E.2d 177 (1991); see also Quill Corp. v. North 
  Dakota, 504 U.S. 298, 307 (1992) (â€œ[W]e have abandoned more formalistic 
  tests that focused on a defendantâ€™s â€˜presenceâ€™ within a State in favor of a 
  more flexible inquiry into whether a defendantâ€™s contacts with the forum made 
  it reasonable, in the context of our federal system of Government, to require 
  it to defend the suit in that State.â€); International Shoe Co. v. Washington, 
  326 U.S. 310 (1945) (noting due process clause requires that maintenance of 
  lawsuit against nonresident must not offend traditional notions of fair play 
  and substantial justice).Â  The due process requirement mandates the defendant 
  possess sufficient minimum contacts with the forum state, so that he could reasonably 
  anticipate being haled into court there.Â  World-Wide Volkswagen Corp. v. 
  Woodson, 444 U.S. 286 (1980); Atlantic Soft Drink Co. v. South Carolina 
  Natâ€™l Bank, 287 S.C. 228, 336 S.E.2d 876 (1985).
In deciding whether a finding of minimum contacts comports with the due process 
  requirements of traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice, the 
  court must consider: (1) the duration of the activity of the nonresident within 
  the state; (2) the character and circumstances of the commission of the nonresidentâ€™s 
  acts; (3) the inconvenience resulting to the parties by conferring or refusing 
  to confer jurisdiction over the nonresident; and (4) the Stateâ€™s interest in 
  exercising jurisdiction.Â  Clark v. Key, 304 S.C. 497, 405 S.E.2d 599 
  (1991); Colite Indus., Inc. v. G.W. Murphy Constr. Co., 297 S.C. 426, 
  377 S.E.2d 321 (1989); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Basnight, 
  346 S.C. 241, 551 S.E.2d 274 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  A single transaction is sufficient 
  to confer jurisdiction if these factors are met.Â  Colite Indus., 297 
  S.C. at 429, 377 S.E.2d at 322; Hammond, 287 S.C. at 203, 336 S.E.2d 
  at 868-69; see also Askins v. Firedoor Corp., 281 S.C. 611, 616, 
  316 S.E.2d 713, 716 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œThe cases are legion that a single contact 
  with the forum state is sufficient to give its courts personal jurisdiction 
  over a nonresident if the contact gives rise to, or figures prominently in the 
  cause of action under consideration.â€).Â  Although a single act may support jurisdiction, 
  it must create a â€œsubstantial connectionâ€ with the forum.Â  Burger King Corp., 
  471 U.S. at 475 n.18; White v. Stephens, 300 S.C. 241, 247, 387 S.E.2d 
  260, 263 (1990).Â  A single act that causes harm in this State may create sufficient 
  minimum contacts where the harm arises out of or relates to that act.Â  Southern 
  Plastics Co. v. Southern Commerce Bank, 310 S.C. 256, 423 S.E.2d 128 (1992).Â Â  

The determination of whether the requirements of due process are satisfied 
  involves a two-prong analysis: (1) the â€œpowerâ€ prong, in which minimum contacts 
  provide courts the â€œpowerâ€ to adjudicate the action; and (2) the â€œfairnessâ€ 
  prong, which requires the exercise of jurisdiction to be â€œreasonableâ€ or â€œfair.â€Â  
  Southern Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 260, 423 S.E.2d at 131.Â  â€œIf either 
  prong fails, the exercise of personal jurisdiction over the [nonresident] defendant 
  fails to comport with the requirements of due process.â€Â  Id.
Under the power prong, a minimum contacts analysis requires a court to find 
  that the defendant directed its activities to residents of South Carolina and 
  that the cause of action arises out of or relates to those activities.Â  Burger 
  King Corp., 471 U.S. at 472; Southern Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 260, 
  423 S.E.2d at 131.Â  Without minimum contacts, the court does not have the â€œpowerâ€ 
  to adjudicate the action.Â  Southern Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 260, 423 
  S.E.2d at 131.Â  It is essential in each case that there be some act by which 
  the defendant purposefully avails itself of the privilege of conducting activities 
  within the forum state, thus invoking the benefits and protections of its laws.Â  
  Hanson v. Denckla, 357 U.S. 235 (1958); Southern Plastics Co., 
  310 S.C. at 261, 423 S.E.2d at 131; see also Burger King Corp., 
  471 U.S. at 474 (stating the constitutional touchstone of determination whether 
  exercise of personal jurisdiction comports with due process is whether defendant 
  purposefully established minimum contacts in forum state).Â  The â€œpurposeful 
  availmentâ€ requirement ensures that a defendant will not be haled into a jurisdiction 
  solely as a result of random, fortuitous, or attenuated contacts.Â  Burger 
  King Corp., 471 U.S. at 475; Southern Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 262, 
  423 S.E.2d at 132.Â  Whether the constitutional requirement of minimum contacts 
  has been met depends on the facts of each case.Â  Burger King Corp., 471 
  U.S. at 485-86; Security Credit Leasing, Inc. v. Armaly, 339 S.C. 533, 
  529 S.E.2d 283 (Ct. App. 2000).
Under the fairness prong, we examine such factors as the burden on the defendant, 
  the extent of the plaintiffâ€™s interest, South Carolinaâ€™s interest, efficiency 
  of adjudication, and the several statesâ€™ interest in substantive social policies.Â  
  See Southern Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 263, 423 S.E.2d at 132.Â  
  While choice of law analysis is separate and distinct from personal jurisdiction 
  analysis, which stateâ€™s law controls is a factor to be considered under the 
  fairness prong of due process.Â  Burger King Corp., 471 U.S. at 481-82.
Because the due process requirements must be met as to each defendant, we must 
  assess individually each defendantâ€™s contacts with South Carolina.Â  See 
  Rush v. Savchuk, 444 U.S. 320 (1980); Allen v. Columbia Fin. Mgmt., 
  Ltd., 297 S.C. 481, 377 S.E.2d 352 (Ct. App. 1988).
A.Â  Meyer
Initially, we note Meyerâ€™s contacts with South Carolina appear to be limited 
  to this litigation.Â  Appellants aver that Meyer has satisfied the minimum contacts 
  requirement through assistance he gave to Thompson as one of the bookâ€™s sources 
  and through his work on the movie version of the book.Â  Notably, none of these 
  things were done within South Carolina.Â  One does not â€œpurposefully availâ€ himself 
  of this Stateâ€™s laws merely by providing information to an author about an event 
  that did not occur in South Carolina.Â  To hold otherwise would be to extend 
  jurisdiction over anyone interviewed by any publication about any event, no 
  matter where it occurred.Â  Indeed, such are the â€œrandomâ€ and â€œfortuitousâ€ contacts 
  the due process clause precludes from serving as the basis for jurisdiction.Â  
  See Southern Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 262, 423 S.E.2d at 132.
Because Meyerâ€™s contacts with this state are virtually nonexistent, the power 
  prong of the due process analysis is not satisfied.Â  Thus, the Circuit Court 
  correctly determined that it could not properly exercise jurisdiction over Meyer.Â  
  See Southern Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 261, 423 S.E.2d at 131 
  (â€œIf either prong fails, the exercise of personal jurisdiction over the defendant 
  fails to comport with the requirements of due process.â€).
B.Â  Thompson
Appellants claim the minimum contacts requirement is met as to Thompson.Â  
  We disagree with this assertion.
Appellants essentially allege that the following activities by Thompson satisfy 
  the minimum contacts requirement: (1) Thompson was a producer on the television 
  show 60 Minutes, which airs in South Carolina; (2) he attended a funeral 
  in South Carolina in 1972 as a reporter for CBS; (3) copies of his book were 
  sold in South Carolina; (4) a movie version of his book was aired in South Carolina 
  on the FX network; and (5) he â€œmade at least one business call to South Carolina 
  for information on the IOWA.â€Â  Thompsonâ€™s personal contacts with South Carolina 
  consisted of one telephone call and attendance at a funeral in 1972.Â  Appellants 
  have cited no authority indicating that involvement with a nationally distributed 
  television program is sufficient to satisfy minimum contacts.Â  Moreover, an 
  individual does not â€œpurposefully availâ€ himself of the laws of this State merely 
  by virtue of having authored a single literary work on a topic of national interest.Â  
  See Southern Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 262, 423 S.E.2d at 132.
Because the subject matter of Thompsonâ€™s manuscript was an event of national 
  interest that occurred outside South Carolina, it does not follow that his activity 
  of pressing pen to paper was directed to the residents of South Carolina.Â  The 
  fruits of his laborâ€”be it in literary or in cinematic formâ€”arrived in South 
  Carolina not through his efforts, but through the efforts of others, and therefore 
  cannot serve as the basis for jurisdiction.Â  See Aviation Assocs. 
  & Consultants, Inc. v. Jet Time, Inc., 303 S.C. 502, 507, 402 S.E.2d 
  177, 180 (1991) (â€œ[T]he focus must center on the contacts generated by the defendant, 
  and not on the unilateral actions of some other entity.â€); Allen v. Columbia 
  Fin. Mgmt., Ltd., 297 S.C. 481, 490, 377 S.E.2d 352, 377 (Ct. App. 1988) 
  (â€œDue Process requires us to examine each [defendantâ€™s] own contacts with South 
  Carolina. We decline to attribute the contacts of one alleged conspirator to 
  another alleged conspirator.â€) (citation omitted).
The â€œpowerâ€ prong of the due process analysis is not met as to Thompson.Â  Consequently, 
  the trial court correctly ruled that it lacked jurisdiction.
C.Â  W.W. Norton
Appellants contend the Circuit Court had personal jurisdiction over 
  W.W. Norton.Â  We agree.
Initially, W.W. Norton admits that it is â€œâ€˜doing businessâ€™ in South 
  Carolina for purposes of the long-arm statute.â€
In analyzing the second step necessary to exercise personal jurisdiction over 
  a nonresident defendant, we examine whether the exercise of personal jurisdiction 
  over W.W. Norton comports with the requirements of the due process clause.Â  
  See Southern Plastics Co. v. Southern Commerce Bank, 310 S.C. 
  256, 423 S.E.2d 128 (1992).
In support of their argument that the Circuit Court had jurisdiction over W.W. 
  Norton, Appellants cite Keeton v. Hustler Magazine, Inc., 465 U.S. 770 
  (1984), where the United States Supreme Court applied the minimum contacts analysis 
  to allegations of libel.Â  In Keeton, a New York resident brought a libel 
  suit in a New Hampshire court against a nationally circulated magazine publisher 
  incorporated in Ohio.Â  Holding that the sale of 10,000 to 15,000 copies of the 
  magazine in New Hampshire each month was sufficient to support the assertion 
  of jurisdiction in a libel action based on the magazineâ€™s contents, the Court 
  noted that â€œregular monthly sales of thousands of magazines cannot by any stretch 
  of the imagination be characterized as random, isolated, or fortuitous.â€Â  Keeton, 
  465 U.S. at 774; see also Burger King, 471 U.S. at 473 (â€œ[A] publisher 
  who distributes magazines in a distant State may fairly be held accountable 
  in that forum for damages resulting there from an allegedly defamatory story.â€).
Similarly, W.W. Norton has continually endeavored to exploit the South Carolina 
  market.Â  W.W. Norton produced discovery documents and responses including a 
  list of approximately 315 bookstores in South Carolina in which W.W. Norton 
  sold books.Â  Many of these books are sold to educational institutions in South 
  Carolina.Â  Stephen King, Chief Financial Officer of W.W. Norton, affirmed that 
  twenty-five copies of A Glimpse of Hell were sold to bookstores in South 
  Carolina.Â  Furthermore, the book has been purchased by and circulated in libraries 
  in South Carolina.Â  Specifically, the Charleston County Public Library has five 
  copies which have circulated at least forty-one times.Â  It is reasonable to 
  assume that a library will disseminate books in its collection.Â  The check-out 
  process and procedure constitutes a separate and distinct dissemination of the 
  books which is, in actuality, a republication.
W.W. Norton has published 7,852 titles in the past twenty years and admits 
  â€œ[i]t is fair to assume that at least one copy of each title was distributed 
  in South Carolina.â€Â  A number of W.W. Nortonâ€™s employees cover South Carolina 
  as sales representatives and visit college campuses for the purpose of selling 
  books.Â  W.W. Norton has had small book fairs in South Carolina, a media demo, 
  and has hosted a breakfast for the English Department at the College of Charleston.Â  
  That the Charleston County Public Library system alone owns 2,900 titles published 
  by W.W. Norton is a testament to the publishing companyâ€™s commercial presence 
  within South Carolina.Â  In this manner, W.W. Norton has directed its activities 
  at the residents of South Carolina, and it must reasonably anticipate being 
  haled into court here in a libel action based on the contents of one of its 
  publications.Â  See Keeton, 465 U.S. at 775-76.Â  W.W. Nortonâ€™s 
  continual practice of marketing and distributing books in South Carolina satisfies 
  the power prong of the due process analysis.
With the power prong satisfied, we turn next to the fairness prong, which requires 
  the exercise of jurisdiction to be â€œreasonableâ€ or â€œfair.â€Â  See Southern 
  Plastics Co. v. Southern Commerce Bank, 310 S.C. 256, 259, 423 S.E.2d 128, 
  130 (1992).Â  Under this prong, we look to the following factors to determine 
  whether the exercise of personal jurisdiction is fair:

â€œthe burden on the defendant[;] . . . the forum stateâ€™s interest in adjudicating 
  the dispute; the plaintiffâ€™s interest in obtaining convenient and effective 
  relief; the interstate judicial systemâ€™s interest in obtaining the most efficient 
  solution to controversies; and the shared interest of the several states in 
  furthering fundamental substantive social policies.â€

Southern Plastics Co., 310 S.C. at 263, 423 S.E.2d at 132 (quoting World-Wide 
  Volkswagen Corp., 444 U.S. 286 (1980)).
 We note that the burden on W.W. Norton is negligible because â€œ[n]o 
  unconstitutional burden is imposed on a foreign corporation by requiring it 
  to defend a suit in a forum located in a state where it has advertised and sold 
  a product whose use gave rise to the cause of action.â€Â  Hardy v. Pioneer 
  Parachute Co., 531 F.2d 193, 195 (4th Cir. 1976).Â  Moreover, applying the 
  relevant factors to the facts of the present case, we perceive no unconstitutional 
  unfairness in requiring W.W. Norton to litigate this matter in a forum where 
  it has regularly directed its business.Â  Concomitantly, we hold that the trial 
  court erred in concluding it did not have personal jurisdiction over W.W. Norton.
II.Â  DOOR CLOSING STATUTE
Appellants assert the trial court erred in determining they were barred from 
  bringing suit against W.W. Norton by South Carolinaâ€™s door closing statute.Â  
  We agree.
South Carolinaâ€™s door closing statute reads:

An action against a corporation created by or under the laws of any other state, 
  government or country may be brought in the circuit court:
  
(1) By any resident of this State for any cause of action; or
(2) By a plaintiff not a resident of this State when the cause of action shall 
  have arisen or the subject of the action shall be situated within this State.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-150 (1977).Â  Initially, the parties incorrectly frame 
  the issue of the door closing statute as one of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  
  Although there has been some confusion on this matter, our Supreme Court recently 
  clarified: â€œÂ§ 15-5-150 does not involve subject matter jurisdiction but rather 
  determines the capacity of a party to sue.â€Â  Farmer v. Monsanto Corp., 
  353 S.C. 553, 557, 579 S.E.2d 325, 327 (2003) (overruling previous holding otherwise).
Because none of the Appellants are residents of South Carolina, our determination 
  of their capacity to sue W.W. Norton turns on whether their cause of action 
  arose within this State.Â  In support of their contention that the libel action 
  arose in South Carolina, Appellants rely on Keeton v. Hustler Magazine, Inc., 
  465 U.S. 770 (1984).Â  In Keeton, the United States Supreme Court determined 
  the â€œtort of libel is generally held to occur wherever the offending material 
  is circulated.â€Â  Id. at 777.Â  The question in Keeton was one of 
  jurisdiction.Â  The issue before us is the applicability of the door closing 
  statute.
In Murphy v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., 356 S.C. 592, 590 S.E.2d 
  479 (2003), a latent disease case, the Supreme Court ruled:

In order for Janet to bring her suit in South Carolina, she must meet the Door 
  Closing Statuteâ€™s requirement that â€œthe cause of action shall have arisen . 
  . . within this State.â€Â  Â§ 15-5-150(2).Â  Janetâ€™s complaint unequivocally meets 
  the â€œcause of actionâ€ component of this requirement since she alleges that the 
  legal wrong occurred in South Carolina when she was exposed to asbestos fibers 
  and dust on Fatherâ€™s clothing.Â  Ophuls & Hill v. Carolina Ice & Fuel 
  Co., supra.Â  As the Court of Appeals held, the critical inquiry here 
  is whether the cause of action arose within the State. . . . 
. . . .
In traditional tort settings, we have held that a cause of action arises in 
  this State for purposes of the Door Closing Statute when the plaintiff has the 
  right to bring suit.Â  See Cornelius v. Atlantic Grey Hound Lines, 
  177 S.C. 93, 180 S.E. 791 (1935).Â  In construing the statutory requirement that 
  â€œthe cause of action shall have arisen . . . within in this State,â€ the Cornelius 
  court cited with approval to an authority that â€œstated that â€˜a cause of action 
  accrues when facts exist which authorize one party to maintain an action against 
  another.â€™â€Â  Id. at 96, 180 S.E. at 792 (emphasis supplied).Â  Cornelius 
  is consistent with our later decision in Stephens v. Draffin, 327 S.C. 
  1, 488 S.E.2d 307 (1997), where we held â€œour cases use the verbs â€˜ariseâ€™ and 
  â€˜accrueâ€™ interchangeably when discussing the issue of the juncture at which 
  the right to sue came into existence.â€Â  Id. at footnote 4; see also 
  Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 585 S.E.2d 292 (2003).
Were we to apply our traditional view of when a tort cause of action arises 
  or accrues, we must conclude that Janetâ€™s cause of action did not arise â€œwithin 
  the Stateâ€ because no injury or damages occurred while she was in South Carolina.Â  
  Until the exposure to asbestos resulted in injury or damage, Janetâ€™s tort cause 
  of action did not accrue.Â  See e.g., Gray v. Southern Facilities, 
  256 S.C. 558, 183 S.E.2d 438 (1971) (â€œIt is basic that a negligent act is not 
  in itself actionable and only becomes such when it results in injury or damage 
  to anotherâ€).

Id. at ___, 590 S.E.2d at 481-82 (footnotes omitted).
Here, the door closing statute, Â§ 15-5-150, does not bar the Appellants 
  from bringing suit against W.W. Norton.Â  In the instant case, there is a continuing 
  publication of A Glimpse of Hell in South Carolina upon each sale and 
  upon each dissemination.Â  The sale and republication of the book are events 
  taking place in South Carolina.Â  The location of the actual â€œprintingâ€ of the 
  book is not controlling.
As set forth in the previous section, the factual record reveals 
  with clarity the activities and conduct of W.W. Norton in South Carolina.Â  Indubitably, 
  the publication of a libel is a basis for a defamation action.Â  The dissemination 
  of the book in South Carolina is a continuing libel in each and every instance.Â  
  The tort of libel occurs wherever the offending material is circulated.Â  Apodictically, 
  the causes of action as alleged arose in the state of South Carolina.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s rulings as to Thompson and Meyer 
  are AFFIRMED.Â  We REVERSE as to W.W. Norton and REMAND 
  to the Circuit Court.
 HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY, J., concur.

 
   [1]  
    Appellants Moosally, Miceli, Morse, and Finney filed an amended complaint 
    on March 15, 2001.Â  Thereafter, on April 12, 2001, Appellant Mortensen filed 
    an amended complaint alleging the same causes of action.

description: Following a verdict for Respondent Peggy Long Elms, Appellants Robert and William Hinds  moved for a new trial â€œas to damages only,â€ contending that the defense verdict was a result of improper influences since the trial court directed a verdict as to â€œliability.â€  The Hinds appeal from the denial of their motion for a new trial.  We affirmed, holding that a plaintiff in a personal injury action is not entitled as a matter of law to a favorable verdict where the court directs a verdict against the defendant on the issue of negligence and the issues of proximate cause and damages are submitted to the trier of fact.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Robert Andrew Hinds and William Henry Hinds,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Peggy Long Elms,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3770
Submitted January 29, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  5, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chalmers Carey Johnson, of Charleston, for Appellants.
Sarah E. Wetmore, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This appeal presents 
  the question whether a plaintiff in a personal injury action is entitled as 
  a matter of law to a favorable verdict where the court directs a verdict against 
  the defendant on the issue of negligence and the issues of proximate cause and 
  damages are submitted to the trier of fact. [1] Â Â  We hold that a plaintiffâ€™s 
  verdict is not mandated under these circumstances. [2] Â  Following a verdict for Respondent Peggy Long 
  Elms, Appellants Robert and William Hinds [3]  moved for a new trial â€œas to 
  damages only,â€ contending that the defense verdict was a result of improper 
  influences since the trial court directed a verdict as to â€œliability.â€Â  The 
  Hinds appeal from the denial of their motion for a new trial.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Robert Hinds was involved in three automobile accidents 
  during the summer of 1995.Â  This case arises from the second accident.Â  Robert 
  was driving his fatherâ€™s truck when it was struck in the rear by the vehicle 
  driven by Elms.Â  
After the July 12 accident, Robert contacted his 
  family doctor, Dr. Skinner, who was unable to schedule him for an immediate 
  appointment.Â  An appointment was scheduled with Dr. Skinner for July 24.Â  In 
  the interim, Robert was involved in a third automobile accident on July 19.Â  
  Robert did not seek medical treatment immediately following the third accident, 
  but instead waited until the previously scheduled July 24 appointment. 
The Hinds initiated the present action in July 
  1998, alleging Robert suffered â€œserious, painful and disablingâ€ injuries in 
  the July 12, 1995, automobile accident caused by Elmsâ€™ negligence. 
  [4] Â  William Hinds sought compensation associated with the damage to his 
  Nissan truck, including loss of use and diminution in value. 
The case was tried to a jury.Â  At the close of 
  the evidence, the following occurred:

THE COURT:Â  At the conclusion of the defendantâ€™s case.Â  
  Plaintiff, motions, please.Â  
COUNSEL FOR PLAINTIFFS:Â  Motion for directed verdict, your 
  honor, on the issue of simple negligence.
THE COURT:Â  Granted.

(emphasis added).
Following a discussion on the defense of comparative 
  negligence, counsel for Elms remarked, â€œ[so] in essence itâ€™s now an admitted 
  simple negligence case that proceeds on proximate cause and damages?â€Â  The court 
  answered, â€œCorrect.â€Â  The trial judge then commented:

The defendant herself obviously throughout the trial has 
  admitted that at the point and time of the collision she was negligent â€¦ The 
  proximate causal connection is still there, obviously, and thatâ€™s the issue 
  I expect to be argued most heavily by the defense, as well as the speculative 
  nature of the damages that Iâ€™m sure they intend to argue full-fledged.

The trial court properly charged the jury on the 
  applicable law, including the Hindsâ€™ burden, as plaintiffs, to establish that 
  the claimed damages were proximately caused by the admitted negligence.Â  At 
  the conclusion of the charge, the trial court reviewed the verdict form with 
  the jury, noting the options for â€œplaintiff blank dollars actual damages â€¦ [or] 
  for the defendant.â€Â  Prior to deliberations, the trial court invited the parties 
  to lodge any exceptions to the charge, to which counsel for the Hinds responded, 
  â€œNothing.â€Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Upon receipt of the defense verdict, the 
  Hinds, for the first time, argued that the jury had to find in their 
  favor and award damages. [5] Â  
  In their motion for a new trial, and before this court, the Hinds assert that 
  the trial court directed a verdict â€œto the plaintiff on the issue of liability.â€Â  
  Based on this premise, the Hinds argue they were entitled to an award of damages, 
  and the juryâ€™s defense verdict was â€œinconsistent with the law of the case.â€Â  
  We disagree.Â  
The premise of the Hindsâ€™ argument is flawed, for 
  the record clearly establishes that the directed verdict was limited to the 
  element of negligence. [6] Â  A 
  determination of negligence, standing alone, is a far cry from a determination 
  of liability.Â  Liability encompasses all elements of a negligence claim, including 
  damages proximately caused by the alleged negligence.Â  â€œTo prevail in an action 
  founded in negligence, the plaintiff must establish three essential elements: 
  (1) a duty of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff; (2) a breach of that 
  duty by a negligent act or omission; and (3) damage proximately caused by a 
  breach of duty.â€Â  Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 399, 477 S.E.2d 715, 
  720 (Ct. App. 1996).
In view of the purported error of the 
  trial court in denying the Hindsâ€™ motion for a new trial, we have reviewed the 
  evidence.Â  At the time of the July 12, 1995 motor vehicle accident, Robert was 
  recovering from injuries from his first accident that summer.Â  Robertâ€™s family 
  physician, Dr. Skinner, had diagnosed Robert with musculoskeletal pain, and 
  prescribed various medications, as a result of a May 30 automobile accident.Â  
  Following the July 12 accident, Robert drove his fatherâ€™s truck home.Â  He received 
  no medical treatment, other than to schedule an appointment with Dr. Skinner 
  for July 24.Â  Robertâ€™s third automobile accident occurred on July 19.Â  Robertâ€™s 
  claim for damages resulting from the July 12 accident was contested and, indeed, 
  was the focus of the trial.Â  The suggestion that the defense verdict resulted 
  from improper influences finds no traction in this record.Â  We conclude the 
  trial court acted well within its discretion in denying the Hindsâ€™ motion for 
  a new trial.Â  Creighton v. Coligny Plaza Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 334 S.C. 96, 113, 
  512 S.E.2d 510, 519 (1998) (â€œThe grant or denial of a new trial motion rests 
  within the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed on appeal 
  unless the trial judgeâ€™s findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or 
  the conclusions reached are controlled by error of law.â€).
CONCLUSION
In a personal injury action, a determination of 
  negligence, standing alone, does not entitle a plaintiff to a favorable verdict 
  as a matter of law.Â  Liability encompasses all elements of a negligence claim, 
  including damages proximately caused by the negligence.Â  Since the directed 
  verdict in favor of the Hinds was limited, in their counselâ€™s words, â€œto the 
  issue of simple negligence,â€ there exists no inconsistency in the defense verdict.Â  
  Accordingly, there is no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of the motion for 
  a new trial. 
AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY and HOWARD, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Negligence was conceded at trial, resulting in a directed verdict 
    on that issue.Â Â  

 
   
    [2]  We revisit this basic principle in a published opinion in light of 
    the continuing confusion among some members of the bar as to the distinction 
    between the element of a negligent act or omission and the concept of liability.Â  
  

 
   
    [3]  Â The primary Appellant is Robert Andrew Hinds.Â  William Henry Hinds 
    is Robertâ€™s father and the owner of the 1995 Nissan truck involved in the 
    accident.Â  

 
   
    [4]  Robert filed a negligence action in connection with the July 19 accident, 
    where he claimed â€œserious, painful and disablingâ€ injuries.Â  In that lawsuit, 
    Robert sought to recover the â€œexact same medical bills â€¦ as [he] did in this 
    case.â€

 
   
     
    [5]    The Hinds do not attempt to distinguish Robertâ€™s personal injury 
    claim from his fatherâ€™s property damage claim.

 
   
    [6]  We do recognize that â€œwhen liability is admitted, a plaintiff is 
    entitled to an award unless proof completely fails.â€Â  Krepps by Krepps 
    v. Ausen, 324 S.C. 597, 609, 479 S.E.2d 290, 296 (Ct. App. 1996).

title: Burton v. York Sheriff's Department
description: In this civil action, Appellants contend the trial judge erred in: (1) concluding that the South Carolina Freedom of Information Act applies to a "Sheriff"; (2) holding that records maintained by the office of the Sheriff were not exempt from disclosure; (3) ruling that the records were not constitutionally protected by the right of privacy under the Fourteenth Amendment; (4) ordering disclosure of records of a personal nature which constituted an unreasonable invasion of personal privacy under the Act; and (5) admitting hearsay testimony by the editor of a newspaper.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ray B. Burton, III and East Coast Newspapers, Inc.,       
Respondents/Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
York County Sheriffâ€™s Department and Bruce Bryant, York County Sheriff,       
Appellants/Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
J. Buford Grier, Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3771
Heard March 10, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  5, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  and REMANDED


  
    
      
Melvin B. McKeown, Jr. and Elizabeth H. Robinson, both 
  of York, for Appellants/Respondents.
Jay Bender, of Columbia, for Respondents/Appellants.
Robert E. Lyon, Jr. and M. Clifton Scott, both of Columbia, 
  for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Association of Counties.
Sandra J. Senn and Stephanie P. McDonald, both of Charleston, 
  for Amici Curiae South Carolina Sheriffsâ€™ Association and South Carolina Fraternal 
  Order of Police.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this case, we decide whether the Freedom of Information 
  Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 30-4-10 to -165 (1991 & Supp. 2003) (â€œFOIAâ€), requires 
  the Sheriff of York County (â€œthe Sheriffâ€) and the York County Sheriffâ€™s Department 
  (collectively, â€œthe Sheriffâ€™s Departmentâ€) to provide information regarding 
  alleged illegal and unethical conduct of four deputy sheriffs to Ray B. Burton, 
  III and East Coast Newspapers, Inc. (collectively, â€œBurtonâ€).
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Sometime in early 2000, four York County deputy sheriffs were suspended 
  without pay for â€œconduct unbecoming an officer.â€Â  The suspension followed an 
  internal investigation of a complaint lodged against the deputies by Lori Williams, 
  a citizen of York County.Â  After filing her complaint, Williams contacted Burton, 
  a reporter for The Herald newspaper, which is published in Rock Hill.Â  
  Williams informed Burton that her complaint to the Sheriffâ€™s Department included 
  falsification of investigative reports, possession of stolen property, abuse 
  of authority, and sexual activity in patrol cars.
 In an effort to obtain more information for a newspaper report, Burton 
  submitted written requests to the Sheriffâ€™s Department for access to records 
  it possessed relating to Williamsâ€™ complaint and the Sheriffâ€™s Departmentâ€™s 
  response to the complaint.Â  Burton identified two specific categories of information 
  he wanted:

(1)Â Â Â Â  Crime Reports.Â  Burton requested access to reports of all complaints 
  or allegations of illegal conduct made against the named deputy sheriffs since 
  January 1, 2000, including all complaints made by Williams during that time.
(2)Â Â Â Â  Employment Records.Â  Burton asked to review the employment information 
  for the named deputy sheriffs, including â€œdates of employment, title, rank, 
  pay-rate schedule, copies of disciplinary letters, records of suspension and 
  all other information as provided by law.â€

The Sheriffâ€™s Departmentâ€™s response only provided information as to the date 
  of hire, title/rank, and pay/rate schedule for each of the named deputies.Â  
  It claimed all other information requested was exempt from disclosure under 
  FOIA because the information was of a personal nature and disclosing it would 
  constitute an unreasonable invasion of personal privacy.Â  The personal privacy 
  exemption is provided under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40(a)(2) (1991).Â  Alternatively, 
  the Sheriffâ€™s Department claimed the information requested was exempt under 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40(a)(3) (Supp. 2003) (records of law enforcement activities 
  compiled in the process of detecting and investigating a crime the disclosure 
  of which would harm an ongoing or prospective law enforcement action) and Â§ 
  30-4-40(a)(7) (1991) (â€œ[c]orrespondence or work products of legal counsel for 
  a public body and any other material that would violate attorney-client relationshipsâ€).Â  
  Burton initiated this action seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.
After conducting an in camera review of the Sheriffâ€™s 
  Departmentâ€™s records that the Department claimed were exempt from disclosure, 
  the trial court concluded the Department had violated the FOIA.Â  The judge â€œpermanently 
  enjoined and restrainedâ€ the Sheriffâ€™s Department â€œfrom asserting exemptions 
  from mandatory disclosure that have no legal or factual justification, and from 
  continuing to refuse to segregate exempt and non-exempt material and make non-exempt 
  public records available for inspection and copying.â€
The trial court found that a portion of the records submitted for in 
  camera review revealed information that would lead to an unreasonable 
  invasion of personal privacy if disclosed.Â  In its findings of fact, the court 
  concluded â€œthe Williamsâ€™ allegations relating to the off-duty sexual practices 
  and activities of the deputies is personal and private, as are the photographs 
  in the record of Williams and Deputy Sullivan.â€Â  Burton has not appealed or 
  otherwise contested this finding.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Burton sought injunctive relief and a declaratory judgment pursuant 
  to FOIA.
Declaratory judgments in and of themselves are neither legal nor equitable.Â  
  See Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 400 S.E.2d 781 (1991); 
  Campbell v. Marion County Hosp. Dist., 354 S.C. 274, 580 S.E.2d 163 (Ct. 
  App. 2003); Wiedemann v. Town of Hilton Head Island, 344 S.C. 233, 542 
  S.E.2d 752 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The standard of review for a declaratory judgment 
  action is therefore determined by the nature of the underlying issue.Â  Campbell, 
  354 S.C. at 279, 580 S.E.2d at 165; see also Goldston v. State Farm 
  Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., Op. No. 3749 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 1, 2004) (Shearouse 
  Adv. Sh. No. 8 at 52) (stating that because declaratory judgment actions are 
  neither legal nor equitable, standard of review depends on nature of underlying 
  issues); Travelers Indem. Co. v. Auto World, 334 S.C. 137, 511 S.E.2d 
  692 (Ct. App. 1999) (noting that suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal 
  nor equitable, but is determined by nature of underlying issue).
A declaratory judgment action under the FOIA to determine whether certain information 
  should be disclosed is an action at law.Â  See South Carolina Tax Commâ€™n 
  v. Gaston Copper Recycling Corp., 316 S.C. 163, 447 S.E.2d 843 (1994); Campbell, 
  354 S.C. at 280, 580 S.E.2d at 165.Â  In an action at law tried without a jury, 
  the appellate courtâ€™s standard of review extends only to the correction of errors 
  of law.Â  Crary v. Djebelli, 329 S.C. 385, 496 S.E.2d 21 (1998); Townes 
  Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976); 
  Okatie River v. Southeastern Site Prep, 353 S.C. 327, 577 S.E.2d 468 
  (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Thus, the trial courtâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed 
  on appeal unless a review of the record discloses that there is no evidence 
  which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Townes, 266 S.C. at 
  86, 221 S.E.2d at 775; Barnacle Broad., Inc. v. Baker Broad., Inc., 343 
  S.C. 140, 538 S.E.2d 672 (Ct. App. 2000); see also Sloan v. Greenville 
  County, 356 S.C. 531, 590 S.E.2d 338 (Ct. App. 2003) (declaring that in 
  actions at law, on appeal of case tried without jury, lower court must be affirmed 
  where there is any evidence which reasonably supports judgeâ€™s findings).
LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.Â  FOIA CLAIMS
The South Carolina Freedom of Information Act is codified as sections 
  30-4-10 to â€“165 in the South Carolina Code.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 30-4-10 
  to â€“165 (1991 & Supp. 2003).Â  Upon request, FOIA mandates disclosure of 
  records held by a â€œpublic bodyâ€ unless the documents fall within enumerated 
  exemptions.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 30-4-30 to -40 (Supp. 2003).Â  As our 
  Legislature explicitly provided in enacting FOIA, disclosure, not secrecy, is 
  the dominant objective of the Act:

The General Assembly finds that it is vital in a democratic 
  society that public business be performed in an open and public manner so that 
  citizens shall be advised of the performance of public officials and of the 
  decisions that are reached in public activity and in the formulation of public 
  policy.Â  Toward this end, provisions of this chapter must be construed so as 
  to make it possible for citizens, or their representatives, to learn and report 
  fully the activities of their public officials at a minimum cost or delay to 
  the persons seeking access to public documents or meetings.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-15 (1991).
The essential purpose of the FOIA is to protect the public from secret government 
  activity.Â  Campbell v. Marion County Hosp. Dist., 354 S.C. 274, 580 S.E.2d 
  163 (Ct. App. 2003); see also Quality Towing, Inc. v. City of Myrtle 
  Beach, 345 S.C. 156, 163, 547 S.E.2d 862, 865 (2001) (â€œFOIA was enacted 
  to prevent the government from acting in secret.â€); Wiedemann v. Town of 
  Hilton Head Island, 330 S.C. 532, 535 n.4, 500 S.E.2d 783, 785 n.4 (1998) 
  (noting that â€œ[t]he purpose of the FOIA is to protect the public from secret 
  government activityâ€).Â  The FOIA meets the demand for open government while 
  preserving workable confidentiality in governmental decisionmaking.Â  Bellamy 
  v. Brown, 305 S.C. 291, 408 S.E.2d 219 (1991); Campbell, 354 S.C. 
  at 281, 580 S.E.2d at 166.
â€œSouth Carolinaâ€™s FOIA was designed to guarantee the public reasonable access 
  to certain activities of the government.â€Â  Fowler v. Beasley, 322 S.C. 
  463, 468, 472 S.E.2d 630, 633 (1996).Â  The FOIA creates an affirmative duty 
  on the part of public bodies to disclose information.Â  Bellamy, 305 S.C. 
  at 295, 408 S.E.2d at 221; Campbell, 354 S.C. at 281, 580 S.E.2d at 166.Â  
  The purpose of the FOIA is to protect the public by providing for the disclosure 
  of information.Â  Id.Â  The FOIA is remedial in nature and should be liberally 
  construed to carry out the purpose mandated by the legislature.Â  Campbell, 
  354 S.C. at 281, 580 S.E.2d at 166.
The exemptions from disclosure under FOIA do not create a duty of 
  nondisclosure.Â  Bellamy, 305 S.C. at 295, 408 S.E.2d at 221.Â  At most, 
  these exemptions simply allow public agencies the discretion to withhold exempted 
  materials from public disclosure.Â  Id.Â  Indeed, consistent with FOIAâ€™s 
  goal of broad disclosure, the exemptions from its mandates are to be narrowly 
  construed.Â  See Campbell, 354 S.C. at 281, 580 S.E.2d at 166; 
  see also Quality Towing, 345 S.C. at 161, 547 S.E.2d at 864-65 
  (stating that FOIA is remedial in nature and should be liberally construed to 
  carry out purpose mandated by legislature).Â  Moreover, the determination of 
  whether documents or portions thereof are exempt from the FOIA must be made 
  on a case-by-case basis.Â  City of Columbia v. ACLU, 323 S.C. 384, 475 
  S.E.2d 747 (1996); Newberry Publâ€™g Co. v. Newberry County Commâ€™n on Alcohol 
  & Drug Abuse, 308 S.C. 352, 417 S.E.2d 870 (1992).
In this appeal, the Sheriffâ€™s Department argues the trial court erred in its 
  application of FOIA.Â  First, the Sheriffâ€™s Department claims the Department 
  is not a â€œpublic bodyâ€ as defined by FOIA and is therefore not subject to its 
  strictures.Â  Alternatively, the Sheriffâ€™s Department maintains the information 
  Burton sought is exempt from disclosure under FOIA because its release would 
  constitute an unreasonable invasion of privacy.Â  We address these arguments 
  seriatim.
A.Â  â€œPublic Bodyâ€ 
  under FOIA
1.Â  Sheriff as â€œpublic bodyâ€
The key operative provision of FOIA provides: â€œAny person has a right 
  to inspect or copy any public record of a public body, except 
  as otherwise provided by Â§ 30-4-40, in accordance with reasonable rules concerning 
  time and place of access.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-30(a) (1991) (emphasis added).Â  
  FOIA defines â€œpublic bodyâ€ for the purposes of the Act: 

â€œPublic bodyâ€ means any department of the State, . . . any 
  state board, commission, agency, and authority, any public or governmental body 
  or political subdivision of the State, including counties, municipalities, townships, 
  school districts, and special purpose districts, or any organization, corporation, 
  or agency supported in whole or in part by public funds or expending public 
  funds, including committees, subcommittees, advisory committees, and the like 
  of any such body by whatever name known, and includes any quasi-governmental 
  body of the State and its political subdivisions . . . .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-20(a) (Supp. 2003).Â  This Court does not need to look 
  any further than the language of the statute to find the Sheriffâ€™s Department 
  is subject to FOIA.Â  See Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 
  361, 373, 585 S.E.2d 292, 298 (2003) (â€œWhen the language of a statute is plain, 
  unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite meaning, the application of standard 
  rules of statutory interpretation is unwarranted. . . . The statutory terms, 
  therefore, must be applied according to their literal meaning.â€) (citations 
  omitted).
We first note that the office of the sheriff was created by our state constitution, 
  which grants the General Assembly authority to determine their duties, qualifications, 
  training, and compensation. See S.C. Const. art. V, Â§ 24; see also 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-11-110 (Supp. 2003) (prescribing the qualifications of sheriffs); 
  Botchie v. Oâ€™Dowd, 299 S.C. 329, 332 n.3, 384 S.E.2d 727, 729 n.3 (1989) 
  (noting that the South Carolina Constitution â€œauthorizes the election of a sheriff 
  as a county officerâ€).Â  The Sheriffâ€™s Department, therefore, clearly falls within 
  the compass of the plain meaning of â€œpublic or governmental body or political 
  subdivision of the Stateâ€ under section 30-4-20(a).
2.Â  Efficacy of Weston v. Carolina Research
Furthermore, the Sheriffâ€™s Department is supported exclusively by 
  public funds.Â  Sheriff Bruce Bryant testified that the Departmentâ€™s annual budget 
  was â€œapproximately thirteen million dollars,â€ all of which was received through 
  York County tax revenue and federal grants.
Our Supreme Court has ruled the fact that an organization, corporation, or 
  agency is supported in whole or in part by public funds or expends public funds 
  is sufficient grounds alone to find the organization is a â€œpublic bodyâ€ under 
  FOIA, regardless of any other factors.Â  See Weston v. Carolina Research 
  & Dev. Found., 303 S.C. 398, 401 S.E.2d 161 (1991).Â  The Weston 
  Court explained its reading of the statute:

The [Defendantâ€™s] argument that the FOIA only applies to 
  governmental and quasi-governmental bodies would rewrite the statutory definition 
  of â€œpublic bodyâ€ by deleting the phrase, â€œor any organization, corporation, 
  or agency supported in whole or in part by public funds or expending public 
  funds.â€Â  According to the [Defendantâ€™s] position, a corporation that cannot 
  be labeled governmental or quasi-governmental would be exempt from the FOIA, 
  regardless of whether it received support from public funds or expended public 
  funds.Â  Such a construction would obliterate both the intent and the clear meaning 
  of the statutory definition.

Id at 403, 401 S.E.2d at 164.
Therefore, based solely on the fact that the Sheriffâ€™s Department is supported 
  exclusively by public funds, we are compelled to find the Department is a â€œpublic 
  bodyâ€ subject to the mandates of FOIA.
B.Â  In Camera 
  Review
Under the FOIA, an in camera review of documentary 
  material is mandated where there exists any controversy in regard to the production 
  of contested documents.
In Newberry Publâ€™g Co. v. Newberry County Commâ€™n on Alcohol & 
  Drug Abuse, 308 S.C. 352, 417 S.E.2d 870 (1992), the Supreme Court inculcated:
Section 30-4-40(b) provides that:

  
If any public record contains material which is 
  not exempt under subsection (a) of this section, the public body shall separate 
  the exempt and nonexempt material and make the nonexempt material available 
  in accordance with the requirements of this chapter.
  
The Observer contends that the trial judge erred 
  in failing to segregate the nonexempt and exempt portions of the report and 
  to provide the Observer with the nonexempt material, as is mandated by section 
  30-4-40(b).Â  We agree.
. . . We find that SLEDâ€™s policy of denying all FOIA requests for 
  criminal investigative reports, without determining whether portions of the 
  report are subject to disclosure, is in direct contravention of the clear language 
  of the FOIA.
. . . [T]he report may not be entirely exempt from disclosure; the statute goes 
  on to state that a public record containing both nonexempt and exempt material 
  must be segregated so that the nonexempt material is made available to the public.Â  
  As a result, we reject SLEDâ€™s contention that this, or any, criminal investigative 
  report is per se exempt from disclosure.
. . . .Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In sum, we emphasize that law enforcement agencies do not have carte blanche 
  to deny all FOIA requests for criminal investigative reports.Â  The information 
  contained in these reports can be withheld from disclosure only to the extent 
  that it falls within one or more of the exemptions enumerated in section 30-4-40(a).Â  
  The determination as to which portions of a report are exempt and which portions 
  must be disclosed should be done on a case-by-case basis.

Id. at 354-56, 417 S.E.2d at 873.Â  Thereafter, the Court, in City 
  of Columbia v. ACLU, 323 S.C. 384, 475 S.E.2d 747 (1996), explicated: â€œBefore 
  Appellant becomes entitled to the report, the trial court must first examine 
  the report in detail in order to determine whether the reportâ€™s contents or 
  portions thereof qualify for an exemption under Â§ 30-4-40.â€Â  Id. at 388-89, 
  475 S.E.2d at 750.
In the case sub judice, the trial court conducted an 
  in camera review resulting in a fact-specific analysis of producible 
  documents as juxtaposed to protected documents.Â  The actual materials and documents 
  reviewed in an in camera hearing constitute evidence in the case.Â  
  The sealed documents reviewed by the trial court have been examined by this 
  Court and support the order issued by the trial court.
C.Â  Privacy Exemption
Though the purpose of FOIA is to create an affirmative duty on the part of 
  public bodies to disclose information, the Act enumerates fifteen categories 
  of public records that may be exempt from mandatory disclosure.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40 (1991 & Supp. 2003).Â  The category relevant to 
  the present case is known as the â€œprivacy exemption.â€Â  Section 30-4-40(a)(2) 
  exempts from disclosure â€œ[i]nformation of a personal nature where the public 
  disclosure thereof would constitute unreasonable invasion of personal privacy.â€Â  
  We find the specific information Burton seeks does not fall within the purview 
  of this exemption.
Section 30-4-40(a)(2) does not specifically list or define the types of records, 
  reports, or other information that should be classified as personal or private 
  information exempt from disclosure.Â  We must, therefore, resort to general privacy 
  principles, which examination involves a balancing of conflicting interestsâ€”the 
  interest of the individual in privacy on the one hand against the interest of 
  the publicâ€™s need to know on the other.
Our Supreme Court has defined the â€œright to privacyâ€ as the right 
  of an individual to be let alone and to live a life free from unwarranted publicity. 
  Â Sloan v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 355 S.C. 321, 586 S.E.2d 
  108 (2003).Â  However, â€œâ€˜one of the primary limitations placed on the right of 
  privacy is that it does not prohibit the publication of matter which is of legitimate 
  public or general interest.â€™â€Â  Society of Profâ€™l Journalists v. Sexton, 
  283 S.C. 563, 566, 324 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1984) (quoting Meetze v. Associated 
  Press, 230 S.C. 330, 95 S.E.2d 606 (1956)).Â  Indeed, the Court has held 
  that, as a matter of law, â€œif a person, whether willingly or not, becomes an 
  actor in an event of public or general interest, â€˜then the publication of his 
  connection with such an occurrence is not an invasion of his right to privacy.â€™â€Â  
  Doe v. Berkeley Publishers, 329 S.C. 412, 414, 496 S.E.2d 636, 637 (1998) 
  (quoting Meetze, 230 S.C. at 337, 95 S.E.2d at 609).
In the present case, we find the manner in which the employees of 
  the Sheriffâ€™s Department prosecute their duties to be a large and vital public 
  interest that outweighs their desire to remain out of the public eye.Â  The newspaper, 
  in fulfilling its obligation to report on and hold to account those in public 
  service, had a legitimate need to access the records Burton requested.Â  Burton 
  and the newspaper did not seek information regarding the off-duty sexual activities 
  of the deputies involved.Â  Rather, the access to information they sought and 
  the trial court granted was focused on the performance of public duties by the 
  Sheriff and his deputies and the response of the Department to allegations of 
  misconduct by the deputies.
We affirm the trial courtâ€™s finding that the information requested 
  by Burton was not exempt under section 30-4-40(a)(2) of the Act.
D.Â  Right to Privacy 
  under the United States Constitution
The Sheriffâ€™s Department contends that disclosing the information 
  Burton requested would violate the deputiesâ€™ â€œright to privacyâ€ guaranteed by 
  the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  The Department 
  essentially raises this argument twice: (1) as grounds for exemption under FOIA 
  from disclosure of â€œ[m]atters specifically exempted from disclosure by statute 
  or law,â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40(a)(4) (1991 & Supp. 2003); and (2) as 
  a defense entirely separate from the FOIA regime.Â  Either way, we find the argument 
  is without merit.
The Fourteenth Amendment provides that no state shall â€œdeprive any 
  person of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law . . . .â€Â  U.S. 
  Const. amend XIV, Â§ 1.Â  From this broad language, the United States Supreme 
  Court has extrapolated a number of principles used to evaluate whether laws 
  enacted by the state and federal governments are reasonable, fair, and supported 
  by adequate justification.Â  These Fourteenth Amendment principles are generally 
  grouped together under the label of â€œsubstantive due process.â€Â  Among these 
  substantive due process guarantees exists what the Supreme Court has termed 
  a â€œright of privacy.â€
Unlike the privacy rights implicated under section 30-4-40(a)(2) 
  of FOIA or under the common law tort of invasion of privacy, the right of privacy 
  subsumed under the Fourteenth Amendment has been narrowly defined and limited 
  to specific situations:

[I]n terms of due process and equal protection the â€œright 
  to privacyâ€ has come to mean a right to engage in certain highly personal activities.Â  
  More specifically, it currently relates to certain rights of freedom of choice 
  in marital, sexual, and reproductive matters.Â  Even this definition may be too 
  broad, for the Court still has not recognized any general right to engage in 
  sexual activities that are done in private.Â  Instead, the Justices have acknowledged 
  the existence of a â€œrightâ€ and defined it by very specific application to laws 
  relating to reproduction, contraception, abortion, and marriage.

Ronald D. Rotunda & John E. Nowak, 3 Treatise on Constitutional Law: 
  Substance and Procedure Â§ 18.26 (3d ed.) (1999); see also, e.g., 
  Griswold v. Connecticut, 381 U.S. 479, 485 (1965) (recognizing a â€œright 
  of privacyâ€ in marriage stemming from the â€œzone of privacy created by several 
  fundamental constitutional guaranteesâ€); Roe v. Wade, 410 U.S. 113, 153 
  (1973) (holding that right of privacy in matters concerning procreation and 
  family â€œis broad enough to encompass a womanâ€™s decision whether or not to terminate 
  her pregnancyâ€); Moore v. City of East Cleveland, 431 U.S. 494 (1977) 
  (invalidating ordinance that barred certain family living arrangements); Lawrence 
  v. Texas, 123 S.Ct. 2472 (2003) (holding that a statute making it a crime 
  for two persons of the same sex to engage in certain intimate sexual conduct 
  violates the â€œright of privacyâ€ guaranteed by the Due Process Clause of the 
  Fourteenth Amendment).
By raising this constitutional argument, the Sheriffâ€™s Department 
  urges this Court to add another category of protection to the privacy rights 
  the Supreme Court has found under the Fourteenth Amendment: the right of an 
  individualâ€™s performance of his public duties to be free from public scrutiny.Â  
  We find this would be ill-advised.Â  Unless and until the Supreme Court rules 
  otherwise, we will follow its precedent and not expand the â€œright of privacyâ€ 
  under the Fourteenth Amendment beyond those situations which the Court has ruled 
  bear on the most intimate decisions affecting personal autonomyâ€”namely reproductive 
  rights, familial and marital relations.
II.Â  VALIDITY OF 
  INJUNCTIVE RELIEF
The Sheriffâ€™s Department maintains the trial court abused its discretion 
  in issuing an injunction.Â  We disagree.
In order that its mandate of disclosure be enforced, there is a statutory 
  presumption that no adequate remedy at law exists for a violation of FOIA and 
  that injured parties are entitled to appropriate equitable relief:

Any citizen of the State may apply to the circuit court 
  for either or both a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief to enforce the 
  provisions of this chapter in appropriate cases . . . . The court may order 
  equitable relief as it considers appropriate, and a violation of this chapter 
  must be considered to be an irreparable injury for which no adequate remedy 
  at law exists.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-100(a) (1991); see also Business License Opposition 
  Comm. v. Sumter County, 311 S.C. 24, 426 S.E.2d 745 (1992) (upholding trial 
  courtâ€™s grant of injunction prohibiting a public body from holding future secret 
  meetings in violation of FOIA); Florence Morning News, Inc. v. Building Commâ€™n 
  of City and County of Florence, 265 S.C. 389, 218 S.E.2d 881 (1975) (upholding 
  trial courtâ€™s injunction prohibiting defendants from interfering with the plaintiffâ€™s 
  right to inspect and copy original records in possession of a public body). 

The Sheriffâ€™s Department clearly violated the provisions of FOIA 
  by withholding non-exempt documents that were the subject of a legitimate request 
  and failing to segregate exempt and non-exempt materials for disclosure.Â  The 
  award of equitable injunctive relief was therefore entirely appropriate.
The Sheriffâ€™s Department alleges the injunction granted by the trial 
  court was overly broad.Â  We disagree.
The injunction issued in the trial courtâ€™s order provided that â€œdefendants 
  are permanently enjoined and restrained from asserting exemptions from mandatory 
  disclosure that have no legal or factual justification, and from continuing 
  to refuse to segregate exempt and non-exempt material and make non-exempt public 
  records available for inspection and copying.â€Â  The Sheriffâ€™s Department avers 
  this injunction â€œdid not set forth specific reasons for its issuance or describe 
  in reasonable detail the acts to be restrained.â€Â  The Department argues â€œthe 
  permanent injunction prevents the defendants from asserting statutory and constitutional 
  exemptions under [FOIA]â€ and â€œextends beyond the records requested in this case 
  to all information and records in possession of the defendants in perpetuity.â€
Reading the trial courtâ€™s order as a whole, the reasons for the 
  injunction and the acts it intends to proscribe are amply clear.Â  The trial 
  court, in its findings of fact and conclusions of law, discussed at length the 
  FOIA violation and the records ultimately subject to disclosure.Â  We do not 
  read the trial courtâ€™s order as compelling the production of records which are 
  exempt under FOIA.Â  To the extent that any of the Sheriffâ€™s Departmentâ€™s records 
  are exempt under section 30-4-40 of FOIA, the Department is not obligated to 
  disclose them.Â  We find no error with the issuance of the injunction or its 
  scope.
III.Â  HEARSAY OBJECTION
The Sheriffâ€™s Department contends the trial court erred in allowing 
  certain testimony of Terry Plumb, claiming it was inadmissible hearsay.Â  We 
  disagree.
Terry Plumb, editor of The Herald during the relevant time 
  period, testified about the events leading up to the FOIA request and the present 
  action.Â  Part of Plumbâ€™s testimony concerned a conversation he had with Burton 
  regarding the story he was developing relating to the allegations made against 
  the Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  Plumb stated:

Well, I asked Ray [Burton] what this was all about, and 
  he told me that a woman by the name of Lori Williams had been arrested on public 
  disorderly conduct.Â  This woman further related she had been a complainant against 
  a deputy and that she had had an affair with him, and they had a falling out.Â  
  She told Ray that [the deputy] had threatened to distribute photographs of her 
  in the nude and that she had reported this to the Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  They 
  had seized his car, found photographs in question of this woman, and that there 
  had been an investigation by the Sheriffâ€™s department and that he and several 
  other deputies had been suspended, and that the shiftâ€”[t]he 300 shift, I believe, 
  it was called, had been reorganized because of the scandal that emanated from 
  this particular incident.

The Sheriffâ€™s Department raised a contemporaneous objection that this testimony 
  was inadmissible hearsay.Â  The trial court overruled the objection and allowed 
  the testimony.
Hearsay is â€œa statement, other than one made by the declarant while 
  testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of 
  the matter asserted.â€Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE.Â  â€œProof of a statement introduced 
  to show a party heard and acted upon information is not objectionable hearsay.â€ 
  Fields v. Regional Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 354 S.C. 445, 454, 581 S.E.2d 
  489, 493 (Ct. App. 2003); see also Webb v. Elrod, 308 S.C. 445, 
  449, 418 S.E.2d 559, 562 (Ct. App. 1992) (â€œProof of a statement introduced for 
  the purpose of showing a party relied and acted upon it is not objectionable 
  on the ground of hearsay.â€).
Plumbâ€™s statement is a clear example of showing an action based upon 
  information and is not offered for the truth of the matter asserted.Â  Reviewing 
  Plumbâ€™s statement in the context of his testimony as a whole, it is apparent 
  the statement was not offered to prove that Williams had an affair with a deputy, 
  that Williams had filed a complaint, that an investigation had been conducted, 
  or that deputies had been suspended.Â  The testimony was merely offered to show 
  why the newspaper was requesting access to the Sheriffâ€™s Departmentâ€™s records.
Because the statement was not hearsay, the trial court did not err 
  in allowing its admission as evidence.
IV.Â  ATTORNEYâ€™S FEES
By way of cross-appeal, Burton appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of 
  its request for attorneyâ€™s fees as the prevailing party.Â  Burton maintains the 
  trial court abused its discretion by failing to enter its findings regarding 
  its denial of the fee request.Â  We agree.
Under FOIA, â€œ[i]f a person or entity seeking such relief prevails, he or it 
  may be awarded reasonable attorney fees and other costs of litigation.â€Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-100(b) (1991).Â  As a general rule, the amount of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees to be awarded in a particular case is within the discretion of the trial 
  judge.Â  Baron Data Systems, Inc. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 377 S.E.2d 296 
  (1989); see also Litchfield Plantation Co. v. Georgetown County Water 
  & Sewer Dist., 314 S.C. 30, 443 S.E.2d 574 (1994) (finding that, as 
  Â§ 30-4-100(b) provides attorneyâ€™s fees may be awarded, judge has discretion 
  to award fees); Campbell v. Marion County Hosp. Dist., 354 S.C. 274, 
  580 S.E.2d 163 (Ct. App. 2003) (where one party prevails in his claim for information 
  under FOIA, Circuit Court has discretion to award attorneyâ€™s fees).Â  The award, 
  however, must be reasonable and supported by adequate findings.Â  Baron Data 
  Systems, 297 S.C. at 384, 377 S.E.2d at 297.
There are six factors for the trial court to consider when determining an award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) 
  the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional 
  standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results 
  obtained; and (6) customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Jackson v. 
  Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 486 S.E.2d 750 (1997).Â  Upon request for attorneyâ€™s 
  fees that are authorized by contract or statute, the trial court should make 
  specific findings of fact on the record for each of these factors.Â  See 
  Jackson, 326 S.C. at 308, 486 S.E.2d at 760 (â€œ[O]n appeal, an award for 
  attorneyâ€™s fees will be affirmed so long as sufficient evidence in the record 
  supports each factor.â€); Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 494, 
  427 S.E.2d 659, 661 (1993) (â€œWhen an award of attorneyâ€™s fees is requested and 
  authorized by contract or statute, the court should make specific findings of 
  fact on the record for each factor.â€).
In Society of Profâ€™l Journalists v. Sexton, 283 S.C. 563, 324 S.E.2d 
  313 (1984), a FOIA case, the appellant urged the Court to reverse the attorneyâ€™s 
  fee award on grounds that DHEC acted in good faith reliance on its regulation.Â  
  The Supreme Court declined to do so, holding the â€œtrial judge did not abuse 
  his discretion in awarding fees to encourage agencies to comply with FOIA requests.â€Â  
  Id. at 568, 324 S.E.2d at 316.
In its order, the trial court addresses the request for attorneyâ€™s 
  fees in a wholly conclusory fashion: â€œThe award is discretionary with the Court, 
  and the Court declines to award fees in this case.â€Â  The court did not consider 
  or enter findings for the factors outlined in Jackson v. Speed as mandated 
  by our Supreme Court.Â  We must, therefore, remand this matter to the trial court 
  for a full and proper consideration of the attorneyâ€™s fees request.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s order 
  is AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED for further disposition.
HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY, J., concur.
