THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Thomas Wayne Richardson,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3773
Submitted December 8, 2003 â€“ Filed April 5, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard Harold Warder, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  GeneralÂ  John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert 
  M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CURETON, A.J.:Â  Thomas Wayne Richardson 
  appeals his convictions for criminal sexual conduct, third degree and criminal 
  sexual conduct with a minor, second degree.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In June 1999, Richardson met SS 
  [1] , pastor of a Greenville church, during revival services at another 
  local church.Â  Richardson befriended SS by informing him that he represented 
  the Richardson Family Foundation (the â€œFoundationâ€), an organization that helped 
  churches and individuals obtain federally funded grants.Â  Richardson participated 
  in several services at SSâ€™s church.
KS, SSâ€™s sixteen-year-old daughter, met Richardson 
  through her parents.Â Â  Prior to this meeting, KS had heard Richardson speak 
  at her fatherâ€™s church several times.Â  During these speaking engagements, Richardson 
  informed the congregation that he helped churches and intended to help rebuild 
  the church and its related facilities.
On August 20, 1999, KSâ€™s parents asked her to provide 
  administrative help to Richardson.Â  On that day, Richardson was working in his 
  hotel room.Â  KS testified Richardson made sexual advances when the two were 
  alone.Â Â  Immediately after she refused his requests, KSâ€™s parents returned to 
  the hotel room.Â  She did not tell her parents about what had happened because 
  she was afraid and in shock.
The next day, SS invited Richardson to stay at 
  his home.Â  KS, her parents, and her seven brothers and sisters also lived in 
  the home, including TS, KSâ€™s fourteen-year-old sister.Â  KS testified 
  she helped Richardson with some of his paperwork while he was a guest.Â  During 
  one of these sessions, Richardson demanded that she go into the closet in her 
  room and pull her pants down.Â  When she questioned him, he responded that he 
  would not help her church or anybody in the ministry if she told anyone.Â  Richardson 
  then had sexual intercourse with her.
KS testified Richardson asked her to perform oral 
  sex on another occasion.Â  She further stated that Richardson came to her room 
  several times and had sexual intercourse with her.Â  When KS asked Richardson 
  if what he was doing was wrong, Richardson claimed it was not wrong and justified 
  his response with scriptures.Â  During this time, Richardson told her the people 
  in the ministry would not get anything if she did not comply or if she told 
  anyone.
KS claimed the encounters with Richardson affected 
  her performance in school and caused her to have headaches and stomach aches.Â  
  On October 28, 1999, KS broke down and told her school principal that Richardson 
  raped her at the family home.Â  TS also admitted to being sexually assaulted 
  by Richardson. 
TS revealed similar behavior by Richardson.Â  She 
  testified that one evening Richardson entered her room and made sexual advances.Â  
  TS refused his requests.Â  Later in the evening, Richardson came to her room 
  while she was asleep.Â  He then got into her bed and began touching her.Â  While 
  he was doing this, he told TS that if she told anyone he would not help her 
  church or her family.Â  According to TS, Richardson removed her clothing and 
  began to have sexual intercourse with her.Â  When she asked Richardson to stop, 
  he reiterated that he would not do anything for the church or her family if 
  she did not comply. TS testified Richardson came to her room at night on several 
  other occasions.Â Â  She did not tell her parents about the incidents because 
  she was embarrassed and afraid to say anything.
Following the discussions with the girls and their 
  school principal, SS and his wife immediately informed the Greenville County 
  Sheriffâ€™s Department about what had happened to their daughters.Â  An investigation 
  was conducted which included both KS and TS undergoing a sexual assault examination.Â  
  After the investigation was completed, a Greenville County grand jury indicted 
  Richardson for one count of criminal sexual conduct, third degree as to KS and 
  one count of criminal sexual conduct with a minor, second degree as to TS.
Richardson testified in his own defense. 
  Â He denied raping or molesting either KS or TS, but admitted to having 
  an affair with their mother. 
 The jury convicted Richardson of criminal 
  sexual conduct, third-degree and criminal sexual conduct with a minor, second-degree.Â  
  The judge sentenced Richardson to five years imprisonment for criminal sexual 
  conduct, third degree and ten years imprisonment for criminal sexual conduct 
  with a minor, second-degree.Â  The sentences were to be served concurrently.Â  
  Richardson appeals.
DISCUSSION
I.
Richardson argues the trial court erred by denying 
  his motions for a directed verdict concerning the charge of criminal sexual 
  conduct, third degree.Â  He contends the evidence failed to establish that he 
  used force or coercion to accomplish a sexual battery on KS.Â  
At the conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case, Richardson 
  moved for a directed verdict as to the charge of criminal sexual conduct, third 
  degree.Â  He asserted there was no evidence of force or coercion.Â  Specifically, 
  he contended the element of coercion required â€œthreats of violence.â€Â  He also 
  argued that even if the evidence could be construed that Richardson persuaded 
  KS to engage in sexual intercourse, persuasion alone was not sufficient to constitute 
  coercion.Â Â  At the conclusion of the case, Richardson renewed his motion.Â  The 
  trial judge denied both motions.
When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict, 
  this Court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light 
  most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 46, 515 
  S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999); State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 364, 574 S.E.2d 
  203, 205 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  If there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial 
  evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find 
  the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Pinckney, 339 
  S.C. 346, 349, 529 S.E.2d 526, 527 (2000).Â  A defendant is entitled to a directed 
  verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â  State 
  v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 642, 576 S.E.2d 168, 171 (2003), cert. denied, 
  124 S. Ct. 101 (2003).Â  Therefore, â€œwhere the facts of the case, even if proved, 
  do not constitute the alleged criminal conduct, a directed verdict must be granted.â€Â  
  State v. Jackson, 338 S.C. 565, 569, 527 S.E.2d 367, 369 (Ct. App. 2000).
â€œA person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct 
  in the third degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with the victim and 
  . . . [t]he actor uses force or coercion to accomplish the sexual battery in 
  the absence of aggravating circumstances.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16‑3‑654(1)(a) 
  (2003); see State v. Ervin, 333 S.C. 351, 354, 510 S.E.2d 220, 
  222 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œCriminal sexual conduct in the third degree specifies 
  the actor must use force or coercion without aggravating circumstances to accomplish 
  the sexual battery.â€).Â  
Â Our Supreme Court has found that â€œforceâ€ and â€œcoercionâ€ 
  as used in section 16-3-654 have â€œbasically the same meaning.â€Â  State v. 
  Hamilton, 276 S.C. 173, 178, 276 S.E.2d 784, 786 (1981).Â  â€œThey â€˜mean to 
  make a person . . .Â  follow a prescribed and dictated course; . . . to inflict 
  or impose:Â  force oneâ€™s will on someone.â€™â€ Id. (quoting American Heritage 
  Dictionary 513).Â Â  The State, in order to prove criminal sexual conduct 
  in any degree, must prove â€œâ€˜that the sexual battery occurred under circumstances 
  where the victimâ€™s consent was lacking.â€™â€ Id. (quoting State v. Cox, 
  274 S.C. 624, 628, 266 S.E.2d 784, 786 (1980)).
 Viewed in the light most favorable to 
  the State, the evidence was sufficient to submit to the jury the charge of criminal 
  sexual conduct, third degree.Â  Richardson presented himself as someone who could 
  provide significant financial assistance to KSâ€™s family and her church. By inviting 
  Richardson into his home, SS conveyed to his family that he was interested in 
  what Richardson could offer.Â  KS testified, and her parents corroborated, that 
  she had been raised in the church and taught to respect her elders and people 
  in positions of authority.Â  Based on these values, she was afraid that she would 
  be punished if she did not do what Richardson asked her to do.Â  Furthermore, 
  KS testified that Richardson had sexual intercourse with her despite her refusals 
  and her questioning whether he was wrong in what he was doing.Â  According to 
  KS, Richardson supported his actions by quoting scriptures.Â  KS testified she 
  was also concerned that her family and church would be deprived of Richardsonâ€™s 
  assistance if she failed to comply with his requests. Â Additionally, 
  she denied she was a willing participant.
Based on this evidence, a jury could reasonably 
  infer that Richardson used coercion to accomplish the sexual battery on KS.Â  
  KS viewed Richardson as an authority figure who relied on religion to support 
  his actions.Â  This authority coupled with Richardsonâ€™s repeated threat to withhold 
  his assistance could have intimidated KS to the point of overcoming her will.Â  
  See State v. Hardy, 409 S.E.2d 96, 98 (N.C. Ct. App. 1991) (â€œ[A]uthority 
  itself intimidates; the implicit threat to exercise it coerces.Â  Coercion . 
  . . is a form of constructive force.â€ (quoting State v. Etheridge, 352 
  S.E.2d 673, 681-82 (N.C. 1987))).Â  Although Richardson contends KS consented 
  and never complained, this alone does not entitle him to a directed verdict.Â  
  Instead, it creates a question of fact in terms of credibility.Â  See 
  State v. Burroughs, 328 S.C. 489, 495, 492 S.E.2d 408, 411 (Ct. App. 
  1997) (finding trial court did not err in denying defendantâ€™s motion for a directed 
  verdict in case involving criminal sexual conduct, third degree, given credibility 
  question was created where defendant claimed the encounter was consensual and 
  the victim testified she refused and was in fear for her life).Â  
Furthermore, we are not persuaded by Richardsonâ€™s 
  argument that the evidence â€œat best . . . supports an attempt to convince KS 
  not to disclose a sexual relationship, but does not support force or 
  coercion to actually engage in one.â€Â  Initially, we note this specific 
  argument was not raised during Richardsonâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  
  As such, we question whether it is preserved for our review.Â  See State 
  v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989) (stating a party cannot 
  argue one theory at trial and a different theory on appeal). In any event, the 
  dichotomy that Richardson attempts to create between statements to prevent a 
  victim from reporting the incident and statements meant to coerce a victim is 
  without merit.Â  Both types of statements may be coercive, especially in this 
  case where KS testified there was a continued pattern of abuse. Even if there 
  were such a distinction, it would not be applicable in this case given KS asserted 
  that she rebuffed Richardson until he warned her that her non-compliance would 
  jeopardize his offers of help to the church.Â Â  
II.
Richardson argues the trial judge erred in admitting 
  prejudicial evidence that had the effect of attacking his character.Â  He contends 
  the solicitor asked him improper questions concerning:Â  (1) whether Richardson 
  considered himself a â€œman of God,â€ and (2) the nature and history of the Foundation.Â  

On cross-examination, the solicitor asked 
  Richardson whether he considered himself a â€œman of God.â€Â  Richardson objected 
  to the question on the ground of relevancy.Â  The judge overruled the objection.Â  

Later in the cross-examination, the solicitor 
  inquired about the nature and history of Richardsonâ€™s foundation.Â  When the 
  solicitor asked about the Foundationâ€™s addresses in other states, Richardson 
  objected.Â  Out of the presence of the jury, Richardson argued the solicitor 
  was trying to question him about matters related to the pending charge of obtaining 
  goods under false pretenses.Â  He contended the charge was not at issue during 
  the trial and it constituted a â€œbad actâ€ under Lyle. 
  [2] Â  The solicitor responded the questions went to Richardsonâ€™s credibility 
  and established the coercive nature of his acts involving KS and TS.Â  The judge 
  sustained the objection. 
The solicitor continued the cross-examination 
  by asking Richardson what representations he had made to the congregations in 
  Greenville.Â  Richardson generally objected.Â  The judge overruled the objection.Â  
  Richardson testified the Foundation could assist churches in developing programs 
  to obtain government subsidies and grants.
â€œThe relevance, materiality, and admissibility 
  of evidence are matters within the sound discretion of the trial court and a 
  ruling will be disturbed only upon a showing of an abuse of discretion.â€Â  State 
  v. Shuler, 353 S.C. 176, 184, 577 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2003).Â  An abuse of discretion 
  occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.Â  State 
  v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467 (2000).Â  
Initially, we note Richardsonâ€™s argument concerning 
  the â€œman of Godâ€ questioning is not preserved for our review.Â  At trial, Richardson 
  objected to this question on the ground of relevancy.Â  On appeal, Richardson 
  asserts the question placed his character at issue.Â  Because Richardson objected 
  to the testimony on a different ground at trial than what he argues on appeal, 
  this argument is not properly before this Court.Â  See State v. Myers, 
  344 S.C. 532, 535, 544 S.E.2d 851, 853 (Ct. App. 2001) (finding where defendant 
  objected at trial on the ground that testimony was irrelevant, he could not 
  argue on appeal that testimony improperly placed his character at issue); see 
  also State v. Dickman, 341 S.C. 293, 295, 534 S.E.2d 268, 269 (2000) 
  (holding a party cannot argue one ground below and then argue another ground 
  on appeal); State v. Byram, 326 S.C. 107, 113, 485 S.E.2d 360, 363 (1997) 
  (stating to be preserved for appeal, an issue must be raised to and ruled on 
  by the trial judge).
In any event, we find no error in the admission 
  of the challenged testimony.Â  First, the solicitorâ€™s questioning did not elicit 
  â€œprior bad actâ€ evidence.Â  See Rule 404(b), SCRE (â€œEvidence of other 
  crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person 
  in order to show action in conformity therewith.Â  It may, however, be admissible 
  to show motive, identity, the existence of a common scheme or plan, the absence 
  of mistake or accident, or intent.â€); Lyle, 125 S.C. at 415-16, 118 S.E. 
  at 807 (South Carolina law precludes evidence of a defendantâ€™s prior crimes 
  or other bad acts to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt for the crime charged except 
  to establish (1) motive, (2) intent, (3) the absence of mistake or accident, 
  (4) a common scheme or plan, or (5) the identity of the perpetrator.).Â  The 
  resulting testimony regarding the history and the work of the Foundation cannot 
  be construed as substantive evidence constituting a â€œbad actâ€ under Lyle.Â  
  Nor did it establish that Richardson had a propensity to commit criminal sexual 
  conduct.Â  Furthermore, the judge excluded any potential â€œbad actâ€ evidence when 
  he sustained Richardsonâ€™s objection to the solicitorâ€™s apparent attempt to delve 
  into the charge for obtaining goods under false pretenses.Â  
Secondly, the evidence was relevant as to the issue 
  of Richardsonâ€™s alleged coercion of KS and TS.Â  See Rule 401, SCRE (â€œâ€˜Relevant 
  evidenceâ€™ means evidence having any tendency to make, the existence of any fact 
  that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less 
  probable than it would be without the evidence.â€).Â  Because KS and TS testified 
  Richardson threatened to withhold from their church the Foundationâ€™s assistance 
  if they did not comply with Richardsonâ€™s sexual demands, it was relevant as 
  to why they in fact complied.Â  Specifically, the evidence established the basis 
  of Richardsonâ€™s authority over KS and TS.Â  Furthermore, the testimony was relevant 
  to Richardsonâ€™s credibility given he denied ever sexually assaulting either 
  KS or TS.Â  See State v. Outlaw, 307 S.C. 177, 179, 414 S.E.2d 
  147, 148 (1992) (â€œIt is well-settled that when a defendant takes the stand he 
  becomes subject to impeachment like any other witness.Â  The defendant may be 
  asked about prior bad acts, not the subject of a conviction, which go to his 
  credibility.â€)(citations omitted). 
In a related argument, Richardson contends that 
  even if the testimony did not involve a prior bad act under Lyle, the 
  evidence effectively attacked his character.Â  See Rule 404(a), SCRE (stating 
  evidence of a personâ€™s character or character trait is inadmissible for the 
  purpose of establishing the person acted in conformity with that particular 
  character or trait on a particular occasion); State v. Nelson, 331 S.C. 
  1, 6, 501 S.E.2d 716, 718-19 (1998) (â€œBoth rules [Lyle and that regarding 
  character evidence] are grounded on the policy that character evidence is not 
  admissible â€œfor purposes of proving that the accused possesses a criminal character 
  or has a propensity to commit the crime with which he is charged.â€ (quoting 
  State v. Peake, 302 S.C. 378, 380, 396 S.E.2d 362, 363 (1990))).Â  We 
  disagree with Richardsonâ€™s contention and find the evidence concerning the Foundation 
  and Richardsonâ€™s involvement in it did not serve the purpose of tending to prove 
  Richardson sexually assaulted KS or TS.Â  Rather, the evidence served to substantiate 
  the testimony of KS and TS regarding their reasons for complying with Richardsonâ€™s 
  demands.
Even if the challenged testimony constituted improper 
  â€œcharacter evidence,â€ any error in its admission was harmless.Â  The testimony 
  was cumulative to other similar testimony that was admitted without objection.Â  
  See State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 196, 577 S.E.2d 445, 448 
  (2003) (stating the erroneous admission of prior bad act evidence is harmless 
  beyond a reasonable doubt if its impact is minimal in the context of the entire 
  record); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993) 
  (finding any error in admission of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to 
  evidence is harmless); State v. Johnson, 298 S.C. 496, 499, 381 S.E.2d 
  732, 733 (1989) (stating admission of improper evidence is harmless where it 
  is merely cumulative to other evidence); see also State v. Reeves, 
  301 S.C. 191, 194, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990) (holding error is harmless when 
  it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial).Â  KS, TS, SS 
  and his wife all testified without objection that Richardson told them and SSâ€™s 
  congregation that the Foundation would assist the church and individuals obtain 
  federal grants to further the ministry. Â Additionally, the solicitor 
  questioned Richardson without objection about the Foundation.
III.
Richardson argues the trial judge erred in permitting 
  the solicitor to make improper and prejudicial comments to the jury during closing 
  arguments.Â  Specifically, he contends the comments constituted a direct attack 
  on his credibility.Â  
Richardson failed to make any objection during 
  closing arguments.Â  He also failed to move for a mistrial on the ground of improper 
  argument.Â  As such, this issue is not properly preserved for our review.Â  See 
  State v. Wiggins, 330 S.C. 538, 550, 500 S.E.2d 489, 496 (1998) (stating 
  failure to object to comments made during argument precludes appellate review 
  of the issue); State v. Penland, 275 S.C. 537, 538-39, 273 S.E.2d 765, 
  766 (1981) (holding defendantâ€™s failure to move for a mistrial on grounds of 
  improper argument by the State constitutes waiver of the issue on appeal); State 
  v. Black, 319 S.C. 515, 521, 462 S.E.2d 311, 315 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œThe proper 
  course to be pursued when counsel makes an improper argument is for opposing 
  counsel to immediately object and to have a record made of the statements 
  or language complained of and to ask the court for a distinct ruling thereon.â€). 

Based on the foregoing, Richardsonâ€™s convictions and sentences are
AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  We use the partiesâ€™ 
    initials to further protect the identity of the minor victims in this case.

 
   [2] Â Â  State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 
    118 S.E. 803 (1923).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Marlboro Park Hospital and Chesterfield General Hospital,
Appellants,
v.
South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control and Doctorâ€™s 
        Outpatient Surgical Clinic, LLC, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3774
Formerly Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-228
Heard January 14, 2004 â€“ Filed March 30, 2004
Revised and Refiled April 12, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED 


  
    
      
David B. Summer, Jr. and Faye A. Flowers, both of Columbia, 
  for Appellants.
E. Katherine Wells, of Columbia; Michael A. Molony and Stephen 
  L. Brown, both of Charleston; and Douglas Jennings, Jr., of Bennettsville; for 
  Respondents.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Marlboro Park Hospital and 
  Chesterfield General Hospital (Hospitals) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s decision 
  affirming the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control 
  Boardâ€™s (the DHEC Board) grant of a certificate of need to Doctorâ€™s Outpatient 
  Surgical Clinic (DOSC), which reversed the decision of a South Carolina Administrative 
  Law Judge (ALJ) denying the certificate.Â  On appeal, the Hospitals argue the 
  circuit court erred in (1) affirming the DHEC Boardâ€™s de novo review 
  of the ALJâ€™s decision; and (2) finding that the ALJ improperly considered evidence 
  not presented at a preceding Staff Review Hearing conducted by the South Carolina 
  Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC).Â  We agree and reverse, 
  finding the DHEC Board erred in using a de novo standard of review rather 
  than one requiring substantial evidence.Â  Additionally, we find that substantial 
  evidence supports the decision of the ALJ. We further find that the ALJ properly 
  considered evidence not presented to DHEC in a preceding Staff Review Hearing 
  because the evidence was related to issues presented during that hearing.Â  Accordingly, 
  we reverse and remand to the circuit court to reinstate the decision of the 
  ALJ.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
DOSC filed its application for a certificate of 
  need with DHEC in 1998, seeking to construct an ambulatory surgery center in 
  Bennettsville.Â  The Hospitals opposed the application.Â  
DHEC conducted a Staff Review Hearing on the application 
  during which both parties presented information supporting their respective 
  positions.Â  In particular, the Hospitals argued that the proposed outpatient 
  surgery center would adversely impact the Hospitals and need for the center 
  was insufficient.Â  DHEC recommended approval of the application for the certificate 
  of need.
The Hospitals requested a contested case hearing 
  before the ALJ.Â  The ALJ conducted a hearing over a seven-day period, during 
  which both sides presented evidence and testimony from eighteen witnesses.Â  
  After making findings of fact, the ALJ concluded the application did not meet 
  the legal criteria for approval of the certificate of need.Â  The ALJâ€™s decision 
  was based in part on the lack of need of a facility and in part on the negative 
  impact the facility would have on the Hospitals.
DOSC appealed this decision to the DHEC 
  Board.Â  In a hearing lasting a little over one hour, the DHEC Board heard oral 
  arguments from both parties.Â  It subsequently issued its order reversing the 
  order of the ALJ and granting the certificate of need.Â  The Board set forth 
  its own findings of fact that contradicted many of the ALJâ€™s findings.
The Hospitals appealed to the circuit 
  court, which affirmed the DHEC Boardâ€™s decision.Â  The Hospitals subsequently 
  filed a motion for reconsideration, which the circuit court denied.Â  This appeal 
  follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Boardâ€™s Standard of Review
The Hospitals argue the Board improperly 
  found facts according to its own view of the evidence utilizing a de novo 
  standard.Â  We agree.
The ALJ presides over all hearings of contested 
  DHEC permitting cases.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-600(B) (Supp. 2002).Â  
  In such cases, the ALJ serves as the finder of fact.Â  Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t 
  of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 512, 560 S.E.2d 410, 413 (2002).Â  
  On appeal of such a contested case, a reviewing tribunal â€œmust affirm the ALJ 
  if the findings are supported by substantial evidence, not based on the [Boardâ€™s] 
  own view of the evidence.â€Â  Dorman v. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 
  350 S.C. 159, 166, 565 S.E.2d 119, 123 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Here, DHECâ€™s Board 
  indisputably sat in an appellate capacity when reviewing the ALJâ€™s decision.Â  
  We find that the DHEC board erred by applying a de novo standard of review 
  rather than a â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ standard. 
  [1] 
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  ALJâ€™s Consideration of New Evidence
The Hospitals further assign error to 
  the DHEC Boardâ€™s determination, with which the circuit court concurred, that 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(E) (Supp. 2000) confines contested hearings before 
  the ALJ to the exact evidence considered during the preceding Staff Review Hearing.Â  
  We agree with this assignment of error.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The DHEC Board held that the ALJ erred 
  in considering evidence not presented during the Staff Review Hearing, all of 
  which undisputedly related to core issues addressed during that hearing. [2] Â  Relying on S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(E), the 
  Board stated that â€œparties are not allowed to submit new or additional facts 
  for consideration at the contested case hearing which were not part of the administrative 
  record at the time of the [DHEC Staff Review Hearing.]â€ 
  [3] Â  We find the DHEC Boardâ€™s interpretation of Section 44-7-210(E) erroneous.
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is 
  to ascertain and effectuate the legislative intent whenever possible.â€Â  Strother 
  v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 62, 504 S.E.2d 117, 
  121 (1998).Â  â€œAll rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one 
  that the legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered 
  in the language used, and that language must be construed in the light of the 
  intended purpose of the statute.â€Â  Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, 
  Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994).Â  The words of the statute 
  must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or 
  forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Hitatchi 
  Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  

Here, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(E) states â€œ[t]he 
  issues considered at the contested case hearing are limited to those 
  presented or considered during the staff review and decision process.â€Â  (emphasis 
  added).Â  However, the DHEC Board expansively interpreted the statute to preclude 
  the ALJ in contested hearings from receiving any evidence not presented 
  to DHEC during a Staff Review Hearing.Â  We reject this interpretation, finding 
  it conflicts with the plain language of the statute and the ordinary meaning 
  of the word â€œissuesâ€ as used in this context.
Additionally, the interpretation advanced 
  by the DHEC Board and circuit court is inconsistent with applicable case law 
  providing a de novo review for ALJ hearings conducted in a posture similar 
  to that in the case at bar.Â Â  See Brown, 348 S.C. at 512, 560 
  S.E.2d at 413 (noting that when reviewing a contested case on appeal, the ALJ 
  conducts a de novo hearing with the presentation of evidence and testimony.).Â  
  A trial de novo is one in which â€œthe whole case is tried as if no trial 
  whatsoever had been had in the first instance.â€Â  Blizzard v. Miller, 
  306 S.C. 373, 375, 412 S.E.2d 406, 407 (1991).Â Â  Moreover, when reviewing a 
  contested case on appeal, â€œ[t]he ALJ, as the fact-finder, must make sufficiently 
  detailed findings supporting the denial [or grant] of a permit application.â€Â  
  Converse Power Corp. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 350 
  S.C. 39, 46, 564 S.E.2d 341, 345 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œDetailed findings enable 
  [an appellate court] to determine whether such findings are supported by the 
  evidence . . . .â€Â  Id.Â  Here, because the ALJ was conducting a de 
  novo hearing, we find that he properly considered the evidence presented 
  in his pursuit to make â€œsufficiently detailed findingsâ€ of fact for subsequent 
  review.Â  
Based on our interpretation of the unambiguous 
  language in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(E) (Supp. 2000) and case law providing 
  the ALJ a de novo review in contested hearings arising from a DHECâ€™s 
  Staff Review Hearing, we conclude that the DHEC Board erred in expanding the 
  term â€œissuesâ€ to include â€œevidence.â€Â  In light of the DHEC Boardâ€™s error, we 
  consequently find that the circuit court erred in its acquiescence to the DHECâ€™s 
  Board position.
III.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Substantial Evidence
The Hospitals contend there was substantial 
  evidence to support the ALJâ€™s finding that the certificate of need should be 
  denied.Â  In particular, they maintain substantial evidence was presented to 
  show the proposed facility would adversely impact the two existing facilities 
  and the need for a new facility was insufficient.Â  Consequently, based upon 
  the credible evidence as determined by the ALJ, the application 
  would not comply with the State Health Plan, thus requiring a denial of the 
  permit by DHEC.Â  We agree.
Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(C) (2002), DHEC must 
  deny a Certificate of Need if an application does not comply with the State 
  Health Plan.Â  Under the applicable State Health Plan, approval of an ambulatory 
  surgical facility requires that six certain criteria must be met.Â  These criteria 
  include proof of a documented need for the facility and a discussion on the 
  impact on existing facilities.Â  The State Health Plan also ranked nine criteria 
  to be considered while reviewing DOSCâ€™s application.Â  The nine criteria in order 
  of importance to DHEC are need, community need documentation, distribution (accessibility), 
  acceptability, efficiency, adverse effect on other facilities, record of the 
  Applicant, ability to complete the project, and financial feasibility. [4] 
As previously discussed, review of the ALJâ€™s factual 
  determinations is measured by the substantial evidence standard.Â  Substantial 
  evidence is not merely a scintilla of evidence, nor is it evidence viewed blindly 
  from one side.Â  Leventis v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 
  340 S.C. 118, 130, 530 S.E.2d 643, 650 (2000)Â  Â Instead, substantial evidence 
  is evidence that, in light of the whole record, allows reasonable minds to reach 
  the reviewing tribunalâ€™s conclusion.Â  Id.Â  Here, the Hospitals, as the 
  moving parties, bore the burden of proving that DOSCâ€™s requested certificate 
  of need should be denied.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(E) (Supp. 2000) 
  (â€œThe burden of proof in a reconsideration or contested case hearing must be 
  upon the moving party.â€).Â  
The ALJ found the Hospitals adequately demonstrated 
  that the proposed facility would have a significant adverse impact on the two 
  Hospitals and that there was not sufficient need demonstrated to justify the 
  new facility.Â  Given evidence presented at the ALJ hearing regarding the lack 
  of full utilization of the Hospitalsâ€™ current facilities, the probability that 
  the new facility will not be able to recapture enough patients to meet its projections, 
  and the result that patients would be taken from the Hospitals, we find substantial 
  evidence existed in the record before the ALJ to support the ALJâ€™s decision 
  denying the certificate of need.Â  We do recognize the evidence to the contrary.Â  
  But, as noted, the appropriate standard of review precludes a de novo 
  review on appeal.Â  Where, as here, reasonable minds could reach the same decision 
  as the ALJ, that decision is supported by substantial evidence.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the decision 
  of the circuit court is reversed, and the matter is remanded to the circuit 
  court to reinstate the decision of the ALJ. 
REVERSED AND REMANDED. 
HEARN, C.J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We are well aware that the DHEC Boardâ€™s brazen attitude 
    and utter disregard for the proper standard of review created the procedural 
    chaos that followed.Â  The parties, in their respective filings with the Board, 
    conceded that the substantial evidence standard governed the review of the 
    ALJâ€™s factual determinations.Â  In defiance of the partiesâ€™ concession and 
    applicable law, the DHEC Board made its own findings of fact, and unapologetically 
    refused to consider the entire record developed in the contested hearing before 
    the ALJ. 

 
   
    [2] Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Two core issues addressed in DHECâ€™s Staff Review Hearing 
    addressed (1) whether there was sufficient need for the proposed facility, 
    and (2) the extent to which, if any, the proposed facility would have an adverse 
    impact on the Hospitals.Â Â  The ALJ considered evidence related to these issues, 
    including the following evidence not presented during the preceding Staff 
    Review Hearing:Â  (1) expert testimony regarding need and adverse impact of 
    the center because the experts were hired subsequent to the hearing; (2) the 
    Hospitalsâ€™ Joint Annual Reports;Â  (3) 1997 outmigration data compiled by the 
    Budget and Control Board; and (4) information on the impact of the federal 
    1997 Balanced Budget Actâ€™s reduction in payments to health care providers.Â  
    This evidence dealt squarely with the issues before the ALJ.

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The circuit court did not specifically address this issue 
    in oral arguments, its subsequent written order, or in response to the Hospitalsâ€™ 
    motion for reconsideration.

 
   [4]  
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The State Health Plan also adds:Â  â€œ[DHEC] will continue to evaluate 
    applications for ambulatory surgery centers on their individual merit.Â  However, 
    it is the determination of [DHEC] that the benefits of improved accessibility 
    will not outweigh the adverse affects caused by the duplication of existing 
    services or equipment.â€

description: Purchaser sued seller of unregistered securities for illegal sale of stock in a corporation, misrepresentation, and breach of fiduciary duty. Seller appeals, arguing:  (1) he was not liable under the Securities Act; (2) a release and settlement agreement signed by the other purchasers was binding on purchaser; and (3) purchaser's claims were barred by laches. THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Frank Gordon, Jr., as Attorney-in-Fact 
        for Dorothy Gordon,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Rudolph Robert Drews, and Raymond 
        Beasley,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3775
Submitted December 8, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  12, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kerry W. Koon, of Charleston, for Appellants.
Justin Oâ€™Toole Lucey, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:Â  Respondent Frank Gordon [1]  brought this action against Rudolph 
  Robert Drews alleging the illegal sale of stock in a corporation, misrepresentation, 
  and breach of fiduciary duty.Â  The trial court: (1) found Drews liable for the 
  sale of unregistered securities in the sum of $50,000; (2) dismissed the other 
  claims; and (3) awarded interest and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Drews appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Drews and his business partner, Raymond 
  Beasley, decided to open a hardware store in the West Ashley area of Charleston 
  in 1996.Â  The store, known as Builders Station, was incorporated, and its board 
  of directors approved a business plan and capital structure that provided for 
  the sale of stock to outside investors. Â Â 
Drews and Beasley agreed that each 
  would own a twenty-five percent share of stock in Builders Station.Â  The other 
  half of the outstanding shares would be sold to outside investors.Â  Drews and 
  Beasley also agreed they would each acquire an additional one-half share for 
  each share issued to outsiders.Â  Ultimately, Builders Station had eleven shareholders. 

Among the investors the company was able to attract 
  was Frank Gordon.Â  On several occasions, Gordon discussed with Drews and Beasley 
  the possibility of investing in the new store.Â  Before agreeing to purchase 
  shares, Gordon asked about the capital structure of the company.Â  Gordon testified 
  he expressed concern that â€œthe monies put in by investors were no where [sic] 
  near sufficient.â€Â  Drews reportedly tried to allay his concern by informing 
  Gordon the company anticipated receiving a $250,000 loan that would be guaranteed 
  by the Small Business Administration.Â  Gordon also claimed Drews and Beasley 
  made oral representations that receipt of the loan was all but certain by assuring 
  Gordon it was a â€œdone dealâ€ or â€œin the bag.â€Â Â  After receiving assurances from 
  Drews and Beasley, Gordon purchased fifty shares at $1,000 per share.Â  
The $250,000 loan, however, never came to fruition.Â  
  When Drews originally negotiated the terms of the loan, he agreed to pledge 
  several parcels of real property he owned as collateral.Â Â  He later sought to 
  revise the terms, seeking a right of indemnification for his collateral, additional 
  compensation, or both.Â  Drewsâ€™ attempts to renegotiate the loan delayed and 
  ultimately prevented its consummation.
The companyâ€™s board of directors (of which all 
  eleven shareholders were members) learned of the dispute over the guaranty and 
  collateralization of the SBA loan in November 1996.Â  Despite the Boardâ€™s additional 
  attempts to obtain the loan, the issue was never resolved.Â  The Board later 
  decided to end Drewsâ€™ relationship with the company.Â  Ultimately, a â€œRelease 
  and Settlement Agreementâ€ was executed releasing Drews and the shareholders 
  from all liability arising out of their business relationship with the corporation.Â  
  Though a majority of the shareholders signed the Release, Frank Gordon refused. 

The business did not succeed and ultimately closed 
  in October 1997. 
Gordon brought suit against Drews, claiming 
  the sale of stock was illegal and fraudulent under section 35-1-1490 of the 
  Uniform Securities Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 35-1-10 to -1590 (Supp. 2003). [2] Â Â  He also asserted claims for 
  common-law misrepresentation and breach of fiduciary duty in connection with 
  Drewsâ€™ sale of the stock.Â Â  
The trial court found Drews was liable 
  under section 35-1-1490(1) for the illegal sale of unregistered securities.Â  
  The court concluded, however, that Drews was not liable for the fraudulent sale 
  of stock under section 35-1-1490(2), nor for common-law misrepresentation or 
  breach of fiduciary duty. Â Â Drews appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section 35-1-1490 provides that a person 
  who purchases a security as a result of an illegal or fraudulent sale or offer 
  â€œmay sue either at law or in equity to recover the consideration paid for the 
  security.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-1490 (Supp. 2003).
To determine whether this suit is legal or equitable, 
  we must look to the â€œmain purposeâ€ of the action as reflected by the nature 
  of the pleadings and proof, and the character of relief sought under them. Ins. 
  Fin. Servs., Inc. v. South Carolina Ins. Co., 271 S.C. 289, 293, 247 S.E.2d 
  315, 318 (1978); see also Alford v. Martin, 176 S.C. 207, 
  212, 180 S.E. 13, 15 (1935) (findingÂ  â€œ[t]he character of an action is determined 
  by the complaint in its main purpose and broad outlines and not merely by allegations 
  that are merely incidentalâ€); Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina v. Daniels, 
  283 S.C. 438, 440, 322 S.E.2d 689, 690 (Ct. App. 1984) (noting that, although 
  the determination of whether an action is legal or equitable â€œmust be determined 
  from the character of the action as framed in the complaint,â€ the court may 
  also consider â€œthe prayer for relief and any other facts and circumstances which 
  throw light upon the main purpose of the actionâ€).
In this action, the only cause of action before 
  this Court is Gordonâ€™s claim seeking return of the price he paid for the Builders 
  Supply stock.Â  Furthermore, this was the exclusive remedy allowed by the trial 
  court.Â  The action, therefore, is rescissionary in nature and is appropriately 
  reviewed under the equitable standard of review. See Brown v. Greenwood 
  Sch. Dist. 50 Bd. of Trustees, 344 S.C. 522, 525, 544 S.E.2d 642, 643 (Ct. 
  App. 2001) (holding an action to rescind a contract was equitable in nature).
Accordingly, this Court may â€œfind facts in accordance 
  with its views of the preponderance of the evidence.â€ Townes Assocs. v. City 
  of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  Our broad scope 
  of review, however, does not require this Court to disregard the findings of 
  the trial judge â€œwho saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position 
  to judge their credibility.â€Â  Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C. 98, 
  105, 531 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2000). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Drewsâ€™ Liability Under the Securities 
  Act
The South Carolina Uniform Securities Act prohibits 
  the sale of securities in this state unless the securities are properly registered 
  with the securities commissioner or the securities are subject to an exemption.Â  
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-810 (Supp. 2003).Â  Drews admits the Builders 
  Supply stock at issue in this case was not registered with the commissioner.Â  
  Drews, however, claims he is not liable for the illegal sale of stock because 
  (A) the stock offering was an exempt transaction under the Securities Act, and 
  (B) he did not participate in the sale of the stock.Â  

A.Â Â Â Â Â  Exemption from Registration Requirement

Drews argues the trial court erred in finding the 
  offering of stock in Builders Station was not exempt from registration as a 
  limited offering.Â  We disagree.
There are numerous registration exemptions 
  provided for under the Securities Act in sections 35-1-310 and 35-1-320.Â  Only 
  one of these exemptionsâ€”the â€œlimited offeringâ€ exemptionâ€”arguably applies in 
  the present case.Â  Section 35-1-320(9) defines this exemption, in pertinent 
  part, as follow:

Any transaction pursuant to an 
  offer directed by the offeror to not more than twenty-five persons . . . in 
  this State during any period of twelve consecutive months, whether or not the 
  offeror or any of the offerees is then present in this State, if (a) the seller 
  reasonably believes that all the buyers in this State . . . are purchasing for 
  investment and (b) no commission or other remuneration is paid or given directly 
  or indirectly for soliciting any prospective buyer in this State.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-320(9) (Supp. 2003).Â  Specifically 
  at issue in the present case is (1) whether Drews offered the Builders Station 
  stock to more than twenty-five people and (2) whether Drews received remuneration 
  for soliciting the potential buyers.
We are mindful that we must narrowly construe 
  exemptions under the Act because the securities laws are remedial in nature 
  and, therefore, should be liberally construed to protect investors.Â  McGaha 
  v. Mosley, 283 S.C. 268, 273, 322 S.E.2d 461, 464 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Furthermore, 
  in arguing the Builders Station stock was exempt from the Actâ€™s registration 
  requirements, Drews bears the burden of proving he was entitled to the claimed 
  exemption.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-340 (Supp. 2003).Â  We find he has failed to 
  satisfy this burden.

1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Number of Offerees

We find Drews failed to sufficiently prove 
  he offered Builders Station stock to no more than twenty-five people.Â  
Drews presented no evidence regarding the number 
  of people to whom he offered stock.Â  Raymond Beasley, Drewsâ€™ original business 
  partner, testified that Drews probably offered the stock to â€œdozensâ€ of people.Â  
  He further testified, â€œI believe we did it to more than 25 peopleâ€ and that 
  Drews offered the stock to â€œdozens and dozens.â€
Drews attempts to circumvent 
  this obvious lack of proof by arguing the limited offering exemption applies 
  when there are not more than twenty-five â€œultimate purchasersâ€ of the offered 
  security.Â  This assertion is without merit.Â  
As always, we look first 
  to the plain meaning of the statute when interpreting its language.Â  See 
  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 
  843, 846 (1992) (holding that words used in a statute â€œmust be given their plain 
  and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit 
  or expand its operationâ€).Â  Under the plain language of section 35-1-320(9), 
  we find this Court is compelled to reject Drewsâ€™ contention that the exemption 
  applies to all transactions involving twenty-five or fewer â€œpurchasers.â€Â  The 
  statute speaks only in terms of an â€œoffer,â€ not a â€œsaleâ€ or â€œpurchase.â€Â  The 
  Securities Act specifically defines â€œofferâ€ and â€œoffer to sellâ€ as including 
  â€œevery attempt or offer to dispose of, or solicitation of an offer to buy, a 
  security or interest in a security for value.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-20(13)(b) 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  We glean no intent on the part of the General Assembly to veer 
  from the plain meaning of this statutory language.
Though our courts have not 
  addressed the application of our stateâ€™s limited offering exemption, similar 
  exemptions under the federal securities laws have been interpreted to require 
  a consideration of the number of offerees, not ultimate purchasers.Â  See, 
  e.g., Doran v. Petroleum Mgmt. Corp., 545 F.2d 893, 900 (5th Cir. 
  1977) (holding that under the private offering exemption of 15 U.S.C.A. Â§ 77d(2), 
  â€œ[t]he number of offerees, not the number of purchasers, is the relevant figure 
  in considering the number of persons involved in an offeringâ€); SEC v. Kenton 
  Capital, Ltd., 69 F. Supp. 2d 1, 11 (D.D.C. 1998) (finding the â€œnumber of 
  offereesâ€ to be a critical factor in determining whether the private placement 
  exemption applies); see also 69A Am. Jur. 2d Securities 
  Regulation Â§ 143 (1993) (commenting that â€œthe failure to prove the number 
  of offerees, not the number of ultimate purchasers, is fatal to the claim of 
  the [limited offering] exemptionâ€).
Although there were only eleven â€œultimate purchasersâ€ 
  in this case, a clear reading of the statute reveals that it is the number of 
  offerees, not the number of ultimate purchasers, with which we are concerned.Â  
  The only evidence presented concerning this question was Beasleyâ€™s testimony 
  that the stock was offered to more than twenty-five people.Â  Because Drews did 
  not introduce any evidence to the contrary, we conclude Drews failed to meet 
  his burden to prove Builders Supply stock was offered to no more than twenty-five 
  persons.

2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Remuneration for Sales

We find Drews is also barred from claiming 
  the limited offering exemption because he received compensation for his sales 
  of the Builders Supply stock.Â  
For each share of Builders Supply stock 
  Drews sold to outside investors, he received an additional one-half share of 
  stock.Â  Drews argues he and Beasley each received an additional one-half share 
  in order to maintain their status as fifty percent shareholders in the corporation, 
  not as compensation for selling stock.Â  We disagree with this characterization.
Again, we look first to the plain meaning 
  of the statutory language.Â  â€œRemunerationâ€ is defined as â€œpayment; compensationâ€ 
  and â€œthe act of paying or compensating.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1298 
  (7th ed. 1999).Â  Other jurisdictions have held that similar share distribution 
  schemes constituted compensation for purposes of determining remuneration under 
  their securities laws.Â  See, e.g., PIC Oil Co. v. Grisham, 
  702 P.2d 28, 33 (Okl. 1985) (holding that receipt of securities by promoters 
  for prices substantially below those paid by outside investors amounted to indirect 
  compensation because the â€œeffect of the interests retained by the [promoters] 
  was to dilute the equity paid by outside investors and to mislead [the outside 
  investors] . . . into believing that [promoters] were contributing a proportionate 
  share of capital for interests retainedâ€); Prince v. Heritage Oil Co., 
  311 N.W.2d 741, 746 (Mich. App. 1981) (holding the sale of undivided fractional 
  interests in oil and gas leases constituted the sale of securities, and the 
  retention of leasehold working interests in the wells amounted to remuneration).
There is no question that the additional shares 
  Drews received when selling the stock represented an increase in the value of 
  his interest in the corporation.Â  For every two shares Drews sold, he received 
  another share.Â  Thus, he received something of value for work he performed.Â  
  We conclude the trial court did not err in finding Drews was remunerated for 
  the sale of Builders Supply stock.

B.Â Â Â Â Â  Liability as Seller of Unregistered 
  Security

Drews contends the trial court erred in 
  finding he was liable as a â€œperson who offers or sells a securityâ€ as defined 
  under the Securities Act.Â  We disagree.
Section 35-1-1490 is the operative provision 
  imposing liability on those who engage in the illegal sale of stock.Â  In pertinent 
  part, it provides: 
Any person who:

(1) offers or sells a security in violation [of the registration 
  requirements of the Securities Act] . . . or
(2) Offers or sells a security by means of any untrue statement 
  of material fact or any omission to state a material fact . . . , the buyer 
  not knowing of the untruth or omission, and who does not sustain the burden 
  of proof that he did not know, and in the exercise of reasonable care could 
  not have known, of the untruth or omission;
Is liable to the person buying the security from him . . . 
  .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-1490 (Supp. 2003). [3] Â  
In evaluating subsection (2) of this statute, our 
  Supreme Court defined a person â€œwho offers or sells a securityâ€ in Biales 
  v. Young, 315 S.C. 166, 432 S.E.2d 482 (1993).Â  The Biales court 
  expressly adopted the â€œfinancial benefits testâ€ articulated by the United States 
  Supreme Court in Pinter v. Dahl, 486 U.S. 622, 108 S.Ct. 2063, 100 L.Ed.2d 
  658 (1988), interpreting a federal law comparable to subsection (1). [4] Â  The Court held that a person â€œwho offers or 
  sells a securityâ€ within the meaning of the Securities Act â€œis not limited to 
  the owner who passes titleâ€; however, to come within the definition, â€œa nonowner 
  must (1) solicit the purchase, and (2) be motivated at least in part by a desire 
  to serve his own financial interest or that of the owner of the security.â€Â  
  Biales, 315 S.C. at 169, 432 S.E.2d at 484-85.Â  In Biales, the 
  Court found that an escrow agent, who had disbursed funds arising from the purchase 
  of securities in property to his client, did not offer, solicit an offer, or 
  pass title to an alleged security within the meaning of the Securities Act where 
  the agent had not â€œpersuaded or urgedâ€ the creditor to purchase the securities 
  in the property.Â  Id. at 170, 432 S.E.2d at 485.Â  The Court went on to 
  adopt the Pinter definition as applicable to the entire statute.Â  Id. 
  (â€œWe, therefore, adopt the Pinter definition of a person â€œwho offers 
  or sells a securityâ€ as applicable to section 35-1-1490.â€).
We are convinced by the evidence in the 
  record that Drews actively solicitedâ€”that is, persuaded or urgedâ€”Gordon to purchase 
  shares in Builders Supply.Â  Drews admitted he met with Gordon at Drewsâ€™ office 
  to discuss investing in Builders Supply, at which time Drews provided Gordon 
  with promotional materials he had prepared. Beasley testified that Drewsâ€™ â€œspecific 
  and total jobâ€ was to raise capital for the new business.Â Â  He also testified 
  that: â€œFrank Gordon was told by the two principal stockholders of Builders Station, 
  Raymond Beasley and R.R. Drews, that financing was in place, and the SBA loan 
  had been procured, in the bag . . . awaiting final signings.â€ 
We also find sufficient evidence to conclude 
  Drewsâ€™ solicitation of Gordon was motivated at least in part by a desire to 
  serve his own financial interests and that of his fellow shareholders, thus 
  satisfying the second prong of the Biales/Pinter test.Â  It can 
  hardly be disputed that the success of the Builders Supply venture depended 
  on the ability of Beasley and Drews to raise sufficient capital.Â  Therefore, 
  they had a direct financial incentive to market and sell shares in the new company.
Accordingly, we find no error with the 
  trial courtâ€™s finding Drews was liable for the illegal sale of stock.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Release and Settlement Agreement
Drews next argues the trial court erred in finding 
  Gordon was not bound by the Release and Settlement Agreement executed by a majority 
  of the Builders Station board members.Â  We disagree.
It is undisputed that 
  Gordon did not sign the agreement.Â  Drews, however, contends the release was 
  binding against Gordon even though he did not sign it because he â€œaccepted the 
  benefits of the release.â€ 
Drews argues this result is mandated by our Supreme 
  Courtâ€™s holding in Watson v. Coxe Bros. Lumber Co., 203 S.C. 125, 26 
  S.E.2d 401 (1943).Â  We find this case inapposite.Â  Watson involved an 
  employee of the lumber company that had been injured on the job.Â  When the employee 
  brought suit against the company for damages, the company claimed it had been 
  released from liability when it paid the employee an agreed-upon settlement.Â  
  The Court held that the employee must return the settlement payment before suing 
  on the underlying action. Â Id. at 135, 26 S.E.2d at 404.
Unlike the injured employee in Watson, Gordon 
  did not enter into an agreement to receive any compensation or other benefit 
  in exchange for Drewsâ€™ resignation.Â  The â€œbenefitâ€ Drews claims Gordon allegedly 
  received was â€œan incremental increase in [his] percentage of stock in relation 
  to the outstanding number of shares.â€Â  Again, unlike Watson, this â€œbenefitâ€ 
  was not bargained for by Gordon, nor was Gordon capable of returning this â€œbenefitâ€ 
  to the company since the change in his percentage ownership was merely incidental 
  to the fixed number of shares he had purchased.Â  
Furthermore, any claim that Gordon impliedly â€œratifiedâ€ 
  the agreement without signing it is equally without merit.Â  The record reflects 
  that, at the board of directors meeting during which the settlement agreement 
  was presented and signed, Gordon specifically asked Builders Supplyâ€™s corporate 
  attorney whether he would be bound by the agreement if he did not sign.Â  He 
  was told he would not be so bound.
For these reasons, we find the trial court correctly 
  ruled Gordon was not bound by the Release and Settlement Agreement.
III.Â Â Â  Laches
Drews also asserts Gordonâ€™s claims are barred 
  by laches. We disagree.
â€œLachesâ€ is defined as â€œneglect for an 
  unreasonable and unexplained length of time, under circumstances affording opportunity 
  for diligence, to do what in law should have been done.â€Â  Muir v. C.R. Bard, 
  Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 296, 519 S.E.2d 583, 598 (Ct. App. 1999); Treadaway 
  v. Smith,Â  325 S.C. 367, 378, 479 S.E.2d 849, 855-56 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œDelay 
  alone is not enough to constitute laches; it must be unreasonable, and the party 
  asserting laches must show prejudice.â€Â  Brown v. Butler, 347 S.C. 259, 
  265, 554 S.E.2d 431, 434 (Ct. App. 2001); Hallums v. Hallums, 296 S.C. 
  195, 130 S.E.2d 525 (1988).
Parties seeking recovery under section 35-1-1490 
  must tender their securities before recovering the consideration paid for the 
  shares.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-1490 (Supp. 2003).Â  Gordon tendered his shares 
  during the trial.Â  Drews asserts Gordonâ€™s claims are barred by laches because 
  he tendered his securities more than four years after Builders Supply ceased 
  business operations.Â  
Section 35-1-1510, however, provides: â€œAny tender 
  specified in Section 35-1-1490 may be made at any time before entry of judgment.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-1510 (Supp. 2003).Â  Gordon, therefore, tendered his shares 
  within the statutorily prescribed time limit.Â  Accordingly, we will not apply 
  the equitable doctrine of laches in a manner that would subvert this explicit 
  statutory provision.
Moreover, we discern no prejudice to Drews due 
  to Gordonâ€™s delay in tendering his shares.Â  Gordon filed his initial complaint 
  over one and one-half years before the action went to trial.Â  Drews had no reason 
  to believe Gordon would not tender his shares within the time period allowed 
  by statute.
We conclude the trial court was correct to deny 
  Drewsâ€™ request to dismiss Gordonâ€™s claims as barred by laches.
IV.Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Lastly, Drews argues the trial courtâ€™s 
  award of $42,693.50 in attorneyâ€™s fees to Gordon was unreasonable.Â  We disagree.
As a general rule, the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees 
  to be awarded in a particular case is within the discretion of the trial judge.Â  
  Baron Data Sys., Inc. v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 385-86, 377 S.E.2d 296, 
  298 (1989).Â  The award, however, must be reasonable.Â  Id.
There are six factors for the trial court to consider 
  when determining an award of attorneyâ€™s fees: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty 
  of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional 
  standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) beneficial results 
  obtained; and (6) customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Jackson v. 
  Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 308, 486 S.E.2d 750, 760 (1997).Â  Upon request for 
  attorneyâ€™s fees that are authorized by contract or statute, the trial court 
  should make specific findings of fact on the record for each of these factors.Â  
  See Jackson, 326 S.C. at 308, 486 S.E.2d at 760 (holding that, 
  â€œon appeal, an award for attorneyâ€™s fees will be affirmed so long as sufficient 
  evidence in the record supports each factorâ€); Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 
  310 S.C. 492, 494, 427 S.E.2d 659, 661 (1993) (holding that the â€œcourt should 
  make specific findings of fact on the record for each factorâ€). 
In the present case, the trial court entered 
  specific findings for each of the required factors outlined in the case law. 
  Â These findings are sustained by the evidence in the record.Â  Thus, the 
  award is affirmed.
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court 
  properly found Drews liable for the illegal sale of an unregistered security 
  under the Securities Act, and that Drews failed to prove his entitlement to 
  the limited offering exemption under the Act.Â  Also, for the reasons stated 
  above, Drewsâ€™ other claims and defenses are without merit.Â  The trial courtâ€™s 
  rulings are therefore
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Gordon brought this action on behalf of his mother, Dorothy Gordon.Â  
    Gordon used his motherâ€™s funds to purchase the stocks in question and acted 
    at all times on her behalf.Â  

 
   [2]  There have been no substantive changes to the 
    Uniform Securities Act since the underlying cause of action arose.Â  Accordingly, 
    we cite to the most current version of the Act.Â Â  

 
   
    [3]  Gordon was allowed to amend his complaint to conform with the evidence 
    at the conclusion of trial to include an action under both section 35-1-1490(1) 
    and (2).Â Â  In the final order, the trial court found Gordon was entitled to 
    recover from Drews for a violation of section 35-1-1490(1).Â Â  However, the 
    court went on to hold that Gordon could not prevail under subsection (2) because 
    Drews met his burden of showing he could not have known of the untruth of 
    his statements.Â  Accordingly, we evaluate the trial courtâ€™s order as applied 
    to subsection (1).

 
   
    [4]  The Pinter Court limited its holding to Section 12(1) of the 
    Securities Act, codified at 15 U.S.C.A. Â§ 77l (1981), holding â€œthis 
    case does not present, nor do we take a position on, the scope of a statutory 
    seller for the purposes of [Section] 12(2).â€Â  Pinter, 486 U.S. at 642 
    n.20, 108 S.Ct. at 2076 n.20, 100 L.Ed.2d at 679 n.20.Â  Although many state 
    courts, including South Carolina, have adopted the Pinter â€œfinancial 
    benefits testâ€ as applicable to their state statutes comparable to Section 
    12(2), some have refused to extend the definition of seller and have instead 
    adopted a â€œsubstantial factor test.â€Â  See, e.g., Hoffer v. 
    State, 776 P.2d 963, 964-65 (Wash. 1989) (refusing to extend the Pinter 
    test to subsection (2) of the state statute and maintaining the â€œsubstantial 
    factor testâ€ to evaluate that section as previously adopted by the court).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Caroline Boyd and The Caroline Collection, Inc.,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
BellSouth Telephone Telegraph Company, Inc., aka BellSouth Telecommunications, 
        Inc., now known as BellSouth,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Bamberg County
J. Martin Harvey, Special Referee

Opinion No. 3776
Heard November 5, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  12, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
and REMANDED


  
    
      
J. D. Mosteller, III, of Barnwell and Stephen A. Spitz, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Richard B. Ness, of Bamberg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 HOWARD, J.:Â  Caroline Boyd, on 
  behalf of herself and her antique business, The Caroline Collection, Inc., sued 
  BellSouth Telephone Telegraph Company, Inc., a/k/a BellSouth Telecommunications, 
  Inc., now known as BellSouth (â€œBellSouthâ€), seeking to establish an easement 
  over BellSouthâ€™s property.Â  Specifically, Boyd alleged she possessed an easement 
  by necessity, pre-existing use, or estoppel.Â  The special referee granted summary 
  judgment to BellSouth, concluding no easement arose under any view of the facts.Â  
  Boyd appeals, arguing factual issues precluded summary judgment as to each cause 
  of action.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The two properties involved in this litigation 
  are located in the City of Denmark, South Carolina.Â  At one time, BellSouth 
  owned both properties under its predecessor name, AT&T. As one parcel, the 
  property was bounded on three sides by public streets. 
In 1923, AT&T built a three-story building 
  to house offices and switching equipment on the front portion of the lot. Thereafter, 
  BellSouth constructed a concrete driveway running from the street at the back 
  of the property to double-doors at the back of the building.Â  These rear doors 
  lead to the basement of the building.Â  
In 1988, BellSouth severed the front lot, 
  selling it to the City of Denmark.Â  The City continued using the driveway to 
  access the rear of the building. Â Approximately three years after the original 
  severance, the City sold the lot and building to Boydâ€™s husband, who in turn 
  transferred it to Boyd to use as a retail antique store.Â  According to Boydâ€™s 
  husband, driveway access was a consideration in the decision to purchase the 
  property.Â  Boyd asserts her husband was acting on behalf of both himself and 
  Boyd in the purchase of the building, in a joint venture, to open the antique 
  business.
Following the purchase, BellSouth gave 
  Boyd access to the driveway by allowing her to have a lock and key to the gate 
  located at the street fronting on BellSouthâ€™s property.Â  Boyd used this driveway 
  to accept deliveries from tractor-trailers carrying large furniture, such as 
  pianos, which she placed in the basement level of the antique store.Â  However, 
  after the terrorist attack on the United States on September 11, 2001, BellSouth 
  increased the security to its property, notifying Boyd it intended to place 
  a fence along her back property line separating Boydâ€™s property from BellSouthâ€™s 
  property, thereby cutting off access to the driveway.
In response, Boyd sued BellSouth, arguing the court 
  should grant her continued use of the driveway by virtue of an easement by necessity 
  and an easement by pre-existing use.Â  Furthermore, Boyd claimed BellSouth made 
  representations to her husband at the time he purchased the property, estopping 
  BellSouth from claiming no easement existed.Â Â  The case was referred to a special 
  referee.
BellSouth moved for summary judgment on all of 
  Boydâ€™s causes of action.Â  The special referee concluded no questions of fact 
  existed and granted summary judgment.Â  Boyd appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
To obtain summary judgment, the moving 
  party must demonstrate there is â€œno genuine issue of material fact and the moving 
  party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  In deciding 
  whether to grant summary judgment, trial courts must construe all ambiguities, 
  conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence against the moving party.Â  
  Id.Â  Alternatively stated, â€œif the pleadings and evidentiary matter in 
  support of summary judgment do not establish the absence of a genuine issue 
  of material fact, summary judgment must be denied . . . .â€ Baird v. Charleston 
  County, 333 S.C. 519, 529, 511 S.E.2d 69, 74 (1999).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[a]n 
  appellate court reviews the granting of summary judgment under the same standard 
  applied by the trial court.â€Â  Wells v. City of Lynchburg, 331 S.C. 296, 
  301, 501 S.E.2d 746, 749 (Ct. App. 1998) 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Easement By Necessity
Boyd argues the special referee erred by granting 
  summary judgment on her claim for easement by necessity.Â  We disagree.
A party claiming to be benefited by an easement 
  by necessity must demonstrate the existence of the following three elements: 
  1) unity of title; 2) severance of the title; and 3) necessity of the easement. 
  Morrow v. Dyches, 328 S.C. 522, 529, 492 S.E.2d 420, 424 (Ct. App. 1997).
The third element, that of necessity, requires 
  a showing of more than convenience. Morrow, 328 S.C. at 529, 492 S.E.2d 
  at 424.Â  The doctrine of easement by necessity is based upon the presumption 
  that the grantor intended the grantee of a landlocked parcel to have access 
  to his property, a right recognized as essential to the enjoyment of the land.Â  
  Id.Â  Thus,Â  â€œ[this] doctrine only provides reasonable access to the dominant 
  estate when there is none; it does not provide a means for ensuring a preferred 
  method of access to a particular portion of a tract when access to the tract 
  is otherwise available.â€ Id.  
Public streets border Boydâ€™s property.Â  Therefore, 
  we agree with the conclusion of the special referee that no easement by necessity 
  arises under the facts of this case.Â  Rather, under any view of the evidence, 
  Boyd has reasonable access to her property.Â  Accordingly, we hold the special 
  referee properly granted summary judgment.
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Implied Easement by Pre-existing Use
Boyd argues the special referee erred 
  by granting summary judgment on her claim for an implied easement by pre-existing 
  use.Â  We agree.
An easement by pre-existing use exists where:Â  
  1) the dominant and servient tracts of land originated from a common grantor; 
  2) the use was in existence at the time the original grantor severed the tracts; 
  and 3) the use was apparent, continuous, and necessary for enjoyment of the 
  dominant tract.Â  Crosland v. Rogers, 32 S.C. 130, 133, 10 S.E. 874, 875 
  (1889); see Slater v. Price, 96 S.C. 245, 255-56, 80 S.E. 372, 
  374 (1913) (holding the trial court did not err by charging the jury on the 
  law of easement by pre-existing use); 25 Am. Jur. 2d Easements and Licenses 
  Â§ 27 (1996) (â€œWhere, during the unity of title, an apparently permanent and 
  obvious servitude is imposed on one part of the estate in favor of another part, 
  which servitude is in use at the time of severance and is necessary for the 
  reasonable enjoyment of the other part, on a severance of the ownership a grant 
  of the right to continue such use arises by implication of law.â€); Russakoff 
  v. Scruggs, 400 S.E.2d 529, 532 (Va. 1991) (holding to establish an easement 
  by pre-existing use, one must demonstrate:Â  â€œ(1) the dominant and servient tracts 
  originated from a common grantor, (2) the use was in existence at the time of 
  the severance, and that (3) the use is apparent, continuous, and reasonably 
  necessary for the enjoyment of the dominant tract.â€); Ryerson Tower, Inc. 
  v. St. James Towers, Inc., 517 N.Y.S.2d 48, 49 (N.Y. App. Div. 1987) (â€œAn 
  implied easement arises when two adjacent parcels of land were previously held 
  in common title and an intent can be ascertained from the circumstances surrounding 
  the landâ€™s previous use and the conveyance that the holder of one parcel is 
  to have a right to pass through the other parcel, or to make some other such 
  limited use of it.â€); Underwood v. Shepard, 521 So.2d 1314, 1316 (Ala. 
  1988) (holding an easement by pre-existing use exists, where the following are 
  demonstrated:Â  1) unity of ownership; and 2) a use during that ownership that 
  was open, visible, continuous, and reasonably necessary to the estate granted); 
  see also Charles C. Marvel, Annotation, What Constitutes Unity of 
  Title or Ownership Sufficient for Creation of an Easement by Implication or 
  Way of Necessity, 94 A.L.R.3d 502 (1979) (â€œ[W]here, during the unity of 
  title, an apparently permanent and obvious servitude is imposed on one part 
  of an estate in favor of another part, which servitude is in use at the time 
  of severance and is necessary for the reasonable enjoyment of the severed part, 
  a grant or reservation of the right to continue such use arises by implication 
  of law.â€).
The term necessary in the context means, â€œthere 
  could be no other reasonable mode of enjoying the dominant tenement without 
  this easement . . . .â€ Crosland, 32 S.C. at 133, 10 S.E. at 875.
In a light most favorable to Boyd, the evidence 
  within the record indicates BellSouth was the common owner of the two properties.Â  
  Furthermore, prior to the severance, BellSouth used Boydâ€™s building as a commercial 
  building, and the driveway in question was used to access the rear doors of 
  the building.Â  The use was present at the time of severance and apparent and 
  continuous during the period of common ownership.Â  Thus, the only remaining 
  inquiry is whether evidence exists within the record indicating use of the driveway 
  to access the rear doors was necessary for the enjoyment of Boydâ€™s property, 
  the dominant tract.Â  Id.Â  
According to the affidavits and testimony presented 
  by Boyd, the building in question only has two entrances â€“ the front entrance 
  and the rear doors.Â  The evidence indicates that at the time BellSouth owned 
  the property, the front entrance was unsuitable for loading and unloading the 
  type of equipment owned by BellSouth.Â  The evidence also indicates the driveway 
  provided the only means of access to the rear doors, and the driveway was used 
  to access the rear doors for a period of at least fifty years. 
Furthermore, the evidence indicates for the brief 
  period the City owned the building, they used the rear doors as loading doors.Â  
  Additionally, at the present time, the loading doors are the only reasonable 
  means of access for moving large items in and out of the building.Â  
Viewing this evidence in a light most favorable 
  to Boyd, we conclude a factual issue exists as to whether BellSouthâ€™s driveway 
  is reasonably necessary for the enjoyment of Boydâ€™s property.Â  Thus, we hold 
  the special referee erred by granting summary judgment on this issue. 
III.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  Estoppel
Boyd argues the special referee erred by granting 
  summary judgment against her claim for easement by estoppel.Â  We agree.
â€œThe doctrine of estoppel applies if a 
  person, by his actions, conduct, words or silence which amounts to a representation, 
  or a concealment of material facts causes another to alter his position to his 
  prejudice or injury.â€ Hubbard v. Beverly, 197 S.C. 476, 480, 15 S.E.2d 
  740, 741 (1941); see also Ott v. Ott, 182 S.C. 135, 140, 188 S.E. 
  789, 792 (1936) (â€œThe final element of an equitable estoppel is that the person 
  claiming it must have been misled into such action that he will suffer injury 
  if the estoppel is not declared. That is, the person setting up the estoppel 
  must have been induced to alter his position, in such a way that he will be 
  injured if the other person is not held to the representation or attitude on 
  which the estoppel is predicated.â€).Â  
In a light most favorable to Boyd, the evidence 
  within the record indicates that when Boydâ€™s husband was negotiating the purchase 
  of the front lot, he negotiated with BellSouth to purchase the rear lot, but 
  thought BellSouthâ€™s price of forty thousand dollars was too high.Â  He countered 
  at thirty-five thousand dollars, whereupon a BellSouth agent explained that 
  he did not need the property because he had access through the driveway to the 
  rear of the building located on the front lot.Â  According to Boydâ€™s husband, 
  the agent supplied him with a â€œplot plan,â€ showing the driveway running through 
  the BellSouth property to the building.Â  Relying on these representations, the 
  Boyds, acting as joint venturers, purchased the front lot to open an antique 
  buisness.Â  
We conclude this evidence is sufficient to establish 
  a claim for estoppel.Â  Thus, we hold the special referee erred by granting summary 
  judgment.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the special 
  referee granting summary judgment on the cause of action to establish easement 
  by necessity is affirmed.Â  The grant of summary judgment on the causes of action 
  to establish an easement implied by pre-existing use and by estoppel is reversed, 
  and the matter is remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
AFFIRMED in part, REVERSED in part, and REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J. and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

title: State v. Childers
description: Childers appeals his conviction for murder, ABHAN, and firing a firearm into a dwelling, arguing: (1) the trial judge erred in refusing his request to relieve defense counsel based on counsel's prosecution of him in the past and counsel's previous representation of the victim's brother, and (2) the trial judge erred by declining to charge the jury on the law of voluntary manslaughter.  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
