THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
William Larry Childers, Jr.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3777
Heard March 11, 2004 â€“ Filed April, 
  12, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor 
  Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: William Larry Childers, Jr. 
  was convicted of murder, assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature 
  (ABHAN), and discharging a firearm into a dwelling.Â  The trial judge imposed 
  a sentence of life imprisonment for murder and concurrent terms of ten years 
  imprisonment each for ABHAN and discharging a firearm.Â  Childers appeals.Â  We 
  affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Childers was estranged from the victim, 
    his former live-in girlfriend, at the time of the victimâ€™s death.Â  Though 
    the victim and her children were living with her mother, Childers testified 
    the couple was attempting to reconcile. 
    [1] Â  The victimâ€™s sister testified that on October 14, 2000, Childers 
    came to the house to visit the victim and return some CDs.Â  After the victim 
    refused to leave the house, the sister testified Childers â€œstarted getting 
    madâ€ and threw the CDs before he left.Â  The victimâ€™s sister further testified 
    that she, her ex-husband, and the victim saw Childers at a turkey shoot later 
    that night.Â 
  At approximately 3:00 a.m. the following morning, 
    October 15, 2000, the victimâ€™s brother testified he called the police because 
    he saw Childers outside of the house.Â  Police arrived at the scene but did 
    not find anyone in the vicinity.Â  The victimâ€™s brother testified that, shortly 
    after the police left, he heard gunshots and ran outside, where he â€œ[saw] 
    Larry Childers go across the yard.â€Â  
  The victimâ€™s sister testified that she, her ex-husband, 
    and the victim returned to her motherâ€™s home from the turkey shoot in the 
    early morning hours of October 15th and stood in the yard talking.Â  The sister 
    testified that her ex-husband suddenly said he saw Childers with a gun right 
    before she heard gunshots.Â  Childers shot the victim twice, killing her.Â  
    The sister testified Childers then shot at her once before he fired a shot 
    into the house.Â  The sisterâ€™s ex-husband corroborated her testimony.Â  
  Childers testified to a different version of 
    the eveningâ€™s events.Â  Childers stated he and the victim had been involved 
    in a serious relationship and that they had only been estranged for eight 
    or nine days before the shooting.Â  Childers admitted that he saw the victim 
    at the turkey shoot, and he claimed that the victim indicated she was willing 
    to talk to him, but he wanted to talk to her privately, not at the turkey 
    shoot. After leaving the turkey shoot, Childers testified that he drove around 
    for a while before going to a friendâ€™s house that was near the home of the 
    victimâ€™s mother.Â  Childers walked to the motherâ€™s home because he wanted to 
    â€œtry to get [the victim] to come outside and talk to [him] a minute because 
    [they had] fussed, she had got mad with [him] earlier and [he] wanted to clear 
    that up.â€Â  Childers testified that he brought a loaded gun with him in case 
    he encountered stray dogs during his walk.Â  
  Childers testified that when he arrived at the 
    house, he saw the victim, her sister, and her sisterâ€™s ex-husband in the yard.Â  
    As he walked toward them, Childers testified that the ex-husband shot at him.Â  
    Childers said he immediately fired back and ran away. 
  After the jury had been selected, the 
    public defender, who was aÂ  former assistant solicitor, informed the trial 
    judge that he had prosecuted Childers approximately ten years earlier and 
    that he had performed some legal work for the victimâ€™s brother approximately 
    six years before the trial.Â  Defense counsel informed the judge that Childers 
    did not â€œfeel comfortable at this point with my previous relationship with 
    the [S]tate and as a prosecutor against him.â€Â  Childers then told the judge, 
    â€œI want him [re]moved because he prosecuted me.â€Â  The trial judge declined 
    to relieve defense counsel, stating there was no â€œbuilt-in conflict,â€ as Childersâ€™ 
    prior trial was several years earlier and defense counsel did not remember 
    prosecuting him. The trial judge did not specifically address the fact that 
    defense counsel had previously done legal work for the victimâ€™s brother.
  At the close of trial, defense counsel asked 
    for charges on self defense, involuntary manslaughter, and voluntary manslaughter. 
    The trial judge agreed to charge self defense and involuntary manslaughter, 
    but refused to charge voluntary manslaughter. The jury ultimately returned 
    with guilty verdicts on murder, ABHAN, and discharging a firearm into a dwelling, 
    and Childers received an aggregate sentence of life imprisonment.Â  Childers 
    appeals.Â  
  LAW/ANALYSIS 
  I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Request to Relieve Defense Counsel 
    Childers argues the trial judge erred in refusing 
      his request to relieve defense counsel based on counselâ€™s prosecution of 
      him in the past and counselâ€™s previous representation of the victimâ€™s brother.Â  
      We disagree.
    â€œA motion to relieve counsel is addressed to 
      the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse 
      of discretion.â€Â  State v. Graddick, 345 S.C. 383, 385, 548 S.E.2d 
      210, 211 (2001) (citation omitted).Â  The mere possibility that defense counsel 
      may have a conflict of interest is insufficient to impugn a criminal conviction.Â  
      See Langford v. State, 310 S.C. 357, 359, 426 S.E.2d 793, 
      795 (1993) (citing Cuyler v. Sullivan, 446 U.S. 335, 350 (1980)).

    A.Â Â Â Â Â  Defense counsel as former 
      prosecutor

    When defense counsel revealed to the court 
      that he had successfully prosecuted Childers ten years earlier, he stated 
      that he had no independent recollection of the case.Â  In fact, he only learned 
      of the prosecution when the solicitor checked the files and revealed to 
      him that he was the assistant solicitor in charge of Childersâ€™ prior case.Â Â  
    
    While South Carolina courts have never addressed 
      whether an attorney who formally prosecuted the defendant can later serve 
      as appointed counsel for the defendant in a subsequent case, other jurisdictions 
      have addressed the issue.Â  In State v. Cobbs, 584 N.W.2d 709 (Wis. 
      Ct. App. 1998), defense counsel had previously prosecuted the defendant 
      when he was working in the district attorneyâ€™s office.Â  The Wisconsin Supreme 
      Court found there was no actual conflict of interest or serious potential 
      conflict of interest.Â  Id. at 711.Â  The court pointed out that â€œ[t]here 
      were no competing loyalties in this case,â€ nor was it â€œa situation where 
      defense counsel has appeared for and represented the State as a prosecutor 
      in prior proceedings involving the same case in which he or she currently 
      represents the defendant[.]â€Â  Id.Â  (Emphasis in original.) See 
      also People v. Nunez, 186 A.D.2d 764 (N.Y. App. Div. 1992) (finding 
      that even though defense counsel had formerly been a solicitor and even 
      though she had only visited defendant twice during his incarceration, the 
      trial court did not err in failing to substitute counsel because there was 
      no irreconcilable conflict of interest). Other jurisdictions have even found 
      no conflict despite defense counselâ€™s actual involvement in the prosecution 
      of the same case against his eventual client.Â  See e.g., State 
      v. King, 447 So.2d 395 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1984) (finding defendantâ€™s 
      counsel need not be disqualified in the revocation of probation case even 
      though he had been the prosecuting attorney for the underlying charges because 
      the alleged violation of probation was factually unrelated to the prior 
      offense and there was no actual prejudice shown); Brown v. State, 
      385 N.E.2d 1148 (Ind. 1979) (finding no abuse of discretion where trial 
      judge denied a mistrial motion that was made after it was discovered that 
      defense counsel, who was a previous prosecutor, had several informations 
      against the defendant).Â Â Â  
    In this case, aside from the fact that defense 
      counsel had prosecuted Childers ten years earlier, there was no showing 
      of any competing loyalties or actual conflict.Â  See People v. 
      Abar, 786 N.E.2d 1255 (N.Y. 2003) (stating that there was no evidence 
      the public defender obtained information about defendant through her prior 
      employment as an assistant district attorney even though she had prosecuted 
      the defendant in the past).Â  When there is no actual conflict, the defendant 
      must demonstrate he was prejudiced by the attorneyâ€™s representation of him. 
      Cf. Thomas v. State, 346 S.C. 140, 145 n.2, 551 S.E.2d 254, 
      259 n.2 (2001) (â€œPetitioner does not have to demonstrate prejudice if there 
      is an actual conflict of interest.â€).Â  Here, there was no showing of prejudice.Â  
      Defense counsel testified that he was ready and prepared to defend Childersâ€™ 
      case, and other than complaining that his attorney had not met with him 
      frequently enough prior to trial, Childers did not articulate any reason 
      he would be prejudiced by being represented by his former prosecutor.Â  Thus, 
      we find no error in the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to relieve defense counsel.

    B.Â Â Â Â Â  Defense counselâ€™s representation 
      of witness

    Childers also argues defense counsel should 
      have been relieved based on his past representation of the victimâ€™s brother.Â  
      While defense counsel mentioned he had â€œpreviously done some workâ€ for the 
      brother approximately six years before Childersâ€™ trial, the trial judge 
      did not rule upon whether this prior representation was grounds for a conflict. 
      [2] Â  As such, this issue is not preserved for review by this court.Â  
      See State v. Perez, 334 S.C. 563, 566-67, 514 S.E.2d 754, 
      755 (1999) (holding an issue must be both raised to and ruled upon by the 
      trial judge to be preserved for appellate review); see also State 
      v. Graddick, 345 S.C. 383, 386, 548 S.E.2d 210, 211 (stating that it 
      was defendantâ€™s burden to show satisfactory cause for removing counsel).Â  
    
    II.Â Â Â Â Â  Jury Charge
    Next, Childers argues the trial judge erred by 
      declining to charge the jury on the law of voluntary manslaughter.Â  We agree.
    The evidence presented at trial determines 
      the charged jury instruction.Â  State v. Lee, 298 S.C. 362, 364, 380 
      S.E.2d 834, 836 (1989).Â  â€œThe purpose of a jury instruction is to enlighten 
      the jury and to aid it in arriving at a correct verdict.â€Â  State v. Blurton, 
      352 S.C. 203, 207, 573 S.E.2d 802, 804 (2002).Â  â€œWhen determining whether 
      a defendant is entitled to a voluntary manslaughter charge, the court views 
      the facts in the light most favorable to the defendant.â€Â  State v. Grubbs, 
      353 S.C. 374, 381, 577 S.E.2d 493, 497 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
    â€œVoluntary manslaughter is the unlawful killing 
      of a human being in sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation.â€Â  
      State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 360, 535 S.E.2d 420, 424 (2000).Â  
      â€œTo warrant a courtâ€™s eliminating the offense of manslaughter, it should 
      very clearly appear that there is no evidence whatsoever tending to reduce 
      the crime from murder to manslaughter.â€Â  State v. Cole, 338 S.C. 
      97, 101, 525 S.E.2d 511, 513 (2000).
    Here, there was evidence that Childers only 
      fired his gun after he was shot at by the victimâ€™s ex-brother-in-law.Â  In 
      State v. Penland, 275 S.C. 537, 540, 273 S.E.2d 765, 766 (1981), 
      our supreme court found that a voluntary manslaughter charge was warranted 
      â€œbased upon a statement given by appellant following the shooting, which 
      created a jury issue on provocation and heat of passion due to the evidence 
      of the pointing of the gun at the appellant and the subsequent struggle.â€Â  
      Thus, if the pointing of a gun and subsequent struggle justifies a voluntary 
      manslaughter charge, so too would the pointing of a gun and subsequent firing 
      of that gun.Â  Although it was the victimâ€™s brother-in-law, and not the victim 
      herself, who allegedly shot at and thereby provoked Childers, the doctrine 
      of transferred intent justifies a voluntary manslaughter charge as to the 
      killing of the victim.Â  See State v. Gandy, 283 S.C. 571, 
      573, 324 S.E.2d 65, 67 (1984) implicitly overruled on other grounds by 
      Casey v. State, 305 S.C. 445, 409 S.E.2d 391 (1991) (â€œWhere a defendant 
      intends to kill or seriously injure one person, but kills another, a defendant 
      may be found guilty of murder or manslaughter.â€)Â  Accordingly, Childersâ€™ 
      conviction for murder is reversed and remanded. 
     CONCLUSION
       We find no error in the trial judgeâ€™s 
        refusal to relieve counsel; however, the trial judge did err by not charging 
        the jury on voluntary manslaughter.Â  Therefore Childersâ€™ convictions for 
        ABHAN and discharging a firearm into a dwelling are AFFIRMED, and 
        his conviction for murder is REVERSED and REMANDED.
       AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
      ANDERSON AND BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  The victimâ€™s sister disputes this, testifying that the victim was 
    living with her mother until she could evict Childers from her home.Â  

 
   
    [2]  At trial, Childers never requested defense counsel be relieved because 
    of counselâ€™s past legal representation of the victimâ€™s brother. Â Rather, Childersâ€™ 
    complaint about defense counsel stemmed from counselâ€™s prior prosecution of 
    him and his perception that counsel had not met with him frequently enough 
    prior to trial.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Carol Hunting, as Guardian ad Litem for Catherine L. Hitchcock,
Respondent,
v.
William Elders, Samuel Chris Gordon and Elmyer Enterprises, Inc.,
Defendants
of whom William Elders is, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3778
Heard October 8, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  19, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
D. Mark Stokes, of N. Charleston, for Appellant.
Geoffrey H. Waggoner, Richard S. Rosen, and Alex B. Cash, 
  all of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  This action was commenced 
  to recover damages sustained by Catherine L. Hitchcock in an accident caused 
  by a drunk driver.Â  Carol Hunting, as guardian ad litem for Hitchcock, brought 
  suit against Chris Gordon as the drunk driver, Elmyer Enterprises, Inc. as the 
  owner and operator of the bar, and William Elders as the alter ego of the corporation.Â  
  In the first portion of the bifurcated trial, damages of $1.5 million were awarded 
  against Gordon and Elmyer Enterprises. Â The second phase of the trial, 
  which is the subject of this appeal, resulted in a holding that Elders was the 
  alter ego of Elmyer Enterprises, justifying piercing the corporate veil, thereby 
  holding Elders personally liable for the $1.5 million verdict and the interest 
  which had accrued from the date of the original judgment against the corporation.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTS
We discern the following facts from the order of 
  the unappealed first phase of the trial.Â  Gordon became intoxicated while at 
  Willieâ€™s, a bar operated by Elmyer Enterprises.Â  Gordon was served alcohol despite 
  being obviously intoxicated.Â  After leaving the bar in an intoxicated state, 
  he caused the accident in which Hitchcock was left permanently brain damaged.Â  
  Hunting was awarded $1.5 million in actual damages against Gordon and Elmyer 
  Enterprises.Â  The jury also awarded $3,000 and $25,000 in punitive damages against 
  Gordon and Elmyer Enterprises respectively.Â  Subsequently, a non-jury trial 
  was held on the issue of whether to pierce the corporate veil of Elmyer Enterprises 
  and hold Elders liable for the judgment as its alter ego.Â  
The facts as gleaned from the second trial reveal that Elmyer 
  Enterprises was originally incorporated in 1981 and engaged in the business 
  of selling tires.Â  Elders and another shareholder operated the business until 
  Elders bought out the other shareholder.Â  The business then became inactive 
  for several years.Â  
In 1990, Elders opened two bars on property 
  he owned.Â  He originally held the liquor licenses in his own name.Â  In 1993, 
  he reinstated Elmyer Enterprises for the purpose of operating the bars.Â  Each 
  bar was capitalized with $1,000, which was deposited into separate bank accounts.Â  
  The property and equipment used to operate the bars were leased to Elmyer Enterprises 
  by other businesses formed and owned by Elders.Â  Both bars operated video poker 
  machines, which were leased from yet another of Eldersâ€™ business corporations.Â  
  That particular enterprise owned many more machines than were present in the 
  bars belonging to Elmyer Enterprises.Â  
In December 1993, Elders transferred several 
  shares of stock in Elmyer Enterprises to his wife and niece.Â  He designated 
  his wife as a vice president and his niece as secretary and treasurer.Â  However, 
  his niece testified that she knew nothing about her ownership of shares of stock 
  of Elmyer Enterprises or her selection as an officer of the company.Â  Minutes 
  were recorded that detailed the selections and the stock transfers.Â  
During the trial, Hunting presented the 
  testimony of Jan Waring-Woods, a forensic accountant, who testified money was 
  siphoned from the corporation for Eldersâ€™ personal use.Â  She testified many 
  records needed for an accurate audit of the corporation were either not created 
  or not made available at the time of trial.Â  After reviewing the corporate tax 
  returns for the various companies Elders owned, as well as some of the records 
  she managed to locate regarding the income of the business, she testified Elders 
  siphoned off between $400,000 and $800,000 from the business over a three-year 
  period.Â  Additionally, she testified some of Eldersâ€™ personal tax forms were 
  altered prior to trial to eliminate information about dividend income from investment 
  accounts Elders held during the time he ran the business.Â  
Hunting also presented testimony from 
  John Freeman, a law professor at the University of South Carolina.Â  He testified 
  that in his opinion the company was operated as a facade by Elders. Â Freeman 
  maintained Elmyer Enterprises was grossly undercapitalized given its purpose 
  of operating bars and considering the inherent risks associated with a business 
  dispensing alcohol.Â  His conclusion was that Elmyer Enterprises had income that 
  was unaccounted for and profit that was not adequately revealed.Â  He further 
  testified that, in his opinion, Elders was the alter ego of Elmyer Enterprises. 
  Â 
Elders testified the income was as reported.Â  
  He claimed detailed records were never kept by the company.Â  He noted that any 
  discrepancies in the records were the result of the way in which the bar was 
  managed.Â  He also argued the business was run as a statutory close corporation 
  and as an S corporation.Â  Therefore, it did not have to meet the normal business 
  formalities and would likely mirror Elders as the majority shareholder.Â  Elders 
  claimed the business met its ongoing financial obligations and therefore was 
  not undercapitalized.Â  
The trial court found Eldersâ€™ testimony 
  was not credible, and the evidence presented at trial clearly indicated Elmyer 
  Enterprises was operated as a mere facade for Elders.Â  Thus, the court concluded 
  Hunting met the burden of proof in establishing the factors necessary to pierce 
  the corporate veil and hold Elders personally liable for the judgment originally 
  awarded against Elmyer Enterprises.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action to pierce the corporate veil 
  lies in equity, and therefore, this court may determine the facts according 
  to its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  See C.T. Lowndes 
  & Co. v. Suburban Gas & Appliance Co., 307 S.C. 394, 396, 415 S.E.2d 
  404, 405 (Ct. App. 1991); Sturkie v. Sifly, 280 S.C. 453, 456-57, 313 
  S.E.2d 316, 318 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  The broad scope of review applicable to appeals 
  in equity actions does not, however, require an appellate court to disregard 
  the findings below or ignore the fact that the trial judge is in the better 
  position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Pinckney v. Warren, 
  344 S.C. 382, 387, 544 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2001).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Elders contends the trial court erred in piercing 
  the corporate veil of Elmyer Enterprises and therefore holding him personally 
  liable for the judgment.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œAt the outset, it is recognized that a corporation 
  is an entity, separate and distinct from its officers and stockholders, and 
  that its debts are not the individual indebtedness of its stockholders.â€Â  DeWitt 
  Truck Brokers, Inc. v. W. Ray Flemming Fruit Co., 540 F.2d 681, 683 (4th 
  Cir. 1976).Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court has ruled that the corporate entity 
  may be disregarded in certain situations.Â  See Baker v. Equitable 
  Leasing Corp., 275 S.C. 359, 271 S.E.2d 596 (1980).Â  â€œHowever, â€˜piercing 
  the corporate veilâ€™ is not a doctrine to be applied without substantial reflection.â€Â  
  Baker, 275 S.C. at 367, 271 S.E.2d at 600.Â  â€œThe corporate form may be 
  disregarded only where equity requires the action to assist a third party.â€Â  
  Woodside v. Woodside, 290 S.C. 366, 370, 350 S.E.2d 407, 410 (Ct. App. 
  1986).Â  The party asserting the corporate veil should be pierced has the burden 
  of proof.Â  Id.
Generally, courts are reluctant to â€œdisregard the integrity 
  of the corporate entity.â€Â  Sturkie, 280 S.C. at 459, 313 S.E.2d at 319.Â Â  


If any general rule can be laid down, it is that a corporation 
  will be looked upon as a legal entity until sufficient reason to the contrary 
  appears; but when the notion of legal entity is used to protect fraud, justify 
  wrong, or defeat public policy, the law will regard the corporation as an association 
  of persons.Â  

Id. at 457, 313 S.E.2d at 318.
In Sturkie, this court set forth 
  a two-pronged test to be used to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil.Â  
  â€œThe first part of the test, an eight-factor analysis, looks to observance of 
  the corporate formalities by the dominant shareholders.Â  The second part requires 
  that there be an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness if the acts 
  of the corporation be not regarded as the acts of the individuals.â€Â  Id. 
  at 457-58, 313 S.E.2d at 318.Â  The first eight factors were delineated in Dumas 
  v. InfoSafe Corp., 320 S.C. 188, 463 S.E.2d 641 (Ct. App. 1995):

  
    
      
        (1)
         whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized;
      
      
        (2) 
         failure to observe corporate formalities;
      
      
        (3) 
         non-payment of dividends;
      
      
        (4)
         insolvency of the debtor corporation 
  at the time;
      
      
        (5)
         siphoning of funds of the corporation by the dominant 
  stockholder;
      
      
        (6)  
         non-functioning of other officers 
  or other directors;
      
      
        (7)  
         absence of corporate records;Â  and
      
      
        (8)
         the fact that the corporation was merely a facade 
  for the operations of the dominant stockholder.
      
    
  

Dumas, 320 S.C. at 192, 463 S.E.2d at 644.Â 
â€œThe conclusion to disregard the corporate entity must involve a number of the 
  eight factors, but need not involve them all.â€Â  Id. (citing Cumberland 
  Wood Prods. v. Bennett, 308 S.C. 268, 417 S.E.2d 617 (Ct. App. 1992)).Â  
  There is a second prong contained in Sturkie, but it need not be reached 
  until and unless the requirements of the first prong are met.Â  
Neither Sturkie nor any other case 
  cited by the parties has set forth the weight that must be accorded to each 
  of the eight factors, nor has any case required that each factor be accorded 
  equal weight with the others.Â  Additionally, in applying the eight-factor test 
  of the first prong set out in Sturkie, significant changes in basic South 
  Carolina corporate law and federal and state tax law have somewhat complicated 
  the analysis.Â  The ability under state corporate law to adopt and operate under 
  a statutory close corporation status has, as a practical matter, diminished 
  the importance of several of the eight factors.Â  In the same fashion, the ability 
  of corporations to avoid double taxation by adopting S corporation status under 
  federal income tax law has lessened the importance of applying the factor concerning 
  the nonpayment of dividends.Â  
The Sturkie factors which now have 
  less importance include the failure to observe corporate formalities, nonfunctioning 
  of other officers or other directors, the absence of corporate records and, 
  as stated above, the nonpayment of dividends.Â  The adoption of the statutory 
  device allowing the creation of a statutory close corporation was designed to 
  lessen the formalities necessary to maintain a corporation.Â  A statutory close 
  corporation may operate without a board of directors, 
  [1]  need not adopt bylaws under certain circumstances, 
  [2]  and need not hold an annual meeting unless pursuant to a shareholder 
  request. [3] Â  The failure to 
  observe the formality â€œis not a ground for imposing personal liability on the 
  shareholders for liabilities of the corporation.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-18-250 
  (1990).Â  Indeed, the official comment to section 33-18-250 notes â€œthe purpose 
  of this section is to eliminate the possible argument that the shareholders 
  in a statutory close corporation are individually liable for the debts and torts 
  of the business because the corporation did not follow the classical model of 
  a corporation.â€Â  The comment continues:

This section does not prevent a court from â€œpiercing the 
  corporate veilâ€ of a statutory close corporation if the circumstances should 
  justify imposing personal liability on the shareholders were the corporation 
  not a statutory close corporation.Â  It merely prevents a court from â€œpiercing 
  the corporate veilâ€ because it is a statutory close corporation.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-18-250 cmt. (1990).Â  
The advent of the statutory close corporation has 
  also had an impact on the type and extent of corporate records required to be 
  maintained and the number and duties of corporate officers and directors.Â  Elders 
  asserts he maintained all necessary corporate records and there were always 
  officers of the corporation.Â  
Although Elders maintained a bare minimum of corporate 
  records, normal business records were definitely lacking in sufficiency.Â  The 
  corporation did not have adequate records of income from the video poker machines 
  or from the operation of the bars.Â  It did not have records of cash receipts, 
  cash expenses, sales, inventory, or other profit and loss statements that normally 
  would be expected.Â  
In the same fashion, although the corporate minutes 
  indicated the election of officers, Eldersâ€™ niece, who served as secretary-treasurer, 
  stated she did not know she was an officer in the corporation.Â  Elders produced 
  minutes indicating that his wife and niece were present during meetings.Â  However, 
  the niece testified she never attended any corporate meetings. 
Admittedly, Elmyer Enterprises was not required 
  to follow the same corporate formalities as a regular business corporation.Â  
  Although the failure to adhere to these formalities alone cannot be used to 
  pierce the corporate veil, coupling the dearth of corporate business records 
  and the inactivity of other corporate officers with the evidence of substantial 
  siphoning of funds provides evidence upon which the trial court, at least in 
  part, based its decision.
As to the factor concerning the payment or nonpayment of 
  dividends, its importance in the overall scheme of things has been diminished 
  by the election now allowed by federal tax law.Â  Elders asserts that because 
  the corporation elected to operate as an S corporation pursuant to 26 U.S.C. 
  Â§Â§ 1361-1399 (2002), the failure to pay dividends should not be considered a 
  factor against it in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil.Â  We agree, 
  because the net income of the corporation would be passed to the shareholders 
  in direct proportion to their ownership percentage.Â  However, at the same time, 
  this lessens the importance of this factor.Â  
The corporation was originally funded with only 
  $2,000, which represented $1,000 for each of the two operating locations.Â  Elders 
  asserts that the corporation was properly capitalized at all times, even though 
  the capitalization never appeared to increase over time.Â  
â€œOne fact which all the authorities consider significant 
  in the inquiry, and particularly so in the case of the one-man or closely-held 
  corporation, is whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized for the 
  purposes of the corporate undertaking.â€Â  See Dewitt, 540 F.2d 
  at 685.Â  The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals continued:Â  â€œ(t)he obligation to 
  provide adequate capital begins with incorporation and is a continuing obligation 
  thereafter * * * during the corporationâ€™s operations.â€Â  Id. (quoting 
  Gillespie, The Thin Corporate Line: Loss of Limited Liability Protection, 
  45 N.D. L. Rev. 363, 377-8 (1969)).Â  â€œAn obvious inadequacy of capital, measured 
  by the nature and magnitude of the corporate undertaking, has frequently been 
  an important factor in cases denying stockholders their defense of limited liability.â€Â  
  Anderson v. Abbott, 321 U.S. 349, 362 (1944).
The corporationâ€™s initial funding was 
  minimal at best.Â  However, as an ongoing concern, the corporation was not properly 
  capitalized.Â  The corporation appeared to have a sufficient cash flow from the 
  bar as well as the video poker machines to continue experiencing growth throughout 
  the life of the corporation.Â  However, no evidence was produced showing that 
  that growth was ever reflected in the corporationâ€™s capital account.Â  
Additionally, as Professor Freeman testified, 
  a corporation established for the purpose of serving alcohol has more inherent 
  risks and should be adequately protected from liability associated with those 
  risks.Â  The failure to properly protect the business and others should be considered 
  when determining whether the corporation is properly capitalized.Â  Accordingly, 
  we hold Elmyer Enterprises failed to remain properly capitalized as an ongoing 
  business.
The factors dealing with undercapitalization, siphoning 
  of funds, and whether the corporation was a facade for its dominant shareholder 
  are closely related.Â  The trial court found Elders siphoned substantial funds 
  from the corporation, and the evidence substantiates this finding.Â  Using documents 
  from the corporation, the forensic accountant testified there was a significant 
  amount of income not reported, and she determined that Elders siphoned $400,000 
  to $800,000 from Elmyer Enterprises over a three-year period. Â Even though 
  the corporation was able to pay its debts and thereby escape the classical definition 
  of insolvency, the evidence indicates that Elders left in the till only so much 
  as was necessary to pay basic expenses.Â  
The trial court found Elders lacked credibility 
  in his explanations for the difference in the income and what was reported.Â  
  The court specifically found the money was never accounted for and must have 
  been siphoned by Elders.Â  This is additional evidence that the corporation was 
  used as a mere facade for the benefit of the dominant shareholder, justifying 
  the ultimate conclusion reached by the trial court.
We therefore agree with the trial court that a 
  sufficient number of the eight Sturkie factors were present to justify 
  moving to the second prong of the analysis.Â  
The second prong of the Sturkie test, requiring 
  â€œthat there be an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness if the acts 
  of the corporation be not regarded as the acts of the individuals,â€Â  Sturkie, 
  280 S.C. at 457-458, 313 S.E.2d at 318, is perhaps more elusive.Â  In Sturkie, 
  the court stated:Â  

The burden of proving fundamental unfairness requires that 
  the plaintiff establish (1) that the defendant was aware of the plaintiffâ€™s 
  claim against the corporation, and (2) thereafter, the defendant acted in a 
  self-serving manner with regard to the property of the corporation and in disregard 
  of the plaintiffâ€™s claim in the property.Â  

Id. at 459, 313 S.E.2d at 319.Â  Later cases 
  clarified the actual knowledge requirement by stating that a person is â€œawareâ€ 
  of a claim against the corporation if he has notice of facts which, if pursued 
  with due diligence, would lead to knowledge of the claim.Â  Multimedia Publâ€™g 
  of South Carolina, Inc. v. Mullins, 314 S.C. 551, 554, 431 S.E.2d 569, 572 
  (1993).Â  Most recently this court has held that â€œthe essence of the fairness 
  test is simply that an individual businessman cannot be allowed to hide from 
  the normal consequences of carefree entrepreneuring by doing so through a corporate 
  shell.â€Â  Dumas, 320 S.C. at 193, 436 S.E.2d at 644.Â  
There is evidence that indicates Elders 
  knew of the plaintiffâ€™s claim against the corporation and that, as the trial 
  court found, he nevertheless acted in a self-serving and unfair manner by siphoning 
  off substantial sums of money, commingling and transferring assets which he 
  held in his own name to different entities, transferring stock in the corporation 
  to other individuals without a valuable consideration, and then finally dissolving 
  the corporation.Â  
Elders submits there is no evidence he 
  intended to avoid the normal consequences of his entrepreneurial adventures.Â  
  However, the â€œnormalâ€ consequences of operating a bar which, at least in this 
  instance, admittedly served alcohol to an already-intoxicated individual, transcends 
  that which would be considered normal consequences for the average entrepreneurial 
  endeavor.
Finally, Elders submits that even if the 
  corporate veil of Elmyer is pierced and he is held individually liable, he should 
  not be responsible for the interest that has so far accrued on the debt against 
  the corporation.Â  We disagree.Â  
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(B) (Supp. 2003) states 
  that money decrees and judgments of courts enrolled or entered shall draw interest.Â  
  â€œ[A] claimant is entitled to interest from the date of the rendition of the 
  verdict, or post-judgment interest, as a matter of course.â€Â  Calhoun v. Calhoun, 
  339 S.C. 96, 102, 529 S.E.2d 14, 18 (2000).Â  â€œThe running of post-judgment interest 
  further encourages judgment debtors to pay judgments promptly.â€Â  Casey v. 
  Casey, 311 S.C. 243, 245, 428 S.E.2d 714, 716 (1993).
In general, a corporation and a shareholder are 
  separate and distinct, and the debts of the corporation are not the debts of 
  the shareholder.Â  However, when the corporate veil is pierced, the corporation 
  and the individual become one and the same.Â  See Dewitt, 540 F.2d 
  at 683.Â  As they are identical, the liabilities of the corporation are the liabilities 
  of the shareholder.Â  This would include the judgment awarded against the corporation 
  as well as post-judgment interest from the time of the original judgment against 
  the corporation.Â  If post-judgment interest were not included, there would be 
  no penalty for failing to pay until after a subsequent trial regarding piercing 
  the corporate veil.Â  Accordingly, Elders should be held responsible for the 
  post-judgment interest attributable to the corporation.
 AFFIRMED.
 HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-18-210(a) (1990).

 
   [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-18-220(a) (1990).

 
   [3]
   Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-18-230(b) (1990).

STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Home Port Rentals, Inc., Appellant,
v.
Roger Moore, Respondent.
      
    
  


 
Appeal From Charleston County
Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3779
Heard December 10, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  19, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
M. Dawes Cooke, Jr., and Phillip 
  S. Ferderigos, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
Thomas W. Bunch, II, and L. Jefferson Davis, IV, both of Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Home Port Rentals, 
  Inc. brought this declaratory judgment action in July 2000 against Roger Moore, 
  seeking to determine the enforceability of a March 20, 1989 judgment.Â  The circuit 
  court granted Mooreâ€™s motion for summary judgment, finding the judgment was 
  more than ten years old and no longer enforceable.Â  We affirm and hold that 
  the ten-year enforcement period for execution on judgments as provided in S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 15-39-30 (Supp. 2003), once commenced, is absolute and not subject 
  to tolling.Â  Such a judgment is â€œutterly extinguishedâ€ ten years from the date 
  of its entry.
FACTS
Home Port obtained a judgment against 
  Moore on March 20, 1989, in the United States District Court of South Carolina.Â  
  During portions of the ten-year period following entry of the March 20, 1989 
  judgment, Home Port undertook efforts to locate Moore.Â  These sporadic efforts 
  were unsuccessful until Moore was located in Bossier City, Louisiana, in January 
  of 1999. Home Port then filed an action on March 17, 1999 to register the judgment 
  in the United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana.Â  
  Home Port filed the present declaratory action in the circuit court on July 
  14, 2000, seeking a determination of its ability to enforce the judgment in 
  South Carolina after the expiration of the ten-year statutory enforcement period.Â Â Â  
  Moore answered, asserting the judgment was no longer valid as the ten-year enforcement 
  period had expired.Â  
The parties filed cross-motions for summary 
  judgment, claiming the only issue for the court to decide was whether the ten-year 
  enforcement period was tolled while Moore was absent from South Carolina.Â  The 
  circuit court granted Mooreâ€™s motion for summary judgment, finding the ten-year 
  time for enforcement was absolute and not tolled during the period ofÂ  Mooreâ€™s 
  absence from South Carolina.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Home Port asserts the circuit court erred 
  in granting summary judgment to Moore.Â  Home Port argues that while S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 15-39-30 places a ten-year statute of limitations on the execution of 
  a judgment, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-30 (Supp. 2003) should operate to toll the 
  expiration of the enforcement period.Â  We disagree and find summary judgment 
  was warranted as the judgment was extinguished ten years from March 20, 1989, 
  the date of its entry.
We begin our analysis with the March 20, 1989 judgment 
  that Home Port obtained against Moore in the United States District Court for 
  the District of South Carolina.Â  South Carolina has adopted the Uniform Enforcement 
  of Foreign Judgments Act (UEFJA), which is codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-35-900 
  et seq. (1976).Â  Pursuant to section 15-35-910(1), a â€œâ€˜[f]oreign 
  [j]udgmentâ€™ means a judgment, decree, or order of a court of the United States 
  . . . which is entitled to full faith and credit . . . .â€Â  The 1989 federal 
  court judgment is a â€œforeign judgment.â€Â  UEFJA is consistent with the federal 
  statute governing enforcement of judgments rendered in federal courts.Â  28 U.S.C.A. 
  Â§ 1962 provides in part:

Every judgment rendered by a district court within a State 
  shall be a lien on the property located in such State in the same manner, 
  to the same extent and under the same conditions as a judgment of a court of 
  general jurisdiction in such State, and shall cease to be a lien in the same 
  manner and time.Â  

(emphasis added).
Federal law thus incorporates the law of the applicable State 
  in determining the effective date of the judgment lien, as well as its expiration.Â  
  In this regard, Home Port acknowledges that a â€œjudgment creditor . . . [has] 
  ten years from entry of a â€˜foreign judgmentâ€™ of a United States District Court 
  of South Carolina to enroll such judgment in a South Carolina county . . . . 
  Thus, the judgment in question is in practical effect a South Carolina judgment, 
  even though it is, paradoxically, a â€˜foreign judgmentâ€™ under UEFJA.â€Â  In essence, 
  as mandated by federal law, the judgment rendered in the United States District 
  Court for the District of South Carolina on March 20, 1989 became a South Carolina 
  judgment for enforcement purposes on the same date.Â  We must therefore resort 
  to South Carolina law, section 15-39-30 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2003), 
  to determine the extent, if any, of Home Portâ€™s continuing right to execute 
  on this judgment in South Carolina. 
  [1] Â Â Â  
â€œA judgment represents a judicial declaration that 
  a judgment debtor is personally indebted to a judgment creditor for a sum of 
  money.â€Â  Wells v. Sutton, 299 S.C. 19, 22, 382 S.E.2d 14, 16 (Ct. App. 
  1989) (citing Ducker v. Standard Supply Co., Inc., 280 S.C. 157, 311 
  S.E.2d 728 (1984)).Â Â  Pursuant to section 15-39-30:

Executions may issue upon final judgments or decrees at any 
  time within ten years from the date of the original entry thereof and shall 
  have active energy during such period, without any renewal or renewals thereof, 
  and this whether any return may or may not have been made during such period 
  on such executions.

The South Carolina Supreme Court has concluded 
  that a judgment is â€œutterly extinguish[ed] . . . after the expiration of ten 
  years from the date of entry.â€Â  Hardee v. Lynch, 212 S.C. 6, 17, 46 S.E.2d 
  179, 183 (1948); see also Garrison v. Owens, 258 S.C. 442, 446-47, 
  189 S.E.2d 31, 33 (1972) (stating that â€œ[a] judgment lien is purely statutory[;] 
  its duration as fixed by the legislature may not be prolonged by the courts 
  and the bringing of an action to enforce the lien will not preserve it beyond 
  the time fixed by the statute, if such time expires before the action is tried.â€).Â  

In Wells, 299 S.C. at 22, 382 S.E.2d 
  at 16, this court stated:

Executions may be issued within ten years from the date of 
  the original entry of the judgment.Â  â€œThe execution is [the] only process to 
  enforce the judgment, and it cannot have active energy unless the underlying 
  judgment has a lien.â€Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court has indicated a judgment 
  is utterly extinguished after the expiration of ten years from the date of entry.Â Â  


(citations omitted).Â  In its conclusion, this court 
  held:

[T]his court emphasizes it does not condone efforts by judgment 
  debtors to secrete assets to avoid payment of judgments . . . . The reason for 
  our holding is simply our recognition of the public policy of this State as 
  expressed in the statutes to limit the life of judgments to ten years.Â  A judgment 
  creditor should recognize this policy and proceed expeditiously to conclude 
  his efforts to collect his judgment within the ten year period.

Id.
Home Port contends the enforcement period 
  should be tolled at some undefined point prior to its expiration while Moore 
  was absent from South Carolina.Â  According to Home Port, section 15-3-30 provides 
  for tolling here.Â  Specifically, section 15-3-30 provides as follows:

If when a cause of action shall accrue against any person 
  he shall be out of the State, such action may be commenced within the terms 
  in this chapter respectively limited after the return of such person into this 
  State.Â  And if, after such cause of action shall have accrued, such person shall 
  depart from and reside out of this State or remain continuously absent therefrom 
  for the space of one year or more, the time of his absence shall not be deemed 
  or taken as any part of the time limited for the commencement of such action.

Home Port cites Commercial Credit Loans, Inc. 
  v. Riddle, 334 S.C. 176, 512 S.E.2d 123 (Ct. App. 1999), arguing it establishes 
  that the ten-year enforcement period may be interrupted and tolled if a party 
  can demonstrate that the judgment debtor was out of the state and unavailable.Â  
  We reject Home Portâ€™s reading of Commercial Credit.Â  Commercial Credit 
  obtained a default judgment in Illinois on May 27, 1986 and subsequently brought 
  an action in South Carolina to domesticate the foreign judgment.Â  The judgment 
  was enrolled in the Book of Abstracts for Newberry County on February 21, 1989.Â  
  The dispute in Commercial Credit focused on determining the commencement 
  date of the enforcement period in South Carolina in accordance with section 
  15-39-30.Â  In the trial court, the special referee found the commencement of 
  the South Carolina enforcement period related back to the date of entry of the 
  judgment in Illinois, a position which this court rejected:

Our state courts have held that a judgment is extinguished 
  ten years from the date of entry.Â  The institution of an action to domesticate 
  a foreign judgment specifically contemplates that a South Carolina judgment 
  will be issued by a South Carolina court.Â  At that point, pursuant to section 
  15-35-810, this South Carolina judgment may then be abstracted and indexed so 
  as to constitute a lien upon the debtorâ€™s real property for a period of ten 
  years.Â  It logically follows that section 15-39-30 also deals with the date 
  of original entry of the South Carolina judgment which may then be executed 
  upon for a period of ten years.Â  In the context of this case, the Illinois judgment 
  was transmuted into a South Carolina judgment when it was domesticated and the 
  judgment duly enrolled on February 21, 1989.Â  Thus, both the ten year lien period 
  on real estate, and the ten year period for enforcement of the judgment began 
  on that date.Â  

Id. at 181-82, 512 S.E.2d at 126.Â  (citations 
  and footnote omitted).Â  
Here, pursuant to the mandate of 28 U.S.C.A. 
  Â§ 1962, the commencement of the ten-year enforcement period in South Carolina 
  is indisputably March 20, 1989.Â  Moreover, contrary to Home Portâ€™s assertion, 
  Commercial Credit does not hold that the enforcement period under section 
  15-39-30 may be tolled after it begins.Â  Indeed, Commercial Credit recognizes 
  â€œthe policy of this state to limit the life of a judgment to ten yearsâ€ and 
  further asserts the ten-year â€œenforcement period cannot be tolled.â€Â  Id. 
  at 185, 183, 512 S.E.2d at 128, 127.  
  [2] 
Home Port additionally cites a number 
  of cases which allow the tolling of a statute of limitations under a variety 
  of circumstances involving the application of the discovery rule 
  [3]  to a potential cause of action, but none applies the discovery rule 
  to delay or interrupt the running of the ten-year enforcement period in section 
  15-39-30 after entry of the judgment in South Carolina.Â  The public policy in 
  favor of extinguishment as set forth in Wells is much stronger than a 
  policy allowing the tolling of the enforcement period once it commences.Â  The 
  burden lies with the judgment creditor to know the policy of South Carolina 
  and to ensure collection on the judgment.Â  Wells, 299 S.C. at 22, 382 
  S.E.2d at 16.Â  The application of the discovery rule to â€œcauses of actionâ€ prejudgment 
  simply does not have the same efficacy postjudgment after the section 15-39-30 
  statutory enforcement period has commenced. [4]   
 CONCLUSION
We find, as many courts of this State before us, 
  that a judgment is â€œutterly extinguishedâ€ ten years from the date of its entry 
  and the ten-year enforcement period cannot be tolled.Â  See, e.g., 
  Garrison, 258 S.C. at 446-47, 189 S.E.2d at 33.Â  Such a holding honors 
  the clear legislative intent in section 15-39-30 precluding â€œany renewalâ€ beyond 
  the ten-year period of â€œactive energy.â€Â  Accordingly, since Home Portâ€™s judgment 
  was extinguished in South Carolina on March 20, 1999, the judgment of the circuit 
  court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HOWARD, J. concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The judgment has been registered in the United States District 
    Court for the Western District of Louisiana.Â  Moore unsuccessfully challenged 
    the entry and enforceability of the judgment in that court, including an appeal 
    to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.Â  Home Port 
    Rentals, Inc. v. The Intâ€™l Yachting Group, Inc., 252 F.3d 399 (5th Cir. 
    2001).Â  For purposes of the case before us, we note the partiesâ€™ position 
    in the Louisiana litigation.Â  Specifically, Home Port filed the enforcement 
    action in the United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana 
    on March 17, 1999, â€œthree days shy of the [judgmentâ€™s] tenth anniversary.â€Â  
    Id. at 402.Â Â  The federal appeals court recognized that on March 17, 
    1999, the judgment was still â€œliveâ€ under South Carolina law.Â  Id. 
    at 403.Â  This finding is consistent with the applicability of section 15-39-30 
    to the judgment rendered in the federal district court in South Carolina.Â  
    Our application of the ten-year enforcement period in section 15-39-30 to 
    this foreign judgment reflects the interplay between UEFJA, 28 U.S.C.A. Â§ 
    1962 and applicable State law.

 
   
    [2] Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Commercial Credit was decided prior to South Carolinaâ€™s 
    adoption of UEFJA.Â  UEFJA, however, does not alter the courtâ€™s analysis or 
    result in Commercial Credit.Â  Since Home Portâ€™s underlying foreign 
    judgment originated in a federal district court in South Carolina, 28 U.S.C.A. 
    Â§ 1962 requires a finding that the South Carolina enforcement period began 
    on March 20, 1989, the date the federal court judgment was rendered in South 
    Carolina.Â  As Home Port candidly acknowledges, its federal court judgment 
    â€œis in practical effect a South Carolina judgment.â€

 
   [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Under the discovery rule, â€œthe statute 
    of limitations begins to run from the date the injured party either knows 
    or should know, by the exercise of reasonable diligence, that a cause of action 
    exists for the wrongful conduct.â€Â Â Â  True v. Monteith, 327 S.C. 116, 
    119, 489 S.E.2d 615, 616 (1997).Â Â Â  

 
   
    [4] Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Home Port submitted an affidavit detailing various attempts 
    to locate Moore.Â  Close scrutiny of this affidavit reveals that Home Port 
    made little or no effort to locate Moore from 1993 through 1998.Â  In light 
    of our holding that tolling is not available to extend the ten-year enforcement 
    period, we need not determine the nature of Home Portâ€™s diligence throughout 
    the ten-year period.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Thomas E. Pope, as Solicitor, Sixteenth Judicial Circuit,
Appellant,
v.
Willie Edward Gordon, Jr., and Twenty-Five 
        Thousand Three Hundred Forty-One and 09/100â€™s (25,341.09) Dollars in U.S. 
        Currency; One 1984 GMC Pickup Truck; Two Motorola Cellular Phones (Serial 
        Numbers; SUF1857M and SUG1049B230L012QT16WF1); and One Hundred Twenty-Eight 
        & no/100s (128.00) Dollars in U.S. Currency, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John Buford Grier, Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3780
Submitted March 11, 2004 â€“ Filed April 
  19, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Kristie Hannah Jordan, of York, for Appellant.
Leland Bland Greeley, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CURETON, A.J.:Â  The State brought this civil 
  forfeiture action pursuant to section 44-53-520(a) of the South Carolina Code 
  of Laws. [1] Â  The 
  State appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order returning property to Willie Edward 
  Gordon, Jr. (â€œGordonâ€).Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
  [2] 
FACTS
This forfeiture action arose from the arrest of 
  Gordon in September of 1996 for trafficking in crack cocaine.Â Â  At the time 
  of his arrest, Gordon was the owner of Gordonâ€™s Car Cleaning Service, an unincorporated 
  business whose principal venture was the cleaning and detailing of automobiles 
  for car dealerships and individuals. 
Precipitating Gordonâ€™s 1996 arrest was an investigation 
  by agents with the Rock Hill Police Department (â€œDepartmentâ€).Â  In the early 
  part of 1994, agents received information from confidential informants that 
  Gordon was involved in selling crack cocaine.Â  Acting on its suspicions, the 
  Department conducted a controlled buy of illegal drugs from Gordon on January 
  27, 1994.Â  As a result, the Department obtained a search warrant on February 
  3, 1994, for Gordonâ€™s home and recovered crack cocaine and marijuana.Â  While 
  conducting an additional search on February 12, 1994, officers recovered crack 
  cocaine in a well house near Gordonâ€™s residence.Â  Gordon pleaded guilty 
  to possession of marijuana for the incident that occurred on February 3, 1994.
In September of 1996, the Department began another 
  investigation of Gordon following the arrest of a low-level crack dealer who 
  identified Gordon as her supplier.Â  She also identified another dealer, Tommy 
  Rhinehart (â€œRhinehartâ€).Â  On September 23, 1996, Rhinehart agreed to cooperate 
  with the Department after agents executed a search warrant at his residence 
  during which they recovered two bags of crack cocaine, each containing approximately 
  10 grams, and a pill bottle containing 1.8 grams. Â Rhinehart informed 
  the agents that Gordon had given him the drugs just prior to the search.Â  According 
  to Rhinehart, he retrieved the drugs from the door of Gordonâ€™s pickup truck 
  where Gordon indicated he had hidden them.
The next day, Rhinehart met with Gordon 
  to discuss future transactions.Â  During the course of the conversation, Rhinehart 
  told Gordon that he had â€œflushedâ€ the crack cocaine during the Departmentâ€™s 
  search of his residence.Â  On September 26, 1996, Gordon and his nephew, Spencer, 
  gave Rhinehart another bag of crack cocaine.Â  Spencer stayed with Rhinehart 
  while he sold some of the crack cocaine.Â  On September 27, 1996, Rhinehart met 
  with agents and turned over the proceeds from the sale and the remaining crack 
  cocaine.Â  At that time, the agents gave Rhinehart $500 in marked money to pay 
  Gordon for the crack cocaine that he had â€œfrontedâ€ him.Â  In a recorded conversation, 
  Rhinehart set up another transaction with Gordon.Â  Gordon indicated that he 
  needed to contact Spencer.Â  Rhinehart was then instructed to meet Spencer at 
  Gordonâ€™s car wash.Â  At the car wash, Spencer gave Rhinehart two bags of crack 
  cocaine, weighing 9.4 grams and 9.8 grams respectively, and collected $500 for 
  a previous transaction.Â  Rhinehart then left, met with the agents, and turned 
  over the crack cocaine.
On September 30, 1996, Rhinehart 
  paged Gordon to arrange a meeting time so that he could pay for the two additional 
  bags of crack cocaine.Â  The agents gave Rhinehart $1,000 in marked money and 
  equipped him with a surveillance wire.Â  Rhinehart met with Spencer at 
  a designated location.Â  He then gave Spencer the money received from the sale 
  of the crack cocaine that was purchased earlier from Gordon.Â  Spencer left and 
  told Rhinehart he would return with more crack cocaine.Â  Spencer met 
  Gordon, who was driving the pickup truck, at the car wash.Â  Spencer left the 
  car wash, drove to NationsBank, and made a deposit.Â  Shortly thereafter, agents 
  arrested Spencer and searched him.Â  The agents found a bank deposit receipt 
  for account number 790167308, the business account for Gordonâ€™s car wash.Â  The 
  balance of the account was $22,209.85, which included the deposit.
During the same time period, Gordon was arrested

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action for forfeiture of property is a civil 
  action at law.â€Â  City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t v. One (1) 1992 Blue Mazda Truck 
  (VIN # JM2UF1132N0294812), 330 S.C. 371, 373, 498 S.E.2d 894, 895 (Ct. App. 
  1998).Â  In a non-jury action at law, the trial judgeâ€™s findings of fact have 
  the same force and effect as a jury verdict unless he or she committed some 
  error of law leading to an erroneous conclusion or unless the evidence is reasonably 
  susceptible of the opposite conclusion only.Â  Hiott v. Guar. Natâ€™l Ins. Co., 
  329 S.C. 522, 528-29, 496 S.E.2d 417, 421 (Ct. App. 1997); see Townes Assocs. 
  v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976) (â€œIn 
  an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of 
  fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without 
  evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€).Â Â  
DISCUSSION
I.
A.
The State argues the circuit court erred 
  in returning the seized money to Gordon.Â  Specifically, the State contends the 
  court committed an error of law by requiring the State to â€œdirectly trace the 
  seized money to a specific drug transaction.â€Â  The State believes, in light 
  of the totality of the circumstances, it met its burden to establish probable 
  cause that the NationsBank accounts were used in furtherance of Gordonâ€™s drug 
  trafficking. [3] 
Based on our review of the courtâ€™s order, 
  we believe the court properly considered the requirements of the forfeiture 
  statute.Â  In its order, the court found â€œfor moneys taken, the State must present 
  evidence that the money is traceable to an exchange involving controlled substances.Â  
  The State presented no evidence whatsoever that the moneys in the account were 
  from drug transactions.â€Â  This holding is precisely what section 44-53-520(a)(7) 
  requires for a forfeiture of monies.
Section 44-53-520(a)(7) provides:

all property including, but not limited to, monies, 
  negotiable instruments, securities, or other things of value furnished or intended 
  to be furnished by any person in exchange for a controlled substance, and all 
  proceeds including, but not limited to, monies, and real and personal property 
  traceable to any [illegal drug] exchange.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-520(a)(7) (2002) (emphasis 
  added).Â  In order to analyze this case, we are faced with determining the exactness 
  required to prove whether the bank accounts are â€œtraceable to any exchange.â€Â  
  Thus, we must employ the rules of statutory construction.Â  
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is 
  to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€Â  Hawkins v. Bruno 
  Yacht Sales, Inc., 353 S.C. 31, 39, 577 S.E.2d 202, 207 (2003).Â  â€œAll rules 
  of statutory construction are subservient to the one that the legislative intent 
  must prevail if it reasonably can be discovered in the language used, and the 
  language must be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.â€Â  
  City of Sumter Police Depâ€™t, 330 S.C. at 375, 498 S.E.2d at 896.Â  If 
  a statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning â€œthe 
  rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right 
  to impose another meaning.â€Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 
  578, 581 (2000).Â Â Â  
An action for forfeiture is a civil in rem 
  action at law that is, by its nature, a penal action that must be strictly construed.Â  
  See Ducworth v. Neely, 319 S.C. 158, 162, 459 S.E.2d 896, 899 
  (Ct. App. 1995) (strictly construing the term â€œknowledgeâ€ to mean â€œactual knowledgeâ€).Â  
  Furthermore, â€œin rem forfeiture statutes must be interpreted in 
  light of the evil sought to be remedied and in a manner that is consistent with 
  the statuteâ€™s purpose.â€Â  Id. at 163, 459 S.E.2d at 899.Â  Accordingly, 
  we must apply a strict definition of the disputed text of the statute which 
  best fulfills the lawâ€™s purpose to remedy a particular evil.
â€œThe purpose of a forfeiture hearing 
  is to confirm that the state had probable cause to seize the property forfeited.â€Â  
  Medlock v. One 1985 Jeep Cherokee VIN 1JCWB782FT129001, 322 S.C. 127, 
  131, 470 S.E.2d 373, 376 (1996).Â  The State has the â€œinitial burden of demonstrating 
  â€˜probable cause for the belief that a substantial connection exists between 
  the property to be forfeited and the criminal activity defined by statute.â€™â€ 
  United States v. Thomas, 913 F.2d 1111, 1114 (4th Cir. 1990)(quoting 
  Boas v. Smith, 786 F.2d 605, 609 (4th Cir. 1986)).Â  â€œIf probable cause 
  is shown, the burden then shifts to the owner to prove that he or she â€˜was not 
  a consenting party to, or privy to, or did not have knowledge of, the use of 
  the property which made it subject to seizure and forfeiture.â€™â€ Medlock, 
  322 S.C. at 131, 470 S.E.2d at 376 (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-586(b)(1) 
  (Supp. 1994)).Â  â€œSection 44-53-586(b) specifically places the burden of proof 
  on the property owner to show innocent ownership by a preponderance of the evidence, 
  showing legislative intent to place the burden of proving innocence on the property 
  owner.â€ Id.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
â€œâ€˜Probable causeâ€™ for the purpose of 
  forfeiture proceedings is the same standard used in search and seizure cases.â€ 
  Thomas, 913 F.2d at 1114.Â  A determination of probable cause requires 
  the magistrate to analyze the totality of the circumstances, which means his 
  task is to â€œmake a practical, common- sense decision whether, given all the 
  circumstances set forth in the affidavit before him, including the â€˜veracityâ€™ 
  and â€˜basis of knowledgeâ€™ of persons supplying hearsay information, there is 
  a fair probability that contraband or evidence of a crime will be found in a 
  particular place.â€Â  State v. Weston, 329 S.C. 287, 290-91, 494 S.E.2d 
  801, 802-03 (1997) (quoting Illinois v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213, 238 (1983)); 
  State v. Martin, 347 S.C. 522, 527, 556 S.E.2d 706, 709 (Ct. App. 2001) 
  (â€œA â€˜totality of the circumstancesâ€™ test is applicable in determining whether 
  sufficient probable cause exists to issue a search warrant.â€).Â Â  
Because our research reveals no South 
  Carolina case that is directly on point, we agree with the State that federal 
  law is instructive in deciding this case.Â  In other forfeiture cases, our Supreme 
  Court and this Court have consistently turned to the guidance of the federal 
  courts, particularly decisions of the Fourth Circuit.Â  See, e.g., Medlock, 
  322 S.C. at 132, 470 S.E.2d at 377 (adopting â€œexcessive fine testâ€ set forth 
  by Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals in United States v. Chandler, 36 F.3d 
  358 (4th Cir. 1994), cert. denied, 514 U.S. 1082 (1995)); Condon v. 
  One 1985 BMW, 4 Door, VIN # WBAAE6403F0704170, 312 S.C. 431, 432, 440 S.E.2d 
  895, 896 (Ct. App. 1994)(applying Fourth Circuit cases to determine whether 
  seized vehicle facilitated the unlawful transportation of controlled substances 
  under sections 44-53-520(a)(4), (a)(6)).      
We are persuaded to consider United 
  States v. Thomas, 913 F.2d 1111 (4th Cir. 1990), a case where the Fourth 
  Circuit Court of Appeals interpreted a federal statute that is similar to our 
  state forfeiture statute. [4] 
  Â  The defendant in Thomas became the subject of a federal government 
  drug investigation.Â  In the course of the investigation, the officers conducted 
  undercover drug buys at the defendantâ€™s business in Georgetown, South Carolina.Â  
  Government officers also discovered Thomas had significant cash expenditures 
  and had â€œunusual travel habits,â€ which included numerous one-way airline tickets 
  from Charleston, South Carolina to Miami, Florida.Â  Ultimately, the investigation 
  was concluded when the Immigration and Naturalization Service arrested Thomas 
  for being an illegal alien.Â  Subsequently, the federal government seized certain 
  real and personal property that belonged to Thomas.Â  After a forfeiture hearing, 
  the district court ordered the return of the property to Thomas, finding the 
  government had not shown probable cause for its belief that there was a substantial 
  connection between the property to be forfeited and the illegal drug-related 
  activities.
On appeal, the Fourth Circuit Court of 
  Appeals reversed the district court, holding the totality of the facts demonstrated 
  probable cause.Â  Id. at 1117.Â  The Court believed the district court 
  took â€œtoo stringent a view of the legal standard involved in establishing probable 
  cause and too dismissive a view of its own factual findings.â€Â  Id. at 
  1115.Â  The Court characterized the district courtâ€™s analysis as â€œ[p]arsing evidence 
  in isolation for a fatal flawâ€ which would defeat a finding of probable cause.Â  
  In reaching this conclusion, the Court noted that â€œâ€˜[c]ircumstantial evidence 
  of drug transactions is sufficient to support the establishment of probable 
  cause in a forfeiture proceeding,â€™ without showing a â€˜direct connection between 
  the property subject to seizure and the illegal activity that renders the items 
  forfeitable.â€™â€ Id. at 1117 (quoting United States v. Edwards, 
  885 F.2d 377, 390 (7th Cir. 1989) and United States v. $93,685.61 in United 
  States Currency, 730 F.2d 571, 572 (9th Cir. 1984))(citations omitted).Â  
  As the factual basis for its decision, the Court emphasized that Thomas:Â  had 
  a criminal record involving drug activity; possessed unusually large amounts 
  of cash; made significant cash expenditures which vastly exceeded his legitimate 
  income; engaged in drug transactions at his business; and had unusual travel

  of illegal drug dealing to purchase the properties sought to be forfeited.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
With these principles in mind, we turn to the instant 
  case.Â  Although we disagree with the Stateâ€™s assessment that Thomas is 
  dispositive based on a comparison of the facts of the two cases, we believe 
  Thomas is instructive as to the â€œmethod of evidentiary assessmentâ€ regarding 
  the establishment of probable cause for forfeiture.Â  Id. at 1117.Â  Here, 
  the court properly weighed the evidence.Â  It considered the totality of the 
  circumstances and did not require the State to trace the money seized from the

  review, we cannot say the courtâ€™s holding that the State failed to establish 
  probable cause regarding the bank accounts is without support in the record 
  or that the evidence is â€œreasonably susceptible of the opposite conclusion only.â€Â  
  Hiott, 329 S.C. at 529, 496 S.E.2d at 421.Â  
Even though there is evidence that Gordon 
  was involved in illegal drug transactions and had significant cash expenditures, 
  this evidence did not rise above â€œmere suspicionâ€ that the bank proceeds were 
  subject to forfeiture.Â  See United States v. All Right, Title and 
  Interest in Real Property and Appurtenances Thereto Known as 785 St. Nicholas 
  Ave. and 789 St. Nicholas Ave., 983 F.2d 396, 403 (2d Cir. 1993) (â€œTo establish

  money from Gordonâ€™s car wash.Â  Furthermore, the State failed to show the withdrawals

  the testimony of Gordonâ€™s accountant did not establish that Gordon was â€œwashingâ€ 
  large amounts of undocumented money through the bank accounts.Â  Therefore, we 
  agree with the circuit court that the State failed to establish probable cause

  to the NationsBank accounts.
B.
Broadly construing the Stateâ€™s argument, 
  it appears the State is appealing the entire $25,341.09 amount that was seized,

II.
The State asserts the circuit court incorrectly 
  incorporated the excessive fines test into the probable cause determination.Â  

In Medlock v. One 1985 Jeep Cherokee VIN 1JCWB7828FT129001, 
  322 S.C. 127, 132, 470 S.E.2d 373, 377 (1996), our Supreme Court discussed the 
  application of the Excessive Fines Clause 
  [7]  to civil forfeiture cases.Â  In Medlock, the Court adopted 
  the Fourth Circuit Court of Appealsâ€™ three-part instrumentality test.Â  â€œUnder 
  this test, a court must examine (1) the nexus between the offense and the property 
  and the extent of the propertyâ€™s role in the offense, (2) the role and culpability 
  of the owner, and (3) the possibility of separating offending property that 
  can readily be separated from the remainder.â€Â  Id. at 132, 470 S.E.2d 
  at 377.Â Â  
We agree with the State that the circuit court 
  incorrectly referenced the excessive fines test.Â  Although not specifically 
  delineated as such in its order, the test was clearly a part of the courtâ€™s 
  analysis as shown by the listing of the three parts of the test.Â  This constituted 
  error.Â  Because the court did not confirm the forfeiture of the NationsBank 
  accounts, the excessive fines test was inapplicable.Â  See Austin v. 
  United States, 509 U.S. 602, 622 (1993) (holding forfeiture is subject to 
  the Excessive Fines Clause if the forfeiture can be viewed as punitive).
The courtâ€™s error in applying the test, however, does 
  not negate its ruling.Â  As previously discussed, the court properly considered 
  the requirements of the forfeiture statute and the Stateâ€™s burden to establish 
  probable cause for the forfeiture.Â  In light of our decision affirming the courtâ€™s 
  ultimate holding that the State failed to carry its burden to confirm the forfeiture, 
  we find the error was harmless.Â  Cf. State v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 
  191, 194, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990) (finding an error is harmless if it could 
  not reasonably have affected the result of the trial); Wells v. Halyard, 
  341 S.C. 234, 237, 533 S.E.2d 341, 343 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œAn alleged error is 
  harmless if the appellate court determines beyond a reasonable doubt that the 
  alleged error did not contribute to the verdict.â€).Â Â  
III.
The State argues the circuit court erred in finding 
  Gordonâ€™s pickup truck had not been used to facilitate the distribution or sale 
  of crack cocaine.Â  
Specifically, the State contends the truck was 
  properly seized pursuant to section 44-53-520(a)(4) or 44-53-520(a)(6).Â  See 
  Condon, 312 S.C. at 432, 440 S.E.2d at 896 (â€œProperty facilitates the

In its order, the court denied the forfeiture

  only served as â€œa location from where drugs were taken.â€Â  Secondly, the court

We find the court erred on

  the language of section 44-53-520(a)(6), the fact that the truck was used to

  conveyances including . . . motor vehicles . . . which are used or intended 
  for use unlawfully to conceal, contain, or transport or facilitate the unlawful

As to the second point, the State did offer evidence

  According to Rhinehart, he retrieved the drugs from the door of Gordonâ€™s pickup

Because our standard of review in forfeiture

    her Jeep constituted an excessive fine in violation of the Eighth Amendment 
    of the United States Constitution and Article I, Â§ 15 of the South Carolina 
    Constitution.Â  Medlock, 322 S.C. at 132, 470 S.E.2d at 377.

title: Nationwide Mutual Insurance v. Prioleau
description: This is an underinsured motorist coverage case involving the purchase by a spouse who rejected UIM coverage.  Nationwide appeals the trial court's ruling that a valid and effective offer of UIM coverage had not been made because (1) such an offer had been made to and rejected by the spouse as the named insured and applicant for the policy and (2) such an offer had been made to and rejected by the spouse as the agent for his wife.
