THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Nationwide Mutual Insurance 
          Company, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Julius Prioleau and Paula 
          Prioleau, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal 
  From Richland County
  Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion 
  No. 3781
  Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  April 26, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        Robert C. Brown, of Columbia, 
          for Appellant.
        Arthur Aiken and Howard Hammer, 
          of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HUFF, 
  J.:Â  Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company brought this declaratory judgment 
  action to determine whether Paula Prioleau was entitled to underinsured motorist 
  (UIM) coverage under her automobile insurance policy purchased from Nationwide.Â  
  The trial court found no meaningful offer of UIM coverage had been made to Paula, 
  and she was therefore entitled to have her policy reformed to include UIM coverage 
  up to the limits of the policy.Â  Nationwide appeals.Â  We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL 
  BACKGROUND
On April 
  25, 1997, Julius Prioleau applied for automobile insurance with Nationwide.Â  
  The application was completed in the names of â€œJulius and Paula Prioleau,â€ but 
  only Julius went to the insurance agency to apply for the insurance, and only 
  Julius signed as an applicant.Â  At the same time that Julius signed the application, 
  he was presented with an â€œOffer of Optional Additional Uninsured and Underinsured 
  Automobile Insurance Coveragesâ€ form.Â  This form described the available UIM 
  coverage and requested that Julius either accept or reject the additional coverage.Â  
  Julius alone signed the form, rejecting the UIM coverage.Â  The policy issued 
  by Nationwide, however, listed both â€œJulius and Paula Prioleauâ€ as the named 
  insureds. 
On February 
  3, 1998, Paula Prioleau was involved in an automobile accident while driving 
  one of the vehicles covered by the Prioleausâ€™ policy with Nationwide.Â  Paula 
  sustained bodily injuries as a result of the accident and made a claim against 
  the at-fault driverâ€™s insurance carrier.Â  The at-fault driverâ€™s insurance carrier 
  paid Paula the liability policy limits.Â  Paula then asserted an underinsured 
  motorist claim against Nationwide.Â  

  At trial, the parties presented the deposition testimony of both Paula and Julius, 
  as well as the in-court testimony of Paula.Â  In his deposition, Julius testified 
  that normally he and his wife handled the acquisition of insurance together, 
  and he could not remember why Paula did not accompany him when he obtained the 
  policy from Nationwide.Â  Paula testified by way of deposition that she did not 
  have anything to do with the acquisition of the Nationwide insurance policy, 
  and although she knew they had to obtain insurance, she did not know her husband 
  was going to get it that day.Â  She could not remember whether it was she or 
  her husband who handled getting their insurance in the two years between the 
  time they returned from Germany in 1995 until Julius acquired the Nationwide 
  policy in 1997.Â  In her testimony before the trial court, Paula stated that 
  Julius did not have authority from her to act as her agent in connection with 
  the application of insurance with Nationwide.Â  She admitted, however, that she 
  knew her husband was â€œgoing to get some insurance,â€ and she did not object to 
  him going and getting the insurance, â€œbecause [she] didnâ€™t know when he was 
  going.â€Â  
Nationwide 
  argued the rejection of UIM coverage form signed by Julius Prioleau was a valid 
  rejection under South Carolina law, and it was not required to also obtain the 
  signature of Paula rejecting UIM coverage, as Julius was the named insured and 
  the only applicant for the policy.Â  Alternatively, Nationwide claimed that the 
  form was sufficient because Julius was acting as the agent for his wife when 
  he obtained the insurance policy.Â  The trial court rejected both claims and 
  ordered the Prioleausâ€™ policy be reformed to include underinsured motorist coverage 
  up to the liability limits of the policy. 
Nationwide 
  appeals, arguing the trial court erred in ruling a valid and effective offer 
  of UIM coverage had not been made when (1) such an offer had been made to and 
  rejected by Julius Prioleau as the named insured and applicant for the policy 
  and (2) such an offer had been made to and rejected by Julius Prioleau as the 
  agent for his wife, Paula Prioleau.Â  Because we find Julius necessarily acted 
  as the agent for Paula, we reverse the trial court.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A suit 
  for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined by 
  the nature of the underlying issue.Â  Antley v. Nobel Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 
  621, 625, 567 S.E.2d 872, 874 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  As the underlying issue in the 
  present case involves determination of coverage under an insurance policy, the 
  action is at law.Â  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Calcutt, 340 S.C. 
  231, 237, 530 S.E.2d 896, 898 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In an action at law, tried without 
  a jury, the trial judgeâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed on appeal unless 
  a review of the record reveals there is no evidence which reasonably supports 
  the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Id.Â  â€œâ€˜When an appeal involves stipulated or undisputed 
  facts, an appellate court is free to review whether the trial court properly 
  applied the law to those facts.â€™Â  In such cases, the appellate court is not 
  required to defer to the trial courtâ€™s legal conclusions.â€Â  Allstate Ins. 
  Co. v. Estate of Hancock, 345 S.C. 81, 84, 545 S.E.2d 845, 846 (Ct. App. 
  2001) (quoting WDW Props. v. City of Sumter, 342 S.C. 6, 10, 535 S.E.2d 
  631, 632 (2000)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
In addressing the agency issue, the trial court found the facts of the case 
  did not support Nationwideâ€™s position that an agency relationship existed between 
  Paula and Julius.Â  In support of this finding, the court noted the uncontradicted 
  testimony of Paula that â€œshe was not aware of her husbandâ€™s intention to sign 
  the offer form and that she did not give her husband authority to act on her 
  behalf, in any way, in matters having to do with automobile insurance.â€Â  We 
  find the trial judge erred as a matter of law in finding the facts did not support 
  the existence of an agency relationship between Paula and Julius. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
It is 
  well-settled that the relationship of agency between a husband and wife is governed 
  by the same rules which apply to other agencies, and no presumption arises from 
  the mere fact of the marital relationship that one spouse is acting as agent 
  for the other.Â  Bankers Trust of South Carolina v. Bruce, 283 S.C. 408, 
  423, 323 S.E.2d 523, 532 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  However, the relationship of agency 
  need not depend upon express appointment and acceptance thereof.Â  Rather, an 
  agency relationship may be, and frequently is, implied or inferred from the 
  words and conduct of the parties and the circumstances of the particular case.Â  
  Id.Â  

  The law creates the relationship 
    of principal and agent if the parties, in the conduct of their affairs, actually 
    place themselves in such position as requires the relationship to be inferred 
    by the courts, and if, from the facts and circumstances of the particular 
    case, it appears that there was at least an implied intention to create it, 
    the relation may be held to exist, notwithstanding a denial by the alleged 
    principal, and whether or not the parties understood it to be an agency.

Crystal 
  Ice Co. of Columbia v. First Colonial Corp., 273 S.C. 306, 309, 257 S.E.2d 
  496, 497 (1979).
In her 
  testimony, Paula admitted she knew she and Julius had to obtain insurance and 
  that she knew her husband was â€œgoing to get some insurance,â€ even though she 
  did not know when he was going to get it or that he was getting it that particular 
  day.Â  While she stated her husband did not â€œhave authority from [her] to act 
  as [her] agent in connection with [the] applicationâ€ for insurance with Nationwide, 
  this testimony is nothing more than a denial of any express authority 
  given by Paula to Julius.Â  The law is clear, however, that the relationship 
  of agency need not depend upon express appointment and acceptance thereof, but 
  may be, and frequently is, implied by the words and conduct of the parties and 
  the circumstances of the particular case.Â  Indeed, the law creates the relationship 
  of principal and agent where the parties, in the conduct of their affairs, actually 
  place themselves in such position as requires the relationship to be inferred 
  by the courts.Â  Crystal Ice Co. of Columbia Corp., 273 S.C. at 309, 257 
  S.E.2d at 497.Â  
Here, 
  Paula and Julius, by their conduct, placed themselves in such a position as 
  required an agency relationship to be inferred by the courts, and the only reasonable 
  conclusion from the facts of this case is that an implied agency existed between 
  Paula and Julius.Â  Otherwise, Paula is repudiating the very contract under which 
  she seeks reformation.Â  As noted by the Appellate Court of Illinois in a similar 
  case, it would be inconsistent to allow a spouse under such facts to argue that

  (1) she was covered by the policy 
    procured exclusively by her husband but admittedly for her benefit;Â  (2) she 
    was entitled to recover from [the insurance company] under the terms of the 
    policy;Â  but (3) with respect to one aspect of the policy, her husband acted 
    without her authority and his decision cannot bind her.Â  To allow such an 
    argument would permit [the wife] to accept the benefit of the bargain her 
    husband made on her behalf but not the burden.

Messerly 
  v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 662 N.E.2d 148, 151 (Ill. 1996). 
CONCLUSION
While the evidence supports a finding 
  that no express agency relationship existed between Paula and her husband, 
  the facts clearly demonstrate an implied agency existed between the parties 
  for the purpose of acquiring the automobile insurance policy in question.Â  By 
  making a claim under the policy, Paula has essentially placed herself in such 
  a position that the court must infer an agency relationship.Â Â Â  Otherwise, no 
  policy would exist under which Paula could claim UIM coverage.Â  Accordingly, 
  the record reveals there is no evidence which reasonably supports the trial 
  courtâ€™s finding of the non-existence of an agency relationship between Paula 
  and her husband. [1] Â  The judgment 
  of the trial court is therefore
REVERSED.
  STILWELL, J. and CURETON, 
  A.J. concur.
   

 
   
    [1] It should be noted that the matter at issue here is the existence 
    of an agency relationship, not the scope.Â  Here, we are not dealing with a 
    situation where one person gives another only limited authority to act as 
    an agent in obtaining specific types and levels of coverage.Â  Accordingly, 
    this opinion does not imply blanket authority when a spouse is authorized 
    to act in some matter on behalf of the other, and it does not address the 
    issue of whether an agentâ€™s authority has been exceeded.

description: The South Carolina Department of Revenue appeals the trial court's award of attorney's fees to Video Gaming Consultant, Inc. pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Section 15-77-300 (Supp. 2003).

THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Video Gaming Consultants, 
          Inc., Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        South Carolina Department 
          of Revenue, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
  Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Special 
  Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3782
  Heard February 11, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  April 26, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        Carol I. McMahan, Nicholas 
          P. Sipe, Harry T. Cooper, Jr., of Columbia; for Appellant.
        H. Buck Cutts, of Surfside 
          Beach; for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, 
  J.:Â  After prevailing in underlying litigation against the South Carolina 
  Department of Revenue (Department), Video Gaming Consultants, Inc. (Video Gaming) 
  asked that it be awarded attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  The circuit court awarded $25,286.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The 
  Department appeals.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS
Video 
  Gaming operated a video gaming business in Garden City.Â  On July 27, 1995, the 
  Department issued Video Gaming a citation for violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  12-21-2804(b) (Supp. 1999) [1]  
  for advertising video games on its premises.Â  Video Gaming had displayed a large 
  sign stating â€œSTOP HERE TRY OUR POKER VIDEO GAMESâ€ and two signs stating â€œJACKPOT 
  VIDEO GAMES.â€
Video 
  Gaming appealed the citation to the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) Division, 
  contending that the Stateâ€™s prohibition against advertising violated the protection 
  of free speech afforded by the First Amendment and the relevant statute should 
  be declared void and unconstitutional.Â  The ALJ upheld the citation.Â  The Honorable 
  J. Stanton Cross, Jr., sitting as Special Circuit Court Judge, affirmed the 
  ALJ decision.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court reversed finding the statute 
  was an unconstitutional restriction on commercial speech. Video Gaming Consultants 
  v. S.C. Dept. of Revenue, 342 S.C. 34, 535 S.E.2d 642 (2000).Â  
After 
  the supreme court issued its opinion, Video Gaming filed a petition for attorneyâ€™s 
  fees pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 (Supp. 2003).Â  The case was heard 
  by Judge Cross.Â  He awarded Video Gaming $27,453.00 in fees.Â  In an amended 
  order, Judge Cross reduced the amount by $6,499.00 to correct a billing error 
  and also added $3,404.00 for fees incurred between May 2001 through September 
  2001 for a total award of $25,286.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD 
  OF REVIEW
On appeal, 
  the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding an award of attorneyâ€™s fees under S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 (Supp. 2003) will not be disturbed absent an abuse of 
  discretion.Â  Heath v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 182, 394 S.E.2d 
  709, 711 (1990).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision 
  is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  Zabinski 
  v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 601, 553 S.E.2d 110, 121 (2001).Â Â  
  
LAW/ANALYSIS 

 The Department argues 
  the trial court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Video Gaming.Â  We agree.
The prevailing 
  party to a civil action may recover attorneyâ€™s fees against a state agency only 
  if â€œthe agency acted without substantial justification in pressing its claim 
  against the partyâ€ and there are no â€œspecial circumstances that would make the 
  award of attorneyâ€™s fees unjust.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 (Supp. 2003).Â  
  Our supreme court held â€œsubstantial justificationâ€ does not mean â€œâ€˜justified 
  to a high degree,â€™ but rather â€˜justified in substance or in the mainâ€™-- that 
  is, justified to a degree that could satisfy a reasonable person.â€ Heath 
  v. County of Aiken, 302 S.C. 178, 183, 394 S.E.2d 709, 712 (1990) (quoting 
  Pierce v. Underwood, 487 U.S. 552, 565 (1988), which was applying the 
  federal Equal Access to Justice Act (EAJA), 28 U.S.C. Â§ 2412(d)(1)(A) (Supp. 
  2003) [2] ).Â  In deciding whether 
  a state agency acted with substantial justification, the courts look to the 
  agencyâ€™s position in litigating the case to determine â€œwhether it is one which 
  has a reasonable basis in law and fact.â€Â  McDowell v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. 
  Servs., 304 S.C. 539, 542, 405 S.E.2d 830, 832 (1991).Â  An agencyâ€™s loss 
  on the merits does not create a presumption that its position was not substantially 
  justified.Â  Kiareldeen v. Ashcroft, 273 F.3d 542, 554 (3rd 
  Cir. 2001); see Pierce, 487 U.S. at 569 (noting the government could 
  take a position that is substantially justified, yet lose).
In awarding 
  attorneyâ€™s fees to Video Gaming, Judge Cross stated the following:

  In further response to [the Departmentâ€™s] 
    Motion to Reconsider, I point out that [the Department] acted without substantial 
    justification when it continued to vigorously prosecute this case after the 
    United States Supreme Court handed down its decision in the 44 Liquormart 
    case [3]  in the summer 1996.Â  This decision was handed 
    down before the Administrative Law Judge decision was issued and substantially 
    undercut the legal analysis and argument of the state relative to both the 
    Reyelt [4]  and Posadas 
    [5]  decisions.Â Â Â  

The court 
  then explained that the Department had failed to meet its affirmative duty to 
  â€œdisclose to the ALJ Division Court and to this Court the impact and legal effect 
  of 44 Liquormart.â€Â  
We find 
  no evidence the Department acted without substantial justification in continuing 
  its action against Video Gaming after the United States Supreme Courtâ€™s decision 
  in 44 Liquormart.Â  Rule 3.3(a)(3) of the Rules of Professional Conduct, 
  Rule 407, SCACR, requires lawyers to disclose to the tribunal â€œlegal authority 
  in the controlling jurisdiction known to the lawyer to be directly adverse to 
  the position of the client and not disclosed by opposing counsel . . . â€Â  As 
  the comment to this section notes, â€œ[a] lawyer is not required to make a disinterested 
  exposition of the law, but must recognize the existence of pertinent legal authorities.â€Â  
  
Our review 
  of the record reveals no indication of the Department being less than forthcoming 
  with regard to the Courtâ€™s decision in 44 Liquormart.Â  The Department 
  did not fail to disclose the case to the tribunals in the underlying litigation.Â  
  The parties argued extensively about the proper interpretation of 44 Liquormart 
  during the ALJ hearing.Â  The circuit court likewise engaged in a substantial 
  discussion of the caseâ€™s impact in its order affirming the ALJ decision.Â  We 
  find no point at which the Department maintained a position that can be viewed 
  as disingenuous.Â  
Furthermore, 
  the Department was in no position to determine that 44 Liquormart had 
  rendered Section 12-21-2804 unconstitutional.Â  All statutes are presumed constitutional.Â  
  Davis v. County of Greenville, 322 S.C. 73, 77, 470 S.E.2d 94, 96 (1996).Â  
  As an administrative agency, the Department â€œmust follow the law as written 
  until its constitutionality is judicially determined; an agency has no authority 
  to pass on the constitutionality of a statute.â€Â  Beaufort County Bd. of Educ. 
  v. Lighthouse Charter Sch. Comm., 335 S.C. 230, 241, 516 S.E.2d 655, 660-61 
  (1999).Â  By continuing its action against Video Gaming, the Department was merely 
  enforcing Section 12-21-2804 as it was obligated to do until a proper court 
  determined the statute to be unconstitutional.Â  Thus, we find the Department 
  had a reasonable basis in law and fact for continuing its action against Video 
  Gaming. 
Accordingly, 
  we hold the trial court abused its discretion in determining the Department 
  acted without substantial justification in the underlying litigation.Â  The trial 
  courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant to Section 15-77-300 isÂ  
REVERSED
STILWELL,J. and CURETON, A.J., 
  concur.Â 
   

 
   
    [1] Â  This section provided, â€œNo person who maintains a place or premises 
    for the operation of machines licensed under Section 12-21-2720(A)(3) may 
    advertise in any manner for the playing of the machines.â€Â  It was repealed 
    by Act No. 125, Part I, Â§ 8, eff. July 1, 2000, 1999 S.C. Acts 1325.

 
   
    [2]  The EAJA provides that â€œa court shall award to a prevailing party 
    other than the United States fees and other expenses . . . incurred by that 
    party in any civil action (other than cases sounding in tort), including proceedings 
    for judicial review of agency action, brought by or against the United States 
    in any court having jurisdiction of that action, unless the court finds that 
    the position of the United States was substantially justified or that special 
    circumstances make an award unjust.â€Â  28 U.S.C. Â§ 2412(d)(1)(A) (Supp. 2003).

 
   [3]  44 Liquormart, Inc. v. Rhode Island, 517 
    U.S. 484 (1996).Â  

 
   [4]  Reyelt et al. v. S.C. Tax Commâ€™n, C/A No. 
    6-93-1491-3 (D.S.C. 1993).

 
   [5]  Posadas de Puerto Rico Assocs. v. Tourism Co. 
    of P.R., 478 U.S. 328, 341 (1986).

THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Ernest Dwight Perry, 
          Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal 
  From Newberry County
  Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion 
  No. 3783
  Submitted December 8, 2003 
  â€“ Filed April 26, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
       
        Senior Assistant Appellate 
          Defender Wanda P. Hagler, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan 
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant 
          Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, Assistant Attorney General 
          W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor William Townes Jones, 
          of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, 
  A.J.:Â  A jury convicted Ernest Dwight Perry of trafficking in marijuana, 
  manufacturing marijuana, manufacturing marijuana on the lands of another, and 
  resisting arrest.Â  The trial judge sentenced Perry to concurrent sentences of 
  twenty-five years for trafficking in marijuana, five years for manufacturing 
  marijuana, five years for entry on anotherâ€™s land for the purpose of cultivating 
  marijuana, and a consecutive sentence of one year for resisting arrest.Â  Additionally, 
  he was ordered to pay a fine of $25,000 for trafficking in marijuana.Â  Perry 
  appeals, arguing the trial judge erred:Â  (1) in failing to direct a verdict 
  as to the charges of trafficking in marijuana and manufacturing marijuana; (2) 
  in denying his motion to require the State to elect to prosecute either manufacturing 
  marijuana or entry on anotherâ€™s land for the purpose of cultivating marijuana; 
  and (3) in denying his motion to quash the indictment charging him with assault 
  on a police officer while resisting arrest.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On July 21, 2000, the Newberry County 
  Sheriffâ€™s Office conducted an eradication flight over different areas of the 
  county in an attempt to locate marijuana.Â  During this flight, Investigator 
  Wesley Boland spotted eight to ten plots of what appeared to be marijuana growing 
  near Prosperity.Â  He also saw hoses running through the woods to each of the 
  plots.Â  The hoses ran from a pump house behind Perryâ€™s residence.Â  Officers 
  with the Newberry County Sheriffâ€™s Department and the Newberry Police Department 
  approached the house and found Perry at the pump house.Â  Based on their investigation, 
  the officers arrested Perry.Â  As Officer Lawson was attempting to get Perry 
  into the police car, Perry became belligerent and kicked Lawson in the right 
  shin. 
Subsequently, 
  the officers obtained a search warrant and executed it on Perryâ€™s house and 
  property. Â The water hoses from the pump house led to fourteen different 
  plots on the adjacent property. Â Officer Robert Dennis testified he recovered 
  several bags of marijuana from inside the house.Â  Wayne Nichols owned 
  the property where all the plants were growing.Â  However, he testified he knew 
  nothing about the marijuana and had not given Perry permission to grow marijuana 
  on his property. Â While conducting the search of the property, the officers 
  pulled up 456 marijuana plants.Â  During the search, the officers inventoried, 
  tagged, and processed the plants for future testing.Â  Shortly thereafter, the 
  officers transported the plants to a secure location. 
 At trial, Investigator Max Pickelsimer 
  was qualified as an expert to analyze marijuana.Â  He testified that he received 
  456 stalks of marijuana and analyzed thirty-four of the stalks.Â  He explained 
  the stalks were wet when they were bundled together and, as a result, they became 
  stuck together as they dried.Â  In attempting to separate them, he was able to 
  get thirty-four plants that were strong enough to analyze, and that all thirty-four 
  plants tested positive for marijuana.Â 
Perry 
  did not testify at trial.Â  The jury convicted him of trafficking in marijuana, 
  manufacturing marijuana, manufacturing marijuana on the lands of another, and 
  resisting arrest.Â  Perry appeals.
DISCUSSION

 
  
 I.                  
  Directed Verdict
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  
Perry 
  contends the trial judge erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict 
  on the charges of trafficking in marijuana and manufacturing marijuana.Â  We 
  disagree.
On appeal from 
  the denial of a directed verdict in a criminal case, this Court must view the 
  evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Al-Amin, 
  353 S.C. 405, 411, 578 S.E.2d 32, 35 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Morgan, 
  352 S.C. 359, 364, 574 S.E.2d 203, 205 (Ct. App. 2002). When ruling on a motion 
  for a directed verdict, the trial judge is concerned with the existence or nonexistence 
  of evidence, not its weight. State v. Wilds, 355 S.C. 269, 274, 584 S.E.2d 
  138, 140 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  If there is any direct evidence or any substantial 
  circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, 
  this Court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  State 
  v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 653, 572 S.E.2d 267, 273 (2002).Â  On the other 
  hand, if the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged, a defendant 
  is entitled to a directed verdict.Â  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 
  544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001); State v. Padgett, 354 S.C. 268, 271, 580 S.E.2d 
  159, 161 (Ct. App. 2003), cert. denied (Sept. 24, 2003).
A.Â Â Â Â Â  
  Trafficking in Marijuana
Perry 
  argues he was entitled to a directed verdict on the charge of trafficking in 
  marijuana because the State failed to present evidence that he was in actual 
  or constructive possession of 100 to 1000 marijuana plants, the quantity element 
  of the offense.Â  Specifically, he claims the State failed to establish this 
  element of the offense given it only tested thirty-four of the seized plants.Â  
  
A person 
  is guilty of trafficking in marijuana if he is in actual or constructive possession 
  of 100 to 1000 marijuana plants.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(e)(1)(b) (2002) [1] ; see State v. Muhammed, 338 S.C. 
  22, 27, 524 S.E.2d 637, 639 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œPossession requires more than 
  mere presence.Â  The State must show the defendant had dominion or control over 
  the thing allegedly possessed or had the right to exercise dominion or control 
  over it.â€). 
Viewed 
  in the light most favorable to the State, we find there was evidence that reasonably 
  tended to prove Perryâ€™s guilt as to the charge of trafficking in marijuana.Â  
  Investigator Salazar testified that 456 marijuana plants were seized from property 
  that was adjacent to Perryâ€™s residence. Â The hoses on the plots originated from 
  a pump house behind Perryâ€™s residence.Â  Police Chief Swindler testified he recognized 
  all the plants as marijuana based on the appearance and the smell of the plants. 
  Â Investigator Pickelsimer testified all the plants appeared to be of 
  the same type and that the sample thirty-four plants all tested positive for 
  marijuana.Â  Â Based on this evidence, it could be fairly and logically 
  deduced that Perry was in actual or constructive possession of 100 to 1000 marijuana 
  plants.Â  See State v. Pinckney, 339 S.C. 346, 349, 529 S.E.2d 
  526, 527 (2000) (stating in reviewing the refusal to grant a directed verdict 
  in a criminal case, the evidence is viewed in the light most favorable to the 
  State to determine whether there is any direct or substantial circumstantial 
  evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which 
  guilt may be fairly and logically deduced).
Â  
Our decision 
  is supported by the holdings of several state and federal courts.Â  For example, 
  the Kentucky Court of Appeals upheld a conviction for trafficking in marijuana 
  when the State presented evidence that only six of the ninety-eight plants that 
  had been seized were tested and found to be positive for marijuana.Â  Taylor 
  v. Commonwealth, 984 S.W.2d 482, 484-85 (Ky. Ct. App. 1998).Â  Because the 
  weight or amount of the marijuana was an element of the trafficking offense 
  with which he was charged, Taylor argued that each plant used to determine the 
  total weight should have been tested.Â  The Court rejected this argument, finding 
  there was no evidence that the ninety-two plants that were not tested were different 
  from the six plants that were tested.Â  Id. (relying on and discussing 
  state and federal cases which held that the prosecution is not required to test 
  samples from all individual portions of a controlled substance when the charged 
  offense relates to a certain amount of a controlled substance).Â  
Similarly, 
  the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals has held that the prosecution need not produce 
  the results of any testing to survive a directed verdict motion for growing 
  marijuana.Â  United States v. Fry, 787 F.2d 903, 906 (4th Cir.), cert. 
  denied, 479 U.S. 861 (1986).Â  In Fry, the defendant was convicted 
  of growing and conspiring to grow and distribute marijuana.Â  As one of his issues 
  on appeal, Fry argued that the evidence was insufficient to convict because 
  law enforcement destroyed all the plants they seized before performing chemical 
  analysis.Â  The Court affirmed Fryâ€™s convictions, holding testimony from two 
  of Fryâ€™s co-conspirators and a law enforcement officer established the plants 
  were marijuana plants.Â  The Court ruled that â€œ[s]uch lay testimony is sufficient 
  to support a jury finding that the plants were marijuana plants.â€Â  Id. 
  at 906.
Based 
  on the foregoing, the trial judge properly denied Perryâ€™s motion for a directed 
  verdict as to the charge of trafficking in marijuana.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Manufacturing 
  Marijuana
Perry 
  next argues the trial judge erred in declining to direct a verdict on the charge 
  of manufacturing marijuana. Because the marijuana was not grown on his property, 
  he contends there was insufficient proof of guilt on this charge.Â  
Section 
  44-53-370 of the South Carolina Code makes it unlawful to â€œmanufacture, distribute, 
  dispense, deliver, . . . a controlled substance or a controlled substance analogue.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(a)(1) (2002).Â  As a threshold matter, the plain language 
  of the statute does not require the manufacturing of marijuana to be on oneâ€™s 
  own property. See State v. Baucom, 340 S.C. 339, 342, 531 S.E.2d 
  922, 923 (2000) (â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain 
  and effectuate the legislative intent whenever possible.â€); State v. Morgan, 
  352 S.C. 359, 366, 574 S.E.2d 203, 206 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œThe legislatureâ€™s intent 
  should be ascertained primarily from the plain language of the statute.â€).Â Â  
  As such, the fact that someone else owns the property is irrelevant in proving 
  the elements of the offense of manufacturing marijuana.Â  
With 
  this in mind, we turn to the issue concerning the sufficiency of the evidence.Â  
  Viewed in the light most favorable to the State, we find the judge properly 
  submitted to the jury the charge of manufacturing marijuana.Â  Investigator Wesley 
  Boland testified he was engaged in an eradication flight over Newberry County 
  on July 21, 2000, when he observed marijuana growing in a field.Â  He also observed 
  water hoses leading to a pump house behind Perryâ€™s house.Â  Law enforcement executed 
  a search warrant on Perryâ€™s property and found water hoses leading from Perryâ€™s 
  pump house to fourteen different plots that had marijuana plants growing. Â This 
  evidence reasonably tended to prove Perryâ€™s guilt.Â  Thus, the trial judge properly 
  denied Perryâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.
 II. Motion to 
  Require the State to Elect
Perry asserts 
  the trial judge erred in denying his motion to require the State to elect to 
  prosecute either the offense of manufacturing marijuana or the offense of manufacturing 
  marijuana on the land of another. [2] Â  We disagree. [3] Â  
At the close 
  of the Stateâ€™s case, defense counsel moved for the State to elect between the 
  two manufacturing offenses.Â  Because the evidence only showed that the marijuana 
  had been grown on Wayne Nicholsâ€™s property, and not Perryâ€™s, counsel contended 
  the jury could not find Perry â€œguilty of both under the circumstances in this 
  case.â€Â  The trial judge denied the motion.Â  Based on the statutory language 
  of the two offenses, the judge found the â€œLegislature intended for this to be 
  a separate offense if you go onto the lands of another to do that.â€ 
A.
â€œ[A] 
  motion to elect is addressed to the sound discretion of the court.â€Â  City 
  of Greenville v. Chapman, 210 S.C. 157, 159, 41 S.E.2d 865, 866 (1947).Â  
  In Chapman, our Supreme Court stated:

  The rule in this state is that 
    distinct offenses--felonies or misdemeanors--may be charged in separate counts 
    of the same indictment, whether growing out of the same transaction or not.Â  
    If the several offense[s] charged do not grow out of the same transaction, 
    then the proper practice is to require the prosecuting officer to elect upon 
    which count he will proceed.Â  But, when several offenses charged grow out 
    of the same transaction, then the prosecuting officer is not required to elect, 
    and the court instructs the jury to pass upon the several counts separately, 
    and write their verdict accordingly.

Id. 
  at 160, 41 S.E.2d at 866 (quoting State v. Lee, 147 S.C. 480, 483, 145 
  S.E.285, 286 (1928)).Â  In interpreting Chapman, this Court found that 
  offenses may be joined in the same indictment and tried together â€œwhere they 
  (1) â€˜aris[e] out of a single chain of circumstances,â€™ (2) â€˜are proved by the 
  same evidence,â€™ (3) â€˜are of the same general nature,â€™ and (4) no â€˜real right 
  of the defendant has been jeopardized.â€™â€ State v. Tate, 286 S.C. 462, 
  464, 334 S.E.2d 289, 290 (Ct. App. 1985) (quoting Chapman, 210 S.C. at 
  160, 41 S.E.2d at 867).Â Â Â  
In the 
  instant case, all of the charged offenses arose out of a single transaction 
  and met the requirements outlined in Tate.Â  Thus, the trial judge did 
  not abuse his discretion when he denied Perryâ€™s motion to require the State 
  to elect to prosecute either the offense of manufacturing marijuana or the offense 
  of entering the land of another for the purpose of cultivating marijuana.Â  See 
  Walker, 349 S.C. at 52, 562 S.E.2d at 314 (indicating defendant may be 
  indicted and tried for trafficking marijuana, manufacturing marijuana, and cultivating 
  marijuana on the land of another); see also State v. Hall, 280 
  S.C. 74, 77, 310 S.E.2d 429, 431 (1983) (holding distinct criminal offenses 
  may arise from a single act).
B.
In a related 
  argument, Perry claims the denial of this motion resulted in a double jeopardy 
  violation.Â  He asserts, â€œa single manufacturing/cultivating offense applied 
  to the case as opposed to the allegation that two manufacturing/cultivating 
  offenses occurred.â€ 
Initially, 
  we question whether this issue is preserved for our review.Â  Based on the arguments 
  presented at trial, we can discern no specific argument concerning a violation 
  of double jeopardy.Â  As such, we need not address this issue. See Medlock 
  v. One 1985 Jeep Cherokee VIN 1JCWB7828FT129001, 322 S.C. 127, 132, 470 
  S.E.2d 373, 376 (1996) (holding double jeopardy issue must be raised to the 
  trial court to be preserved for appellate review); see also Humbert 
  v. State, 345 S.C. 332, 337, 548 S.E.2d 862, 865 (2001) (stating issues 
  not raised and ruled upon in the trial court will not be considered on appeal).Â  
  However, to the extent counselâ€™s argument can be construed as relating to double 
  jeopardy, we address the merits of the issue. 
Section 
  44-53-370(a)(1) provides that it is unlawful for a person â€œto manufacture . 
  . . a controlled substance.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(a)(1) (2002).Â  Pursuant 
  to section 16-11-617, â€œ[i]t is unlawful for a person to enter on the land of 
  another for the purpose of cultivating or attempting to cultivate marijuana.Â  
  The provisions of this section are cumulative to other provisions of law.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-617 (2003) (emphasis added).Â  
The United 
  States Constitution and the South Carolina Constitution protect against double 
  jeopardy.Â  The Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution provides that 
  â€œ[n]o person shall . . . be subject for the same offence to be twice put in 
  jeopardy of life or limb . . ..â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. V.Â  The South Carolina 
  Constitution states:Â  â€œNo person shall be subject for the same offense to be 
  twice put in jeopardy of life or liberty . . ..â€Â  S.C. Const.Â  art. I, Â§ 12.Â  
  
â€œThe 
  Double Jeopardy clause protects against:Â  (1) a second prosecution for the same 
  offense after acquittal;Â  (2) a second prosecution for the same offense after 
  conviction; and (3) multiple punishments for the same offense.â€Â  State v. 
  Nelson, 336 S.C. 186, 195, 519 S.E.2d 786, 790 (1999).Â  Our Supreme Court 
  has reaffirmed that Blockburger v. United States, 284 U.S. 299 (1932), 
  is â€œthe only remaining test for determining a double jeopardy violation, in 
  both multiple punishment and successive prosecution cases.â€Â Â  State v. Easler, 
  327 S.C. 121, 132, 489 S.E.2d 617, 623 (1997).
â€œIn Blockburger 
  v. United States, the United States Supreme Court held where the same act 
  or transaction constitutes a violation of two distinct statutory provisions, 
  â€˜the test to determine whether these are two offenses or only one is whether 
  each provision requires proof of an additional fact which the other does not.â€™â€Â  
  Stevenson v. State, 335 S.C. 193, 198, 516 S.E.2d 434, 436-37 (1999) 
  (quoting Blockburger, 284 U.S. at 304).Â Â  However, â€œa court may conclude 
  there is no double jeopardy violation even if the same elements test is met 
  where the legislature clearly intends multiple punishments for a single act.â€Â  
  State v. Price, 333 S.C. 267, 270 n.4, 510 S.E.2d 215, 217 n.4 (1998).Â  
  
Because 
  the offense of cultivating or attempting to cultivate marijuana on the land 
  of another requires proof of an element that is not present in the charge of 
  manufacturing marijuana, there exists no double jeopardy violation.Â  Furthermore, 
  based on the plain language of section 16-11-617, the General Assembly clearly 
  intended for this offense to be cumulative to other provisions of the law.Â  
  Therefore, it did not violate Perryâ€™s protection against double jeopardy to 
  be convicted of both offenses.Â  Cf. State v. Brown, 319 S.C. 400, 
  408, 461 S.E.2d 828, 831 (Ct. App. 1995) (emphasizing that â€œthere is no [double 
  jeopardy] prohibition against the contemporaneous prosecution by the State for 
  both possession with intent to distribute and distribution of crack cocaine 
  and the related school charges where . . . they arise out of the same conductâ€).
 III. Motion to 
  Quash the Indictment for Resisting Arrest
Perry 
  contends the trial court erred in denying his motion to quash the indictment 
  charging him with assault on a police officer while resisting arrest. Because 
  the date of the offense as stated in the indictment was incorrect, Perry argues 
  the indictment was defective and, as result, the court was without subject matter 
  jurisdiction.Â Â  We disagree.
At trial, 
  defense counsel moved to â€œquashâ€ [4]  the indictment after Officer Lawson testified to the physical 
  altercation with Perry. Â Counsel argued the two-count indictment alleged 
  the incidents occurred on July 24, 2000, but all the testimony indicated the 
  incidents happened on July 21, 2000. Â The trial judge denied the motion, 
  but stated he would reconsider the motion at the close of the Stateâ€™s case.
After 
  the State rested its case, Perry renewed his motion, arguing he was in jail 
  on July 24, and â€œthe State has failed to prove the [sic] sufficient evidence 
  with respect to that particular indictment.â€ [5] Â  The State relied on the language in the indictment, 
  â€œ . . . did in Newberry County, state aforesaid, on or about the 24th day of 
  July, 2000, willfully and unlawfully resist an arrest . . ..â€Â  Additionally, 
  the State argued the indictment was sufficient to put Perry on notice of the 
  charges against him and it had met the burden on each element of the charge. 
  Â The trial judge again denied the motion on the ground that it was a 
  typographical error.Â  The judge reasoned,Â  â€œI think everyone has been on the 
  same page since day one that it was alleged that at the time he was arrested 
  it is no question that it was on the 21st.â€ Â 
A circuit court has subject matter 
  jurisdiction over a criminal offense if:Â  (1) there has been an indictment that 
  sufficiently states the offense; (2) there has been a waiver of indictment; 
  or (3) the charge is a lesser-included offense of the crime charged in the indictment.Â  
  Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 362, 495 S.E.2d 773, 777 (1998).Â  â€œAn 
  indictment passes legal muster if it â€˜charges the crime substantially in the 
  language of the . . . statute prohibiting the crime or so plainly that the nature 
  of the offense charged may be easily understood . . ..â€™â€Â  State v. Reddick, 
  348 S.C. 631, 635, 560 S.E.2d 441, 443 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 17-19-20(1985)); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20 (2003) (â€œEvery indictment 
  shall be deemed and judged sufficient and good in law which, in addition to 
  allegations as to time and place, as required by law, charges the crime substantially 
  in the language of the common law or of the statute prohibiting the crime or 
  so plainly that the nature of the offense charged may be easily understood and, 
  if the offense be a statutory offense, that the offense be alleged to be contrary 
  to the statute in such case made and provided.â€).
The indictment 
  for the charge of resisting arrest provided:

  That ERNEST DWIGHT PERRY, did in 
    Newberry County, state aforesaid, on or about the 24th day of July, 
    2000, wilfully and unlawfully resist an arrest being made by one whom the 
    said defendant knew or reasonably should have known was a law enforcement 
    officer, to wit:Â  Officer Curtis Lawson, in violation of section 16-9-320 
    of the South Carolina Code of Laws, 1976, as amended[.]

The text 
  of this indictment charges the crime of resisting arrest in substantially the 
  same language as section 16-9-320(1).Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-9-320(A) (2003) (â€œIt 
  is unlawful for a person knowingly and wilfully to oppose or resist a law enforcement 
  officer in serving, executing, or attempting to serve or execute a legal writ 
  or process or to resist an arrest being made by one whom the person knows or 
  reasonably should know is a law enforcement officer, whether under process or 
  not.â€).Â Â  As such, there is no jurisdictional defect given Perry was apprised 
  of the offense with which he was being charged.
  
CONCLUSION 
  
Accordingly, Perryâ€™s 
  convictions and sentences are
AFFIRMED.
HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.



 
   
    [1] Â Â  We note section 44-53-370 was amended effective May 20, 2002.Â  
    This amendment, however, does not affect the merits of this case.

 
   
    [2] Â Â  Perry repeatedly refers to this offense as â€œmanufacturing marijuana 
    on the land of another.â€Â  However, the actual offense charged is, â€œEntry on 
    anotherâ€™s land for purpose of cultivating marijuana.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-617 
    (2003). Our Supreme Court has recognized the distinction between â€œcultivatingâ€ 
    and â€œmanufacturing.â€ State v. Walker, 349 S.C. 49, 52 n.2, 562 S.E.2d 
    313, 314 n.2 (2002) (stating â€œ[e]vidence sufficient to sustain a conviction 
    for manufacturing marijuana may not always be sufficient to sustain a conviction 
    for cultivating marijuana on the lands of another, even where there is no 
    dispute the property belonged to someone other than the defendantâ€).Â  Perry 
    has never asserted any argument regarding this distinction.

 
   
    [3] Â Â  Although it is not determinative of the outcome of this issue, 
    we note the trial judge sentenced Perry to concurrent terms of five years 
    imprisonment on these charges, which, in turn, were to be served concurrently 
    with the twenty-five-year sentence Perry received for trafficking in marijuana.Â  
    As such, we are not required to review this issue.Â  See State v. 
    Ervin, 333 S.C. 351, 359, 510 S.E.2d 220, 225 (Ct. App. 1998) (recognizing 
    appellate court has discretion to review issues concerning convictions which 
    involve concurrent sentences).

 
   
    [4]  Counsel never specifically made a motion to quash the indictment 
    but simply stated the dates in the indictment were incorrect based on the 
    testimony. 

 
   
    [5]  The language used by defense counsel in renewing his motion at the 
    close of the Stateâ€™s case indicates that he was actually moving for a directed 
    verdict on this charge.Â  On appeal, Perry only raises an argument regarding 
    the validity of the indictment and not the sufficiency of the evidence.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Errin Hutton,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Donald W. Beatty, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3785
Submitted February 23, 2004 â€“ Filed April 26, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey, Office of Appellate Defense, 
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson 
  and Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.: Following a jury trial, Errin 
  Hutton was found guilty of three counts of kidnapping, one count of armed robbery, 
  two counts of attempted armed robbery, one count of burglary in the first degree, 
  and one count of grand larceny.Â  Hutton appeals the trial judgeâ€™s denial of 
  his motion to dismiss based on the fact that his counsel was deprived of the 
  opportunity to fully cross-examine a key Stateâ€™s witness when he was not provided 
  with a pre-trial statement.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Hutton was indicted for the various charges 
  in connection with events occurring on March 8, 2001.Â  James Bellinger testified 
  that on the night of the incident, he was at home with his wife and two young 
  children watching television when he heard a knock at the door.Â  He found a 
  man named Darryl and the appellant, Errin Hutton, at the door.Â  Darryl asked 
  Bellinger if he could get him a bag of marijuana.Â  Bellinger, who had met Darryl 
  on one previous occasion, told him he had to go across the street and talk to 
  a friend to see if he could get the drugs.Â  Bellinger was accompanied by appellant 
  when he went across the street and asked his friend J.T. to get â€œa quarter bag.â€ 
  After being told it would be twenty-five to thirty minutes before they could 
  get the drugs, Bellinger and appellant walked back across the street to a car.Â  
  Sitting in the carâ€™s driverâ€™s seat was a woman, identified by appellant as his 
  girlfriend, and sitting in the backseat was a man.Â  Darryl then got in the car, 
  and the man sitting in the backseat, Tony, got out of the car.Â  Tony and appellant 
  asked Bellinger if he had anything to smoke in the house, and then began telling 
  Bellinger that he owed them $500.00.Â  Bellinger testified that as he stepped 
  onto his porch, a gun was pulled on him and he was instructed to go inside his 
  home.Â  Once inside, appellant escorted Bellinger to the bedroom, while Tony 
  stood in the hallway to keep an eye on Bellingerâ€™s wife.Â  While in the bedroom, 
  appellant ransacked the area and asked where Bellinger kept his valuables.Â  
  Appellant started getting upset when he could not find anything.Â  When appellant 
  turned his back, Bellinger attempted to get the gun, but appellant hit him in 
  the head with the gun.Â  Bellinger stumbled and appellant hit him again.Â  Appellant 
  then cocked the gun and Bellinger saw a bullet fly out of the chamber.Â  Bellingerâ€™s 
  wife indicated there was a phone call, at which point appellant told Bellinger 
  to go into the living room.Â  Bellingerâ€™s wife then realized what was happening, 
  and told the men to leave her home.Â  As she approached the front door, Tony 
  picked her up and sat her on the couch.Â  Tony then took Bellingerâ€™s wifeâ€™s purse 
  and emptied the contents.Â  Appellant held Bellinger at gunpoint as Tony ransacked 
  the childrenâ€™s room.Â  The ordeal in the living room lasted approximately fifteen 
  minutes, during which time appellant put the gun to Bellingerâ€™s head, and on 
  his wife and children, and threatened to kill them in front of each other.Â  
  Because appellant was becoming increasingly upset that they could find no valuables 
  and continued to threaten the family, Bellinger told him he â€œknew someone [who] 
  had some money.â€Â  Appellant got the home phone number and wrote it down and 
  indicated he was going to leave Tony in the house so he could contact him if 
  Bellinger â€œtried anything stupid.â€Â  
Bellinger testified he and appellant left in a 
  car belonging to Bellingerâ€™s wife and drove to Dustyâ€™s house.Â  There, they ran 
  into Carson Keen and Nathan Seals, who were in Nathanâ€™s truck.Â  Appellant and 
  Bellinger spoke to Carson about getting drugs, and they then left to go to Jessieâ€™s 
  house.Â  Jessie was not home, and they then drove to a convenience store so Carson 
  could use a phone.Â  Carson exited the truck and went to the pay phones while 
  Nathan remained in his truck.Â  Appellant instructed Bellinger to get out of 
  the car, and as Bellinger approached the pay phones, he observed appellant talking 
  to Nathan through the truck window.Â  Appellant opened the truck door and sat 
  inside it.Â  Bellinger then noticed that Nathan â€œgot a really scared look on 
  his face.â€Â  He saw Nathan dig through his pockets, and then take the keys out 
  of the ignition and give them to appellant.Â  During this time, while Carson 
  was at the phones, Bellinger attempted to relay to Carson what was happening, 
  but he did not seem to understand.Â  At that time, appellant made Nathan get 
  out of the truck, and had all of them walk into the store.Â  After purchasing 
  beer and cigarettes, the men walked back outside, and appellant proceeded to 
  pull the gun on Carson to rob him.Â  Carson pulled a knife on appellant and the 
  two began to struggle.Â  Bellinger and Nathan then ran, until they reached a 
  home where the occupants allowed them to call the police.Â  Approximately two 
  weeks later, Bellinger identified appellant in a photographic line-up as the 
  man who held him hostage and left the house with him that day.Â  
Belinda Bellinger likewise testified that on the 
  night in question, she was at home watching television with her husband and 
  her eighteen month old and ten day old sons, when they heard a knock at their 
  door.Â  Her husband eventually went to answer the door, and was gone for about 
  ten to fifteen minutes.Â  When he returned, he was accompanied by two men.Â  One 
  of the men went to the bedroom while the other stood in the hallway.Â  Belinda 
  did not recognize either of the men.Â  She made an in-court identification of 
  appellant as the man who went into the bedroom with her husband.Â  
While her husband was in the bedroom with appellant, 
  the door was shut.Â  The other man told Belinda everything was okay, which made 
  Belinda suspicious.Â  Their neighbor, J.T., from across the street called and 
  asked to speak to Bellinger.Â  When Belinda approached the bedroom to tell her 
  husband he had a phone call, Bellinger and appellant exited the room.Â  Belinda 
  then noticed a red mark on Bellingerâ€™s neck and saw that Bellinger looked scared.Â  
  She then knew something was not right.Â  When Bellinger talked on the phone, 
  she overheard him talk about marijuana.Â  The men then started asking for money.Â  
  Belinda told them to â€œtake it outside,â€ and the man who had stood in the hallway 
  then picked her up, sat her on the couch, told her to keep her mouth shut, and 
  removed her glasses from her face so that she could not see well.Â  The men started 
  saying they wanted money, and appellant opened the clip of the pistol to show 
  Belinda the bullets and told her he was not afraid to use the gun.Â  The men 
  ransacked the house, dumping Belindaâ€™s purse and removing a small amount of 
  cash from her wallet.Â  One of them also found Belindaâ€™s pepper spray, and threatened 
  to spray it on her sonâ€™s face.Â  The men became very angry when they could not 
  find anything to take, and appellant held the gun to Belindaâ€™s nose and to Bellingerâ€™s 
  temple, threatening to shoot each of them in the presence of the other.Â  
Bellinger told appellant he could take him to get 
  â€œsome money or whatever he wanted,â€ at which point appellant indicated he would 
  go with Bellinger, while the other man stayed at the house with Belinda and 
  the children.Â  Appellant got the home phone number and stated he would call 
  if anything happened. He also said he had friends outside in a car in case Belinda 
  attempted to leave.Â  Bellinger and appellant left the house, and the other man 
  stayed with Belinda.Â  Although she never saw him with a gun, the other man told 
  her he had one and he would use it.Â  While waiting in the house, the neighbor, 
  J.T., kept calling on the phone and asking if everything was okay.Â  After a 
  while, another neighbor, Mrs. Smith, came over to the house and asked Belinda 
  if she was okay.Â  Belinda did not invite her inside for fear of putting her 
  neighbor in danger.Â  She told the neighbor she was all right, and the neighbor 
  left.Â  J.T. continued to call Belinda asking her what was wrong, but she could 
  not tell him.Â  Belinda then noticed some headlights through the window blinds.Â  
  After looking through the window and realizing there were police out there, 
  the man ran out the back door.Â  Belinda walked outside with her children and 
  saw numerous police cars.Â  She also observed a man and a woman on the ground 
  with handcuffs on them.Â  
Nathan Seals testified that on March 8, 2001, he 
  was with Carson Keen at Dustyâ€™s house when Bellinger and appellant pulled up 
  in a car.Â  Bellinger looked like â€œhe had fear in his eyes.â€Â  He and Carson left 
  in his truck to go to Jessieâ€™s house, with Bellinger and appellant following 
  behind.Â  When Jessie was not home, Carson told Nathan to drive to the store 
  so he could use the pay phone.Â  While in the truck, Nathan gave Carson a steak 
  knife because he had a feeling that something was amiss. Â Carson exited the 
  truck and he and Bellinger went up to the pay phone.Â  As Nathan sat in his truck, 
  appellant jumped inside, pulled a gun out, and shoved it into Nathan, telling 
  Nathan he â€œneeded to give him everything.â€Â  Appellant told Nathan to remove 
  his necklace.Â  He asked Nathan if he had any guns, then began searching the 
  car for any weapons.Â  He then told Nathan that Bellinger owed him money and 
  if he did not get it, all of them, along with Bellingerâ€™s wife and children, 
  would be killed.Â  Appellant stated that Belinda and the children were being 
  held at gunpoint and if anything went wrong, he would call and have them shot.Â  
  Nathan handed appellant his necklace, and appellant took the keys from the ignition.Â  

Appellant told Nathan to get out of the truck, 
  and all of the men walked inside the store.Â  Some beer was purchased, and all 
  of them walked back outside.Â  Appellant called Carson over to talk to him, at 
  which point he put a gun to Carsonâ€™s side.Â  Carson then pulled out the knife 
  and held it to appellantâ€™s throat.Â  The two men began yelling at each other, 
  and Nathan and Bellinger ran away.Â  After going to a couple of homes, someone 
  finally let them in their house to call the authorities.Â  Nathan testified he 
  had never seen appellant before this incident.Â  He subsequently identified appellant 
  from a photographic line-up as the man who had robbed him that day.Â  
Carson Keen testified that on the night of March 
  8, 2001, he was at Dustyâ€™s house with Nathan Seals when Bellinger and appellant 
  drove up and asked for some cocaine.Â  Carson had never met appellant before.Â  
  Carson told them he could get them the drugs.Â  He noticed that Bellinger was 
  acting like â€œsomething bad was going on.â€Â  They went over to Jessieâ€™s house 
  to get some cocaine, but Jessie was not home.Â  Bellinger and appellant followed 
  them to a convenience store, where Carson made some calls in an attempt to get 
  some cocaine.Â  Carson could not reach the dealers he was trying to call, but 
  stayed at the phones pretending to make other calls because he was concerned 
  about the way Bellinger was acting.Â  Carson saw appellant get into Nathanâ€™s 
  truck.Â  At some point, appellant asked Carson to get him some beer.Â  When Carson 
  asked appellant for money to purchase the beer and appellant told Carson to 
  â€œjust go get it,â€ Carson thought he was going to be robbed.Â  When the men all 
  walked into the store, Bellinger followed behind Carson and told him appellant 
  was holding his family hostage.Â  Carson purchased the beer and walked back outside 
  toward the telephones, where he intended to call the police.Â  Before he had 
  a chance to use the phone, appellant called him over to the truck and pulled 
  a gun out, sticking it in Carsonâ€™s side.Â  Appellant told Carson to get in the 
  truck.Â  Carson refused and appellant told him to give him all his money.Â  At 
  that time, Carson pulled out a knife and stuck it to appellantâ€™s throat.Â  Appellant 
  then ran, jumped in the truck, and drove away.Â  Carson went into the store and 
  told them to call the police.Â  
Detha Smith testified that on the night of the 
  incident, she received a phone call from J.T.Â  As a result of that call, she 
  went over to Belindaâ€™s house.Â  She knocked on the door, and when Belinda answered, 
  she observed a man sitting on the couch.Â  Mrs. Smith asked Belinda what was 
  wrong, because it was unusual for Belinda to be sitting in her living room with 
  the lights out.Â  She could also tell that Belinda was upset.Â  When Mrs. Smith 
  would ask her questions, Belinda was unusually quiet.Â  Mrs. Smith told Belinda 
  that she was going to her house to try to get some help.Â  When she reached her 
  home, she called 9-1-1, and shortly thereafter numerous officers arrived on 
  the scene.Â  
During cross-examination of Bellinger, 
  it became apparent that Bellinger had given more than one written statement 
  to the police.Â  Bellinger testified that he gave a total of three written statements.Â  
  In the first statement, Bellinger wrote about one third or one half of the way 
  down the page, but did not finish it.Â  In this statement, he wrote only about 
  the robbery, and did not provide any information about the drug activity.Â  Bellinger 
  stated, â€œI wrote [the first statement] and [the police officers] told me are 
  you sure youâ€™re telling the truth.Â  They told me we know about the drug incident.Â  
  We know about there was drugs involved.Â  And they said, if you donâ€™t tell the 
  truth right now, admit to everything, that you could get in trouble.Â  And thatâ€™s 
  when I wrote the next one and told the truth about everything.â€Â  Bellinger said 
  he lied on the first statement, but only by leaving out the drug activity.Â  
  He stated, â€œ[T]he only difference in the statements was the fact that I was 
  going to try to find them drugs.â€Â  Bellinger testified that the first statement 
  was thrown away by an officer.Â  In the second statement, which Bellinger handwrote 
  but did not sign, he included the drug information, but did not go into details 
  about what occurred at the house.Â  The third statement, which was given on March 
  10, 2001 and included the drug activity and all of the events occurring on March 
  8, was provided to Huttonâ€™s counsel, but the first two were not.Â  
At trial, the Solicitor told the trial judge he 
  was only aware of the statement given on March 10, and he had no knowledge of 
  the other statement until Bellingerâ€™s testimony.Â  The trial judge allowed appellantâ€™s 
  counsel to cross-examine Bellinger outside the presence of the jury, so he could 
  determine what was in the first statement and use that information to impeach 
  Bellinger in front of the jury.Â  Thereafter, appellantâ€™s counsel moved for a 
  dismissal of the charges arguing, because the other statements Bellinger gave 
  were not available, he could not effectively cross-examine him.Â  The trial judge 
  denied Huttonâ€™s motion, ruling that he had an opportunity to question Bellinger 
  as to the content of the first two statements, and Bellinger had admitted the 
  information he provided was incorrect and gave the particulars of how it was 
  incorrect.Â  Appellant was found guilty on all charges and now appeals.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hutton argues the trial court erred in denying his motion to dismiss because his counsel was not provided with the initial statement made by Bellinger, and therefore he was deprived of the opportunity to fully cross-examine a key Stateâ€™s witness.[1] We
disagree.
Pursuant to the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, criminal prosecutions must comport with prevailing notions of fundamental fairness. California v. Trombetta, 467 U.S. 479, 485 (1984). This standard requires criminal defendants be afforded a meaningful opportunity to present a complete defense. Id. The State does not, however, have an absolute duty to preserve potentially useful evidence that might exonerate a defendant. State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 538, 552 S.E.2d 300, 307 (2001). Furthermore, â€œ[w]hatever duty the Constitution imposes on the States to preserve evidence, that duty must be limited to evidence that might be expected to play a significant role in the suspectâ€™s defense.â€ Trombetta, 467 U.S. at 488. To establish a due process violation where the State fails to preserve evidence, a defendant must demonstrate (1) that the State destroyed the evidence in bad faith, or (2) that the evidence possessed an exculpatory value apparent before the evidence was destroyed and the defendant cannot obtain other evidence of comparable value by other means. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. at 538, 552 S.E.2d at 307.

There is no evidence the State destroyed the initial statement of witness Bellinger in bad faith. Bellinger testified the officer threw away theunfinished statement after Bellinger admitted it was not the complete truth, and the officer gave him another piece of paper and told him to â€œwrite the truth.â€ There is simply no indication the officer who threw away the first statement did so in an effort to suppress exculpatory evidence, or with any other bad faith motive. Rather, it appears the officer considered the statement that Bellinger began to write as having no evidentiary value since Bellinger himself admitted to the deception by omission in the statement.Â 
As to the second prong, we find nothing to indicate that the evidence possessed an exculpatory value that was apparent before the evidence was destroyed. Exculpatory evidence is evidence which creates a reasonable doubt about the defendantâ€™s guilt. State v. Jarrell, 350 S.C. 90, 107, 564 S.E.2d 362, 372 (Ct. App. 2002). Here, Bellinger testified the only difference in the statements was that he only included the robbery in the first one, and not the fact that he was going to help the appellant find drugs. There is nothing in this statement which would create a reasonable doubt as to appellantâ€™s guilt. Nor can we find appellant could not obtain other evidence of comparable value by other means. The trial court allowed trial counsel to thoroughly cross-examine Bellinger about the first statement he gave and its contents. Further, at best, the initial statement was of value to appellant in the impeachment of Bellinger. On cross-examination, Bellinger admitted he did not initially tell one of the officerâ€™s about the drugs, he knew that he was not being truthful, and he gave a second statement after an officer accused him of lying. Thus, counsel was able to thoroughly impeach Bellinger before the jury. 
  Finally, we see no prejudice to appellant as a result 
    of the destruction of the unfinished statement.Â  As noted, appellant was able 
    to effectively impeach Bellinger regarding his inconsistent statements.Â  See 
    State v. Jones, 325 S.C. 310, 322, 479 S.E.2d 517, 523 (Ct. App. 1996) 
    (appellants failed to demonstrate prejudice resulting from Stateâ€™s failure 
    to reveal new statement of witness where counsel was able to impeach witness 
    about new allegation by introducing prior statement and questioning witness 
    about the discrepancy).Â  State v. Gathers, 295 S.C. 476, 482, 369 S.E.2d 
    140, 143 (1988) (appellant failed to show prejudice from alleged non-disclosure 
    of doctorâ€™s equivocation on whether wound was pre- or post-mortem where appellant 
    effectively cross-examined doctor at trial and doctor conceded she was unsure 
    whether wound occurred before or after death); State v. Woods, 
    282 S.C. 18, 20, 316 S.E.2d 673, 674 (1984) (there was no merit to argument 
    that appellant was denied adequate confrontation of witnesses against him 
    based on missing medical records where treating psychiatrist testified and 
    was fully cross-examined by appellantâ€™s trial counsel).Â  Further, the 
    other witnessesâ€™ testimony directly comports with Bellingerâ€™s testimony regarding 
    the specific chain of events on March 8, 2001 and the identity of appellant 
    as one of the perpetrators.Â  Several of these witnesses were present as the 
    crimes occurred, including Bellingerâ€™s wife and the other victims, who testified 
    as to the events just as Bellinger did. Â We find the other witnessesâ€™ 
    testimony provides overwhelming evidence of appellantâ€™s guilt.Â  See 
    State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989) (when guilt 
    has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational 
    conclusion can be reached, the appellate court should not set aside a conviction 
    because of insubstantial errors not affecting the result).Â Â Â  
  While we do not condone the destruction of any statements 
    made by witnesses to the authorities, we consider dismissal of criminal charges 
    a drastic remedy which should rarely be invoked as a sanction for the Stateâ€™s 
    failure to preserve evidence.Â  We still caution the prosecution and law enforcement 
    authorities that the destruction of evidence will be highly scrutinized; however, 
    we cannot find appellant was entitled to a dismissal based on the facts of 
    this case.Â  After considering the lack of evidence of bad faith on the part 
    of the State in the destruction of the evidence, the importance of the missing 
    evidence in light of the availability of evidence of comparable value, and 
    the overwhelming sufficiency of the other evidence produced at the trial to 
    sustain appellantâ€™s conviction, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial 
    of appellantâ€™s motion to dismiss.
  For the foregoing reasons, appellantâ€™s convictions 
    are
 STILWELL, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   [1] Appellant 
    challenges only the failure of the State to provide the initial statement 
    that was allegedly thrown away.Â  He does not make any argument regarding the 
    second statement given on the same date in which Bellinger stated he â€œtold 
    the truth about everything.â€Â

title: Hardin v. SCDOT
description: In this civil action, the court analyzes whether the circuit court judge erred in ruling that respondents are entitled to just compensation for the loss in value of properties caused by the closing of two roads at an intersection.  Additionally, the court analyzes the efficacy of Gray v. S.C. Dept. of Highways and Public Transportation, 311 S.C. 144, 427 S.E.2d 899 (Ct. App. 1993).
