THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
John A. Hardin and Martha Hardin Curran, as Trustees of Marital Trust 
        2 under the Will of Martha S. Hardin, Deceased,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
The South Carolina Department of Transportation,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3786
Heard April 8, 2004 â€“ Filed April 26, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Beacham O. Brooker, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
David A. White, of Rock Hill, for Respondents.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  John A. Hardin and Martha Hardin Curran (collectively, 
  â€œRespondentsâ€) filed a complaint against the South Carolina Department of Transportation 
  (â€œSCDOTâ€) in inverse condemnation seeking compensation for the loss in value 
  to two [1]  tracts of land they owned on the north side 
  of Dave Lyle Boulevard on either side of its intersection with Baskins and Garrison 
  Roads in Rock Hill, South Carolina, because of the construction of a median 
  barrier in the center of Dave Lyle Boulevard.Â  The trial was bifurcated.Â  A 
  bench trial was held on the sole issue of whether the medianâ€™s construction 
  deprived Respondents of a property right entitling them to just compensation.Â  
  The trial judge ruled that a taking had occurred and ordered a separate trial 
  to assess just compensation.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Completed in 1974, Dave Lyle Boulevard is a high-speed, divided, 
  controlled-access, four-lane highway connecting Interstate 77 with downtown 
  Rock Hill.Â  Right of way for the highway was acquired from Respondentsâ€™ predecessor 
  in title in 1971.Â  The highway was planned and constructed to permit no private 
  entrances and a limited number of public road intersections in order to maintain 
  a high level of service and safety.
Prior to construction of Dave Lyle Boulevard, two local roads, Baskins Road 
  and Garrison Road, intersected in an â€œXâ€ pattern.Â  During construction of Dave 
  Lyle Boulevard, these roads were joined on each side of the new highway to provide 
  a shared single entry point.Â  A break in the controlled-access line and in the 
  highway median barrier accommodated the joined Baskins-Garrison entry point.
In 1992, the City of Rock Hill requested permission from the SCDOT 
  for a new intersection about 1,000 feet east of the Baskins-Garrison/Dave Lyle 
  intersection to accommodate a new road that would connect the Rock Hill Industrial 
  Park with York Technical College.Â  Because of the limitation on cross streets, 
  the SCDOT responded that a new intersection would require that the existing 
  Baskins-Garrison/Dave Lyle intersection be closed.Â  Several area landowners, 
  including Respondents, protested.Â  A public hearing was held on the matter.Â  
  After the hearing, SCDOT determined that, because right turns were less disruptive 
  than left turns, only the median would be closed, leaving the intersections 
  on each side â€œright turns in and [right turns] outâ€ only.Â  In 1998, a median 
  barrier was constructed across Dave Lyle Boulevard that prevents vehicular traffic 
  from crossing over the highway at that point.Â  This median barrier was erected 
  in the middle of Dave Lyle Boulevard at the point which Baskins and Garrison 
  Roads cross over the highway.
Respondents own two parcels of property that abut Baskins and Garrison Roads.Â  
  Due to the newly erected barrier, eastbound travelers on Dave Lyle can no longer 
  turn left across the highway to access Respondentsâ€™ properties and travelers 
  exiting Respondentsâ€™ properties can no longer cross the highway to access the 
  eastbound lane.
Respondents asserted they were entitled to just compensation for any loss in 
  value of their properties caused by the median.Â  The trial judge agreed and 
  ruled:

At the hearing in this case, Plaintiffs adduced convincing evidence that Plaintiffsâ€™ 
  Tracts A and B were specially injured by the closing of Baskins and Garrison 
  Roads, because they possessed the unique characteristic of directly abutting 
  the intersection of a controlled access highway.Â  I conclude that Plaintiffsâ€™ 
  [sic] are entitled to a jury trial for the determination of just compensation 
  due.Â  (Emphasis added).

ISSUES

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in finding that Respondents 
  had a valid property right infringed upon by the construction of the median 
  barricade?
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in excluding the official highway plans for 
  the project underlying the decision in Gray v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways 
  & Pub. Transp.?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The trial judge bifurcated the proceedings below and conducted a trial in equity 
  solely to determine the question of whether Respondents were deprived of a property 
  right entitling them to just compensation.Â  We note that the issue of whether 
  the proceeding conducted by the Circuit Court in a case of this type is equitable 
  or legal is novel in South Carolina.Â  We conclude that the proceeding is equitable 
  in nature and adopt the reasoning of the Supreme Court of Florida in Palm 
  Beach County v. Tessler, 538 So. 2d 846 (Fla. 1989).Â  Tessler explicated:

Actually, in an inverse condemnation proceeding of this nature, the trial judge 
  makes both findings of fact and findings of law.Â  As a fact finder, the judge 
  resolves all conflicts in the evidence.Â  Based upon the facts as so determined, 
  the judge then decides as a matter of law whether the landowner has incurred 
  a substantial loss of access by reason of the governmental activity.Â  Should 
  it be determined that a taking has occurred, the question of compensation is 
  then decided as in any other condemnation proceeding.

Id. at 850.Â  Accord Department of Pub. Works & Bldgs. 
  v. Wilson & Co., 340 N.E.2d 12 (Ill. 1975); Brock v. State Highway 
  Commâ€™n, 404 P.2d 934 (Kan. 1965); Guerard v. State, 220 N.W.2d 525 
  (N.D. 1974).
On appeal from an action in equity, the appellate court has authority 
  to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Williams v. Wilson, 349 S.C. 336, 563 S.E.2d 320 (2002); Townes Assocs. 
  Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Valid 
  Property Right
SCDOT argues the trial court erred in its holding that 
  the erection of the traffic barricade at issue infringed on a valid property 
  right of Respondents and entitled them to a trial for the ascertainment of just 
  compensation.Â  We disagree.
We address the issue of when an action regarding the 
  alteration of public thoroughfares may warrant just compensation to those owners 
  whose property is negatively affected by the change.
Our analysis begins with the case of Cherry v. Fewell, 
  48 S.C. 553, 26 S.E. 798 (1897).Â  In Cherry, the city of Rock Hill altered 
  a road approximately 225 feet from plaintiffâ€™s home, but not directly adjoining 
  his property.Â  The plaintiff alleged he was entitled to compensation because 
  this road closing required him â€œto take a more circuitous and difficult route, 
  to his great inconvenience personally, and to the great damage to his said lot 
  as a place of residence.â€Â  Id. at 559, 26 S.E. at 800.Â  The Supreme Court 
  affirmed the Circuit Courtâ€™s demurrer, finding a mere claim of inconvenience 


â€œin going from the street in front of his house to 
  a particular part of the city, on account of vacating and closing up certain 
  streets and alleys in another block, is the â€˜same kindâ€™ of damage that 
  would be sustained by all other persons in the city that might have occasion 
  to go that way, and although the inconvenience he may suffer may be greater 
  in degree than to any other person, that fact would not give him a right of 
  action.â€

Id.  at 563, 26 S.E. at 801 (quoting City 
  of E. St. Louis v. Oâ€™Flynn, 10 N.E. 395 (Ill. 1887)) (emphasis added).Â  
  The Courtâ€™s holding was predicated on the fact that plaintiffâ€™s claim did not 
  allege any other â€œspecial or peculiar injury, differing in kind, and not merely 
  in degree, from that which the public generally sustain[s], which alone would 
  entitle a private person to maintain an action . . . for damages.â€Â  Cherry, 
  48 S.C. at 560, 26 S.E. at 800.Â  
Cherry established the basic rule in South Carolina 
  that an alteration of a public roadway adjoining plaintiffâ€™s property constitutes 
  a taking of private property for public use within the constitutional prohibition.Â  
  However, when this alteration takes place on a part of the roadway not abutting
